fields.headline: Supernatural Birtwistle
fields.standfirst:
The Last Supper
Glyndebourne Touring Opera
***
fields.trailText:
The Last Supper
Glyndebourne Touring Opera
***
fields.body:
Harrison Birtwistle's The Last Supper, jointly commissioned by Glyndebourne and the Deutsche Staatsoper in Berlin, had its premiere in Germany last Easter. The emotions and the debate that the opera generated were testimony to its impact at the time. Yet the British premiere seemed to lack clout. What has happened in the interim?

Having not heard the opera in Berlin, I cannot draw comparisons between the Berlin and Glyndebourne premieres. But it does strike me that the work has flaws, the most prominent being a disparity between subject matter and expression. Ever the teller of tales and the narrator of variants of tales, Birtwistle combines a re-enactment of the events leading to the Crucifixion with a variation on the theme explored by Dostoevsky in The Brothers Karamazov: the return of Christ to earth to confront the legacy of his church. Eleven of the disciples are summoned to a second Passover celebration in the year 2000 by an enigmatic female figure called Ghost, part mediator between humanity and divinity, part commentator after the fashion of a Greek chorus. Judas appears unannounced, provoking the hostility of the other disciples until Jesus himself arrives to intervene.

Birtwistle's Judas is a tortured man, who acted out of the belief that God would reveal Christ's true nature as the Messiah by intervening to save his son on the cross. As the opera proceeds, however, it becomes apparent that Jesus's ultimate betrayer is not Judas but those who throughout history have acted vilely in Christ's name. The catalogue of Christianity's crimes builds up relentlessly - denial of the human body, the suppression of women, homophobia, racism, anti-semitism. The last is the ultimate atrocity for it is based on the denial of the fact that Christ himself was a Jew. "The Holocaust," Jesus sings, "shattered my heart."

It is at this point that Birtwistle stumbles. The score contains some of the most lyrically beautiful music he has written to date. But as he contemplates the catastrophic legacy of Christianity his inspiration seems to falter. The outrage and grief central to Robin Blaser's libretto does not find its equivalent in the incantatory movements of the score. Birtwistle, of course, may be implying that music is incapable of conveying such a nightmare - but I for one would dispute that.

Martin Duncan's production, hugely admired in Berlin, is a model of eloquent understatement, even though its central image - the disciples emerging in slow motion out of eternity into the present through a garishly lit time-tunnel - carries echoes, intentional or not, of Close Encounters of a Third Kind. Much of the singing is tremendous, with the voices of the disciples and the off-stage Chorus Mysticus blending to ravishing perfection. Susan Bickley and Thomas Randle are outstanding as Ghost and Judas respectively. Only William Dazeley, lacking charisma as Jesus, is a tiny bit disappointing. The conducting, from Birtwistle's regular collaborator Elgar Howarth, is on the cool side. The whole is an evening that never fails to excite the intellect, but only intermittently touches the heart.

At Glyndebourne (01273 813813) until Friday, then tours.

fields.headline: Gary Numan is still an alien - and still loves his car
fields.standfirst:
Brixton Academy, London
***
fields.trailText:
Brixton Academy, London
***
fields.body:
Now that Marilyn Manson and Nine Inch Nails's Trent Reznor are claiming to have been into Gary Numan for ever, it won't be long before his long-suffering core following will have to share him with outsiders. There were signs of infiltration at this one-off show promoting his new album, Pure (said by Numanoids to be his best in years, though it seems to contain exactly the same ratio of industro-beats to alienated keyboards as ever).

Some of the hordes, far too young to remember when Gaz was feeling safest of all in his car, were plainly there because Uncle Marilyn said so, and the old-timers looked none too happy. In the world of Numan, fandom is for life, and until you have endured decades of ridicule you have no business being at one of his tribal gatherings.

In the foyer was a board on which fans could scribble their thoughts about the man and his music. The international flavour (for example: "I'm coming from Chile and at last I see you") proved that alienation respects no boundaries. Numan's I-am-a-lonely-android schtick taps into a universal sense of dislocation. Never mind that the man himself is a happily married 42-year-old - for some he will always be the Chief Alien from Planet Misunderstood. Hence the Pavlovian reaction as he loped on stage, black PVC mac flapping around his ankles. The crowd were screaming for "Noo-man" even before the keyboards struck their first doomy note, and moshing by the time he began to sing.

Of the show there is little to say that does not include the well-worn words "glacial", "synth-laden" and "bewildering". Bewildering because Numan hasn't changed his sound since 1979 and it was impossible to tell whether any given song was brand new or 20 years old. Cars was easy enough to recognise, its bleeping six-note intro wired into the synapses of every clubber in the land since the recent Armand Van Helden remix. Me, I Disconnect From You was familiar, too, with its icy descending chords and Numan's down-a-mineshaft yelp.

But tracks from Pure, of which there were too many, were distinguishable only by a more industrial feel and more clanging from Numan's guitar. They contained no tunes - no wonder Manson and Reznor rave about them - and one wonders whether this can really be encouraged, given that Numan's traditional saving grace has been his melodies. The fans seemed happy enough, though. And, because alienation is a two-way street, so did Gary.

fields.headline: BBC Philharmonic/ Downes
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
*****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
*****
fields.body:
Last Saturday would have been the late conductor Sir Georg Solti's 88th birthday, and the BBC Philharmonic's programme was intended as a tribute to his towering contribution to the reputation of Wagner in Britain. It included the rarely heard concert suite from Götterdämmerung, which, as with the Prelude and Liebestod from Tristan, was compiled by Wagner himself in an attempt to reach as wide an audience as possible.

The strategy worked well enough; Nietzsche was won over after hearing these excerpts in the concert hall, and it is not difficult to see why. The compression of hours' worth of music into half-hour chunks works so well that the listener could easily feel guilty: it's all the pleasure without the pain.

Such guilt may have been somewhat assuaged by Downes's remarkable restraint in his conducting of the overtly theatrical overture to the Flying Dutchman. Disappointing as this may have been for some, any urge to reach for the volume control must have been mitigated by the conviction of the playing.

The Siegfried Idyll, Wagner's radiant birthday offering to his wife, received a comparably understated performance. This was Wagner at his most tender; no sudden passionate surging ruffled the gentle lyricism, while Downes's almost classical approach to phrasing allowed space for the overall structure to breathe.

Overall structure is perhaps something we tend not to listen for in performances of the Tristan prelude; here, absence of the familiar sense of urgency and short-breathed string phrasing produced a quite distinctive Tristan tone, almost more reflective than yearning. The young Swedish soprano Irene Theorin responded sensitively to Downes; although the final, long-awaited climax swamped her for a few moments she showed no sign of strain.

Wagner's selection of interludes from Götterdämmerung seamlessly weaves together Dawn and Siegfried's Rhine journey from act one with his funeral music and the closing immolation scene. In this last Theorin was a passionate Brünnhilde, while Downes allowed the orchestral sound to broaden and open out. The final moments, as Valhalla is consumed by flames, were shattering and glorious.

fields.headline: Massow merges firm into Rainbow
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ivan Massow, the wealthy gay businessman who defected from the Tories to Labour in August, is merging his finance company and stepping down as managing director to pursue other business interests.
fields.body:
Ivan Massow, the wealthy gay businessman who defected from the Tories to Labour in August, is merging his finance company and stepping down as managing director to pursue other business interests.

Massow Financial Services is to merge with Oxford-based Rainbow Finance, Britain's second-largest gay-focused independent financial adviser, to create a "super IFA" which it claims will be the biggest such company outside the United States.

Mr Massow, who quit the Conservative party because of its "bigoted"stance on Clause 28, will become chairman of the merged group.

"I will still have a desk at the company, but the deal I wanted was an entrepreneurial role where I wasn't tied down and could get involved in other businesses. But I don't know what those businesses are yet," he said.

Former Conservative minister Steven Norris made Mr Massow a special adviser during his campaign for mayor of London, but yesterday Mr Massow said he had no plans to use his extra free time to pursue a political career in the Labour Party.

No money will change hands as a result of the merger. Last year Massow Financial Services made a loss of £749,000 on turnover of £913,000, with Mr Massow taking a salary of £387,000, according to accounts posted at Companies House.

But Mr Massow says the loss figures are deceptive because they mask heavy investment in dealing with new corporate clients.

Over the past year he has taken on as clients sandwich chain Pret A Manger and a number of advertising agencies, and says he expects the combined group to record a profit next year.

Mr Massow insists that the new group will remain a strong advocate of gay and lesbian rights.

"The gay and lesbian market will continue to be our core business. People are still naturally very hesitant about speaking to insurance salesmen about their private affairs."

The merged company will be run by Louis Letourneau, a Canadian who founded Rainbow five years ago. "Bringing our two companies together gives us the critical mass for the message we are trying to work towards," he said.

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 8. Coping
fields.trailText: Most PAs know the sensation that hits you when you realise you simply can't do everything that's on your desk. Even putting in extra hours and cutting corners, you're still not going to deliver it all on time. Hopefully, this is a rare situation, but if you constantly lurch from crisis to missed deadline and back, there's something wrong with your workload. And for the sake of your self-esteem, your reputation at work and your health, you need to find out where the problem lies.
fields.body:
Most PAs know the sensation that hits you when you realise you simply can't do everything that's on your desk. Even putting in extra hours and cutting corners, you're still not going to deliver it all on time. Hopefully, this is a rare situation, but if you constantly lurch from crisis to missed deadline and back, there's something wrong with your workload. And for the sake of your self-esteem, your reputation at work and your health, you need to find out where the problem lies.

 Take a step back and look at where your work comes from. Is it because all three of your managers expect work at the same time? Or maybe your workload has increased since a colleague left? Perhaps your unreliable office kit means you're losing hours of valuable time looking at a dormant PC?

 When you've hit on the problem areas, talk to someone who can help. That doesn't mean moaning to your colleagues - talk to your boss or the personnel department and give them a written summary of the problem. Don't be emotional and never utter the words, "I can't cope". This is merely a business challenge which needs to be resolved, and the fact that you're doing just that shows that you can cope.

 Suggest some solutions - would a temp help to cover a busy time, or could work be delegated elsewhere? Maybe some of those important deadlines are not really so important and could be moved? Would more reliable, up-to-date office equipment pay dividends?

 If you're drowning because your managers refuse to prioritise your work, negotiate with the most approachable of them. Explain calmly that, given the timescales, tasks x, y and z will not all be delivered on time and which would they like first?

 Have a look at your time management, too. Track down your common time-wasters - be they people interrupting, constant shuffling through papers or maybe even your boss - and resolve to deal with them. Plan your days realistically and schedule in extra time for interruptions. Keep looking ahead, too. It's no good being surprised that those three days at a conference destroy your week's work plan. You should have seen that coming.

 And finally, don't panic. Think who your boss is more likely to respond to - someone who keeps repeating "I can't cope" and has no solutions to offer? Or the calm explanations and suggestions of a PA in control - even if it's faked?

 Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine.

fields.headline: The Book Room
fields.standfirst:
Arches Theatre, Glasgow
**
fields.trailText:
Arches Theatre, Glasgow
**
fields.body:
Paul Auster's fiction makes people do very strange things. In response to his writing, French artist Sophie Calle once followed strangers through city streets letting her destiny be led by them; she also set up home in a New York phone box and forced herself to smile at strangers.

Julie Fuller was so entranced by the postmodern enigma of his New York Trilogy that she has written her new play in the spirit of it - it is full of chance encounters, and there is a thin line between fiction and reality.

Greta is being sent copies of Paul Auster books from New York. Intrigued, she travels to the city. Instead of finding Auster, she finds Hope, a Polish immigrant. He had an Aunt Greta, killed in a road accident. Greta's mother met a similar fate. They talk about life, chance, bagels. After a while, Hope disappears. "It didn't mean anything," he says, before exiting through a fridge- freezer.

And it doesn't mean anything. Auster's ideas are being toyed with here. The elegance and depth of his writing is sadly lacking, as is any real sense of intrigue. We are supposed to believe that Greta is under surveillance, that she is lost in a labyrinthine existential maze. To suggest this, a man lurks behind the set, pushing Post-it notes and books on to the stage. At what is meant to be a dramatic climax, a cascade of notes come flying out of the freezer compartment, and your interest is suddenly gripped by the possibility that some oven chips might follow, or maybe some peas.

Greta does a lot of lying on her bed with books and saying trite things about them. By the time Moby's Porcelain comes on as one of the musical interludes, any sense of enigma has been squashed. This is all too obvious, too cliched.

There is a glimmer of dramatic possibility in the unlikely friendship between the two strangers, and you can't help wishing Fuller had dumped the Auster framework and explored the bizarre connections and disconnections of city life in her own way. "The question is the story itself," she quotes from Auster. As it stands, the story isn't strong enough to make you care about its answers.

Until Saturday. Box office: 0141-221 4001.

fields.headline: Swan Lake on mescaline
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
After Anthony Dowell became director of the Royal Ballet in 1986, one of his first projects was to oversee a new production of Swan Lake. This staging has always been mildly controversial for it comes burdened with a design concept that laces gothic with mescaline. Yet even so, the production seems a good choice to launch Dowell's final season with the company for it sends out such confident signals as to how things have changed during his tenure.

The dancing has indisputably got better. In 1987, when Swan Lake opened, The Royal barely had two ballerinas who could dance the great Odette/Odile role. This autumn it is fielding seven. In 1987 the rank and file of the company were ragged; 13 years later the company perform as if they had a claim to world-class status.

Not that Friday's performance was a landmark event - the first show of a new season is often blunted by nerves. But it was assured and in parts impressive. The four cygnets zipped through their frenetic showstopper with aplomb: Zenaida Yanowsky stuck a note of eerie grandeur as one of the Big Swans and Elizabeth McGorian's Queen hinted at some really interesting damage in her relations with Prince Siegfried. The contemptuous glance she threw at her son's sybaritic friends and the steely calculation with which she assessed Siegfried's potential fiancees were blood-curdling. And best of all was Belinda Hatley in the pas de trois, combining gaiety and elegance in a performance that was pure style.

The major focus was Darcey Bussell, who as Odette/Odile gave one of the oddest but most interesting performances of her career. Technically, her credentials to dance this dual role are a given, yet she seems intent on sacrificing its traditional lyric beauties and scintillating displays for something more willed. Her Odette, during much of act two, is a wild creature, as wary and feral as Fokine's Firebird. In the edgy use of her head, eyes and hands and in the staccato emphases of her phrasing Bussell sometimes bucks the music strangely. Yet all the time she shows Odette resisting Siegfried's love, resisting the pain of feeling human. The moment at which Odette pushes down her uplifted "wings", forcing them to become human arms, has rarely been so potent.

As Odile, Bussell doesn't instantly turn on the sexual glitter, but starts out as a cynical blank barely bothering to respond to Siegfried. Only as she absorbs the advice of the magician Von Rothbart does she gradually start to seduce the prince. Roberto Bolle's Siegfried is in a blander mould than Bussell but he is a tender and focused partner. Bolle is, however, only a guest with the company, and one of the issues Dowell has never managed to resolve is finding Bussell a permanent partner.

In repertory until December 2. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

The four cygnets zipped through their frenetic showstopper with aplomb: Zenaida Yanowsky stuck a note of eerie grandeur as one of the Big Swans and Elizabeth McGorian's Queen hinted at some really interesting damage in her relations with Prince Siegfried. The contemptuous glance she threw at her son's sybaritic friends and the steely calculation with which she assessed Siegfried's potential fiancees were blood-curdling. And best of all was Belinda Hatley in the pas de trois, combining gaiety and elegance in a performance that was pure style. The major focus was Darcey Bussell, who as Odette/Odile gave one of the oddest but most interesting performances of her career. Technically, her credentials to dance this dual role are a given, yet she seems intent on sacrificing its traditional lyric beauties and scintillating displays for something more willed. Her Odette, during much of act two, is a wild creature, as wary and feral as Fokine's Firebird. In the edgy use of her head, eyes and hands and in the staccato emphases of her phrasing Bussell sometimes bucks the music strangely. Yet all the time she shows Odette resisting Siegfried's love, resisting the pain of feeling human. The moment at which Odette pushes down her uplifted "wings", forcing them to become human arms, has rarely been so potent. As Odile, Bussell doesn't instantly turn on the sexual glitter, but starts out as a cynical blank barely bothering to respond to Siegfried. Only as she absorbs the advice of the magician Von Rothbart does she gradually start to seduce the prince. Roberto Bolle's Siegfried is in a blander mould than Bussell but he is a tender and focused partner. Bolle is, however, only a guest with the company, and one of the issues Dowell has never managed to resolve is finding Bussell a permanent partner. In repertory until December 2. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Alice
fields.standfirst:
Harrogate Theatre
****
fields.trailText:
Harrogate Theatre
****
fields.body:
This has nothing to do with Wonderland - Alice is the name of Harrogate Theatre's ghost, and the last time this intrepid little theatre commissioned a play the old girl was probably still in the audience.

But it is Harrogate Theatre's 100th birthday, and to mark the occasion writer Rony Robinson has been invited to contribute a drama celebrating the theatre's history. Robinson's new play is primarily made up of bits of old ones, but sampled and superimposed into a punchy, contemporary piece that feels something like an Essential Repertory Remix.

Everyone knows that all theatres are haunted, if only because wardrobe mistresses will always need someone to blame when the scissors go missing. No one is certain of Alice's identity, however. She may have been an actress, an usher or the theatre-founder's fancy friend. Whatever the case, she is reputed to have taken the most direct route from the top balcony to the stalls and most frequently manifests herself as a smell in the corridor.

Robinson's script is a neat set of variations on the theme of deja-vu, which opens spectacularly with an ending. This paradoxical piece of dramaturgy cleverly engineers a situation whereby, as the crew dismantle a show's scenery, Kate the stage manager volunteers to spend the night alone in the building.

Right on cue the theatre's spirits come drifting out of the woodwork, and, as snatches of hoary old staples such as Arnold Ridley's the Ghost Train, Coward's Still Life and Emlyn Williams's Someone Waiting swirl around her, Kate (earthily played by Nicola Bolton) finds herself experiencing the classic theatrical anxiety dream in which you are on stage, but don't know any of your lines.

It is a complex piece of writing that performs so many double twists that the plot does not always recover its balance. But the stagecraft of Rob Swain's production is so seamless and the ensemble playing so virtuosic that one is more than prepared to submit to its spell. Shelly Willetts in the title role cuts an imperious figure. An enchanting evening.

Until November 11. Box office: 01423 502116.

fields.headline: I Am Dandy
fields.standfirst:
BAC, London
**
fields.trailText:
BAC, London
**
fields.body:
The British Festival of Visual Theatre ends with David Gale's theatre piece. It begins with eight people - four men and four women - sitting in a row dressed as if for a cocktail party. Suddenly one of them leans forward and we are plunged into the world beneath the rules of polite behaviour and social engagement. The woman who fails to introduce herself in the correct manner is given short shrift. Another, whose small talk turns serious, her state of mind increasingly in doubt, suddenly finds that her audience evaporates. Madness, after all, might be catching. There are snarls lurking under all these smiles.

Initially David Gale's performance piece seems like a Pinter play without real characters, where the real drama is in the silences between the words. As it continues it becomes clear that it is much more to do with the behaviour of the group as it is with individuals. One woman's story about meeting a small child alone in the park develops speedily into a shocking playlet in which adults' real feelings towards children are exposed. "Up a kiddie's arse. It makes my blood boil," screams a man with appalling choleric ecstasy.

Soon we are deeper and deeper into the group mentality as trance and possession take hold and everyone is wandering around in the desert during the Gulf War possessed by the spirit of Elton John. This is funny, though never quite as hysterical as perhaps it should be, and it comes too late to save the evening from its own too serious fixation with psychobabble.

This is a clever 70 minutes but never an engaging one. The programme, which includes essays by Gale and others on hypnosis, dancing with the fairies and alien abduction is much more interesting than anything that takes place on stage. There is a huge gap between the inspiration for the show and its realisation.

What keeps your interest, is not the evening's intellectual or theatrical thrust, but the remarkable performances from the actors. Their obscenities, gurning features and physical ravages make Linda Blair in The Exorcist look like an amateur.

Until November 4. Box office: 020-7223 2223.

fields.headline: The lying game
fields.standfirst:
Beware CVs that are economical with the truth, warns Ian Boughton

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Beware CVs that are economical with the truth, warns Ian Boughton.
fields.body:
How many lies did you tell in your job-hunting today? Did you excise the kids from your CV, add or remove a husband, shave 10 years from your age, or put five on for that company who wanted someone "mature and experienced"?

Manchester United has just appointed a new director of communications, Paddy Haverson, whose background in PR and sports journalism the club must surely hope will mask the embarrassment surrounding the departure of his predecessor. Alison Ryan was fired from the post before she had stepped into the office after it was revealed that she had kept off her CV the fact that she had been banned from practising law - a punishment imposed after she had falsely claimed to have a first class degree from Cambridge. More worryingly, a lecturer who last week was cleared of raping a student at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside will be sentenced next month for obtaining his job by deception. Russell Griffiths had not disclosed his previous convictions for harassing women.

All employers could tell Manchester United that CVs contain lies, and that the real skill is to spot the ones that matter. Even massive fibs, it seems, don't necessarily mean the worst. Martin Abramson, chairman of import-exporters Brennan Atkinson, confesses to having been in a rush the day he took on a dyslexic PA and an office manager who assured him that complex export paperwork would be "no problem" - even though she had never done it before.

"My business went through absolute hell for three months. It was six weeks before I discovered the secretary was dyslexic - then I found she was such a good trader that she became MD of one of my companies. The export clerk pleaded with me to be patient, and now she's my operations director.

"Neither of them actually told a bare-faced lie, but CVs can be misleading, and if someone's sent along for a secretarial job, you don't usually ask if she's dyslexic. I should have spoken to the previous employers, but the agency is supposed to have done that. It shows you can't judge what's on paper."

Commercially-prepared CVs have been derided as "put-together papers by people who don't know who they're writing about, and don't know who they're writing to", but, the professional CV writers protest, they are now so used to being asked to exaggerate that they grill their clients automatically. And, says Michelle Atkinson of Impact CV, checking-up is getting very sophisticated. She cites a finance-checking company which has turned, profitably, into a qualification-checking service.

Although she has spotted all the classic lies, such as those who "went to Oxford", but not to the university, Atkinson is sympathetic. "The most common lie is date-changing and age-changing. I know one client who has lived for twenty years in fear of his CV being exposed."

But lies may lead to more than dismissal, warns CV-writer Chris Christensen of A Write Impression. "Very few people can pull it off - and if they are found out after being paid a sign-on bonus, they might be forced to return it. It might be considered fraud."

Elizabeth Henry of Leeds law firm Last Cawthra Feather says a lying applicant could end up in court. "The employer might be entitled to sue for salary paid, the cost of training and any other monies expended - for example, recruitment fees."

The longer a career goes on, however, the more an employer is interested in experience over grades, and Henry agrees that time offers a defence. "To justify instant dismissal, the lie must amount to gross misconduct. If it is a matter of higher grades having been quoted in respect of qualifications obtained years before, then it may not be reasonable to dismiss summarily. The employer would have to allow the employee an opportunity to explain - and for not doing so, the employer could possibly be taken to an employment tribunal."

Errors do happen, as in the CV which boasted "I was instrumental in ruining an entire operation". The best course in composing a resume is simply careful phrasing.

Kauser Kanji, co-founder of i-resign.com, points out that prisoners' associations recommend that time inside be described as "not in work", which is technically correct. And subjective statements such as "I'm a team player", or "I'm a hard worker" are opinions, and legally unchallengable.

But candidates can be too honest, warns Paul King of Achiever Career Development. "I cringe at the number of CVs which invite discrimination. The most common mistakes are in 'marital status' and 'religion' - a client of some standing in a particular religious denomination said so at length in his CV. We revised it to 'active in the community', which took no risks. It is just as important to leave out material which may be used as an excuse to reject you."

webTitle: Observer review: Shadows of a Princess by PD Jephson

fields.headline: A marital aide
fields.standfirst: As if Diana hadn't suffered enough, along comes her man PD Jephson with his memoir Shadows of a Princess
fields.trailText: As if Diana hadn't suffered enough, along comes her man PD Jephson with his memoir Shadows of a Princess
fields.body:
Shadows of a Princess: Diana, Princess of Wales 1987-1996
PD Jephson
HarperCollins £17.99, pp400
Buy it at BOL

You already know the story of the princess and the pea. This book is the story of the princess and the penile substitute. Or rather - for fear I might have made you want to read it - one paragraph tells that short, sadly pointless story. The rest is about the princess and a pea-brained employee who fawned on her, forgave her trespasses, cried for her and now seeks to profit from defaming her.

Back, however, to the dildo. Diana, Jephson breathlessly confides, returned from Paris in 1992 sporting a souvenir - 'a large, pink, battery-powered vibrator'. By now she knew she'd never get her hands on an orb or sceptre: this plastic knob would have to do. It had 'the aim', Jephson notes with courtly tact, 'of raising royal morale at critical moments'. But he denies that it was actually aimed at the critical royal part, and insists it was 'never used for its designed purpose'. Eventually Dodi assumed the role of royal morale-booster, which made the cheeky pink chap redundant.

Meanwhile, it's curious that Diana should have felt she needed this bulbous, buzzing personal attendant. After all, she already had Jephson, who was her private secretary during the decade covered by his book, and he saw himself as a dildo in a pin-stripe suit. When he took the job, a courtier seasoned in sycophancy warned him: 'To these people you're just a toy. They'll wind you up and watch you whizz all over the place, then they'll throw you away and get another one.'

Jephson prided himself for a while on being Diana's 'current favourite toy', and even aspired to function as a marital aid - rather than a bureaucratic aide - for the estranged Waleses. A few days after Diana acquired the dildo, Jephson smarmed into Charles's office to remind him: 'I joined this household to serve both Your Royal Highnesses.' But Charles had mentally metamorphosed himself into a snuggly sanitary pad, and Jephson's ministrations could hardly be counted on, since his batteries were starting to go flat.

He resigned in 1996, petulant about Diana's secret Panorama interview. That, at least, is how he tells it. In fact, Diana executed him electronically by sending him a malevolent anonymous message on his pager. Jephson could no longer claim to be her best-beloved toy, her faithful and indefatigable stand-by; she had reduced him to the size of the transistorised gadget which stirred to life in his trouser pocket. Life, alas, would never be quite so vibrant again.

Jephson piously professes to regard Diana as 'a global force for good', though his account of her kills the poor woman all over again. The charities she adopted, he makes clear, were excuses for foreign junkets; she used public money to subsidise her career as an 'independent celebrity'. Her temper was vile, her humour crude, and her laugh asinine. Jephson, impeccably proper, winces when her braying reaches 'the delicate ears of outsiders such as Queen's Flight crews'.

Despite her global frolics, Diana hadn't the foggiest about the destinations to which her private planes - jet-propelled vibrators, if you come to think of it - were headed. At the White House just before the Gulf War, George Bush père asked her about the invasion of Kuwait. The opinion she vouchsafed was a meditative 'Um'. Jephson rejoices in her embarrassment, but reserves his haughtiest outrage for a more clandestine vice, her addiction to chocolate. 'I frequently watched her eat a whole bar of fruit-and-nut between engagements,' he reveals, and pauses to listen to us gasp.

He is slavishly discreet, by contrast, about the elder Windsors, who are alive and liable to sue. Reneging on his contract to supply title-tattle, he opaquely paraphrases their dialogue. Charles, infuriated by Diana's refusal to spend a weekend at Sandringham, expressed his annoyance - Jephson informs us - 'in blunt and peremptory tones'. We are left to imagine the four-letter words the heir actually used. The evasion is characteristic of this cowardly book, too hyprocritically high-minded to get down to its job of scandal-mongering.

Though he disdains his mistress, Jephson has a lofty opinion of himself. Describing how he supported Diana against her detractors at St James's Palace, he positively glows as the memory of his chivalry: 'If all this sounds rather overprincipled, then it probably was.' He admires the Queen's stoical immunity to emotion, and boasts of sharing it: between them, they uphold 'so many of the great British strengths which had withstood all the tests that Empire and war could bring'. He is also deeply, nauseatingly religious. When Diana jabs him with that message on his pager, he 'told nobody of my agonised thoughts except God. He had heard most of it before'. Now, thanks to Jephson's book, God generously shares this privileged information with everyone who reads a tabloid.

Unplugged by the princess, Jephson apparently 'decided to take up writing'. He had served his apprenticeship ghosting thank-you notes for Diana, so he is proficient at ornately arranging clichés. She and Charles, exchanging insults, remind him of pots and kettles. She wants to have her cake and eat it, while sipping from a poisoned chalice. Jephson adds a pinch of salt when she gossips about her adulterous in-laws. For a while, she rides the crest of a wave, though a straw finally breaks the camel's back.

Sometimes, Jephson makes his catchphrases copulate. Thus the last meeting between the separate staffs of the Waleses is 'the merest fig leaf, the fag end of a process'. Just try to picture that: a fag posing as a fig. The vibrator rears its pert head on page 267. Otherwise, there is no reason at all to read this empty, imperceptive and crassly opportunistic book.

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: This is a horror story that will very pleasurably curdle the blood of nine to 13-year-olds
fields.body:
Cirque du Freak
Darren Shan
Collins £3.99, pp192
Buy it at BOL

This is a horror story that will very pleasurably curdle the blood of nine to 13-year-olds. The narrator of the story mysteriously has the same name as the author, but says: 'Everything's true in this book except for the names... I'm not even going to tell you the name of my town or country. I daren't.'

Darren and his best friend, Steve, find a flier for the Cirque du Freak and sneak out to the spooky, abandoned, old cinema where the bizarre show is being held. Of course, they get a lot more than they bargained for. Steve recognises one of the performers, Mr Crepsley and his amazing performing tarantula, from an old book about vampires. Steve wants to be a vampire, but Mr Crepsley turns him down.

Darren, meanwhile, steals the poisonous spider which later bites Steve, who nearly dies. Mr Crepsley will only hand over the antidote if Darren agrees to become his assistant - and to become half-vampire. Darren must be 'killed', leave his family, his home and his friends. The newly cured Steve, bitter at Darren taking his place, swears that he won't rest until he has killed him.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The Proustian length of Stephen Fry's fourth novel is more than a tad off-putting
fields.body:
The Stars' Tennis Balls
Stephen Fry
Read by the author
Listening time 10 hours
Random House, £20

'Brevity,' said Shakespeare, 'is the soul of wit.' Try telling that to the witty Stephen Fry, because the Proustian length of his fourth novel is more than a tad off-putting. That wouldn't be a problem if the content and humour matched the extraordinary lengths this talented man has gone to in creating a farcical and incomprehensible plot.

Less surprising is the subject matter - privileged, good-looking boys from a 'well-known public school'.

Our hero, Ned Maddstone, is a handsome 17-year-old with floppy blond hair and a charmed life that takes an unexpected nose-dive when he is kidnapped and incarcerated to the point where he almost goes mad. His subsequent revenge on those responsible becomes a tangle of structureless plot lines that alternately leap and dally in pace.

As a novel, this wouldn't be worth approaching. As an audiobook, it is digestible to a listener prepared to be uninvolved and enjoy only Fry's considerable verbal talents and the enthusiasm that he maintains to the last unnecessary metaphor.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Jonathan Rendall traces the path of a melancholic doppelgänger across America, plus When I Lived in Modern Times, Motherless Brooklyn, Rough Music and Writing at the Kitchen Table
fields.body:
Twelve Grand
Jonathan Rendall
Yellow Jersey Press £7, pp250
Buy it at BOL

Given £12,000 over three months to gamble with by Yellow Jersey Press, with the commission to write a book about it, Jonathan Rendall instead delivered a fictionalised account to fit the brief. A melancholic, self-destructive writer-journalist who drinks to a creative biting point, Rendall's doppelgänger anti-hero desperately chases an emotional stake, his spectral, fallen girlfriend, as she lap-dances (to Led Zeppelin) across America.

It's familiar territory for Rendall, but the biggest gamble is with the unsettling style. Behind the excess lies a writerly uncertainty; the exploration of an orphaned childhood that becomes a dissolute adulthood exceeds the conceit. Definitely worth a flutter.

When I Lived in Modern Times
Linda Grant
Granta £6.99, pp260
Buy it at BOL

Linda Grant's fictional memoir of displacement and forged identity was the controversial winner of the Orange Prize, producing a gnashing of White Teeth as well as charges of plagiarism.

The narrative accompanies 20-year-old Jewish orphan Evelyn Sert in 1946 as she makes her way to Palestine from Soho. After an unhappy spell on a kibbutz, she reincarnates in Tel Aviv as Priscilla Jones from Lewisham, styling the hair of complacently racist British Empire wives. Her boyfriend, 'Johnny', is a Zionist terrorist-tailor with a pencil moustache and an ingrowing toenail, but when things start to overheat, her only hope is to go underground, into the dark-cornered ghettos of the gleaming, Bauhaus-influenced city.

While national and personal identities are at stake, Evelyn becomes buried beneath her disguises, leaving Palestine as the principal character in a story over-ripe with purposeful ideas. Behind the period drama, though, is a decent, intelligent love-story, intimately expressed.

Motherless Brooklyn
Jonathan Lethem
Faber and Faber £5.99, pp311
Buy it at BOL

When small-time goodfella Frank Minna is killed, 'Minna Man' Lionel Essrog sets out to find his killer and becomes embroiled in a sinister world of urchin eggs, father figures and Zen gangsters. Routine noir-ish stuff, were it not for Lionel, who has Tourette syndrome. Labelled the 'free human freak show', he cannot help but tap, count and bark gobbledegook, mangling language into exhilarating, Joycean association. Alfred Hitchcock? Altered Houseclock. Or Ilford Hotchkiss. What initially appears a stylistic gimmick ultimately distinguishes a witty, ambitious book that blends self-conscious meta-fiction with aural lyricism and inquires into the complexity of the brain's 'wheels within wheels'.

Rough Music
Patrick Gale
Flamingo £9.99, pp374
Buy it at BOL

The jacket blurb includes a description of Gale's fiction as 'hip', but it's a bizarre adjective for what proves an endearingly old-fashioned, generational saga. Interlacing two narratives separated by 30 years, Gale traces the history of the Pagett family at Beachcomber, a Cornish holiday cottage, until the stories marry up and relationships fissure. Will has problems: he is 40, sleeping with his sister's husband, and his mother, Frances, has early-onset Alzheimer's. In addition, he finds himself attracted to the dreadlocked widower living in the caravan behind the cottage. Gale unravels the details through dialogue as convincing as it is plentiful, while examining containment, fidelity and identity within a child's universe and the years beyond. And his own identity is relevant, for if he were to adopt a female name, his wrought, quietly bubbling fiction might reach the wider audience it deserves.

Writing at the Kitchen Table
Elizabeth David
Edited by Artemis Cooper
Penguin £7.99, pp351
Buy it at BOL

After travelling extensively, and marrying unhappily, Elizabeth David returned to a post-war, rationed England that neither gave a fig about cookery, nor knew how to prepare one. A Book of Mediterranean Food, written 'to work out an agonised craving for the sun', was published in 1950 and immediately established her reputation.

The antithesis of Delia, her recipes scorched rather than branded, eschewing instruction for inspiration. But it was her passionate prose that thrilled. Cooper's authorised biography elegantly separates the fruit from the pith, but it rather lacks David's scrupulous curiosity. A feisty, heavy-drinking woman with 'prunes-in-brandy' eyes, David indelibly transformed the jaded palate and imagination of Middle England to celebrate exoticism in the kitchen. Remember to toast her when you next put wine rather than cabbage water in your gravy.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: The New New Thing

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Michael Lewis tells the story of the geeks with no past
fields.body:
The New New Thing
Michael Lewis
Coronet £7.99, pp424
Buy it at BOL

Who are the Prime Movers of Wealth today? Michael Lewis thinks he has the answer. In The New New Thing, the acclaimed author of Liar's Poker 'hitches a ride on the back of a life', investigating the motivations of Silicon Valley billionaire, the amazing Jim Clark, one of the nuttier Californians to have found a raison d'être in the wacky world of the new technology. Clark is a man who cannot sit still for five minutes without finding his pants on fire.

According to Lewis, the new prime mover is no longer the great industrialist or the heroic entrepreneur, he's the 'geek in the basement', the guy in trainers who spends his weekends figuring out wonderful new things to do with his computer.

As readers of this highly entertaining 'Silicon Valley story' will discover, this new American character is one Michael Lewis was born to write about, a future American for whom there is no past, very little present, and only the uncharted tomorrow to respond to, a figure from fiction.

As well as being a beady-eyed evisceration of the Wild West of American capitalism, Lewis's high-octane reportage is also as compelling as the very best kind of fiction, a rags-to-riches tale of a small-town boy elbowing his way into the premier league of the super-rich.

The New New Thing is the amazing story of American hi-tech capitalism during the decade in which the internet became 'the single most important event in the United States economy since the industrial revolution', a fascinating and adventurous ride through the unreal world of netheads and billionaires.

webTitle: Observer review: The Catholics of Ulster and Wherever Green is Worn

fields.headline: Different shades of green
fields.standfirst: Americans may not grasp it, but not all Irish Catholics are the same. Anne McHardy on The Catholics of Ulster and Wherever Green is Worn
fields.trailText: Americans may not grasp it, but not all Irish Catholics are the same. Anne McHardy on The Catholics of Ulster and Wherever Green is Worn
fields.body:
The Catholics of Ulster
Marianne Elliott
Penguin £25, pp688
Buy it at BOL

Wherever Green is Worn
Tim Pat Coogan
Hutchinson £25, pp757
Buy it at BOL

Buried in the careful research that Marianne Elliott has put into The Catholics of Ulster, there are nuggets of emotion. Writing the book has involved painful recognition of the prejudices she grew up with in Belfast and had not yet shed in 25 years in England. She is professor of modern history and director of the Institute of Irish Studies at Liverpool University.

As far as this forceful book is concerned, recognition of the distinctiveness of Ulster Catholics, and even the difference between Catholics living in the east and west within Northern Ireland, is crucial to political progress. 'I have always felt different from Catholics elsewhere in Ireland and this is a common feeling among Ulster Catholics. Yet I have found them consistently neglected in the histories of Ireland and of Irish Catholicism in particular, as if Irishness and Catholicism so dominated their sense of themselves that they could be safely included with all other Irish Catholics... if that had been so, we would not have been left with that overwhelming sense of insecurity which is such a feature of the Ulster personality.'

The scarring of the psyche has influenced Ulster's Catholics - Professor Elliott reclaims the old Irish kingdom name, 'Ulster', recognising the political sensitivity since Unionists use it for six-county Northern Ireland - and deepened their innate conservatism in their response to the Irish state, to their church and to segregated education.

Her history shows the distinctiveness pre-dating partition in 1921 and rooted in early migrations and alliances. She recognises the horrors of the potato famines, but points to complexities beyond the demonology. By implication, even if only as cousins, northern Catholics are different from most Catholics who regard their Irish extraction as crucial to their make-up, particularly those in the United States.

This is the nub of the difference between Elliott and the author of a second book on Catholics from Ireland, the journalist-turned-historian, Tim Pat Coogan, whose Wherever Green is Worn is a rollicking trawl looking at the fate of migrants, including those during the potato famines. Important among their descendants are the influential Irish-Americans affecting US involvement in the peace process. What Coogan very definitely does not do is identify Northern Ireland Catholics as different.

Coogan, who has written two serious biographies, of Michael Collins and of Eamon De Valera, as well as a history of the IRA, trawls from the US via Britain to Japan looking at the Orange and Green tensions. His stock-in-trade is the hard-done-by, hard-drinking Irish Catholic and the patronising British colonial. Stereotypes last, he says, if they are founded in truth.

The two authors are both deeply critical of the Catholic Church, Elliott for its political dealings in Northern Ireland, Coogan for its failure to care for the migrants. Coogan is outspoken in his criticism of the Dublin and London governments, although inevitably the British get more stick.

Both authors recognise that the fact the Catholics are growing as a proportion of the population of Northern Ireland is vital, but here they divide. Elliott, whose family still lives in north Belfast, recalls rioting by loyalists that followed a mistaken report in 1991 that Catholics would shortly outnumber Protestants. Every word of her book is tempered to warn against triumphalism.

Coogan, who refers to his own emotional background as a little boy watching the pathetic parade of migrants through Dun Laoghaoire, also worries about the effect of Catholic expansion in numbers and wealth on the Protestant psyche, but he cannot resist an epilogue saying: 'One day the sheer energy of the Celts... will subsume the present Unionist majority.'

Coogan's book, woven throughout though it is with fascinating nuggets, falls on that sentence. Sadly, with its sexy cover showing migrants crowding under the White Star sign and its clear spin for a US readership, it is the one that will influence before Elliott's equally readable work. Her elegant grey cover says 'serious reader'. The less serious should not be put off.

webTitle: Observer review: The Wrong Boy by Willy Russell

fields.headline: Tales of ordinary sadness
fields.standfirst: Willy Russell goes back to his roots to create a character to stand alongside Rita and Shirley Valentine in The Wrong Boy
fields.trailText: Willy Russell goes back to his roots to create a character to stand alongside Rita and Shirley Valentine in The Wrong Boy
fields.body:
The Wrong Boy
Willy Russell
Doubleday £16.99

In his first novel, Willy Russell has created a character to stand alongside his celebrated progeny, Shirley Valentine and Rita, and has eased the transition from stage writing to prose fiction by presenting his story through a series of letters which could cheerfully work as dramatic monologues.

His narrator, 19-year-old Raymond Marks from Failsworth, Manchester, is the kind of misfit Russell loves: a northern, working-class dreamer with creative yearnings that make him impatient with surrounding banalities and vulnerable to a frightening sense of not belonging, but who (more or less) triumphs over adversity to develop his artistic gift and find himself. It may sniff a bit of Billy Elliott, but Russell has been telling these stories for years.

Raymond is in transit at the time of writing, en route from Manchester to Grimsby where his Bastard Uncle Jason has fixed up a job on a building site. From the opening line, it is apparent that a building site is entirely the wrong place for solipsistic, depressive, would-be poetic Raymond - his letters, all painstakingly addressed from various service stations or lay-bys, are written to Morrissey, the only one who has ever understood him.

As Raymond's journey becomes increasingly complicated, thanks to his fatal attraction to Fawltyesque misadventure, so his letters delve back into his past to explain to Morrissey how the domino effect of a few childhood misunderstandings has blighted his teenage years, culminating in an accusation of paedophilia and his incarceration in a psychiatric institution under heavy medication.

Because the novel exists entirely in Raymond's distinctive voice, the question of whether he was really going mad or was just pushed beyond his limits by a stolid, prosaic community eager to squeeze him into their narrow definition of normality is never answered. Madness, Russell implies, is a nebulous term used by visionless people of anyone whose imagination and gifts set them apart; madness and art are unfixed definitions.

The moral is simple and even a little trite; Raymond's unhappiness, his sense of himself as the wrong boy of the title, stems from his failure to recognise his true self. A tragic parallel is provided in the shape of Raymond's absent father, a man with 'melodies in his head' who wanted desperately to be a musician but failed at every instrument he tried. By the time he discovers that his gift is his voice, it's almost too late.

As with Russell's stage plays, The Wrong Boy swerves perilously close to sentimentality, but he has produced a deliberately heartwarming tale, and though the happy ending features too many neat coincidences and can't help but feel contrived, you wouldn't want it otherwise. The observational humour on the minutiae of northern life feels familiar, but there are some wonderful vignettes, such as the country and western band, the Dewsbury Desperadoes, and the progressive headmaster who stages a transvestite nativity play.

Russell should have resisted the urge to throw a few of Raymond's own song lyrics into the mix, but his real achievement is to present the exaggerated horrors of childhood and adolescence with an unusual wit and sympathy.

webTitle: Observer review: The Best a Man Can Get by John O'Farrell

fields.headline: Father in haven
fields.standfirst: John O'Farrell paints a bedroom pink and produces a second novel about fatherhood in The Best a Man Can Get
fields.trailText: John O'Farrell paints a bedroom pink and produces a second novel about fatherhood in The Best a Man Can Get
fields.body:
The Best a Man Can Get
John O'Farrell
Doubleday £10, pp271

John O'Farrell has written satire for Spitting Image, jokes to liven up Gordon Brown's speeches and an account of 18 miserable years in the life of a Labour supporter, Things Can Only Get Better. Since his first novel, he has become a father of two and cometh the hour, cometh the second novel about being a dad.

Michael shares a student-like flat in south London with Paul, Simon and Jim. His bedroom has been arranged so that he never has to get up other than to shuffle the few feet to his computer where he composes jingles for the 'Mr Gearbox' ad on Capital Radio. But he is not a student. He is married to Catherine and they have two children.

Michael spends his days at the flat telling Catherine he is 'working against a deadline in a Manchester recording studio'. When he gets bored, he takes the Tube north and goes 'home'. For years, Mike gets away with his double life but shortly before the birth of their third child, Catherine rumbles him, arranges the children's fridge magnets to read 'wanker' and walks out.

Suddenly, Michael has to face up to his responsibilities. He is not a bad man, nor a bad father - it's just that he is having an affair with a younger, carefree version of himself. Will 'lad dad' do the right thing?

O'Farrell says that the 'starting point for the novel was wanting to write about how power changes in a relationship when the children come along'. The book describes how men have lost an empire as head of the family and suggests new masculine roles.

But O'Farrell's strength lies not in telling us how we should live but in satirising the way we already do. His bedroom has been arranged so that he never has to get up other than to shuffle the few feet to his computer where he composes jingles for the 'Mr Gearbox' ad on Capital Radio. webTitle: Observer review: The Last Samurai, In the Fall and Diamond Dogs

fields.headline: Pa for the course
fields.standfirst: Fathers and forebears - you never know what you might find once you start looking. Anna Schapiro on debuts from Helen DeWitt, Jeffrey Lent and Alan Watt
fields.trailText: Fathers and forebears - you never know what you might find once you start looking. Anna Schapiro on debuts from Helen DeWitt, Jeffrey Lent and Alan Watt
fields.body:
The Last Samurai
Helen DeWitt
Chatto & Windus £16.99, pp530
Buy it at BOL

In the Fall
Jeffrey Lent
Picador £14.99, pp542
Buy it at BOL

Diamond Dogs
Alan Watt
Duck £9.99, pp198
Buy it at BOL

It is amazing that people trust novelists to tell their stories. Novelists are weirdos with sensitivities wide-ranging but so acute that they can hardly bear the company of others. They are omnivores of vicarious experience but often queasy around its manifestations. Most strangely, they write versions of themselves that make people feel they are reading about their own selves.

The two main characters in this month's shining fictional debut, The Last Samurai, bear the marks of the fiction writers' idiosyncratic tribe. They find almost everything 'extraordinarily interesting' and almost all other people so undiscerning as hardly to be borne. Instead of feeling they won't like you, you feel you are one of the élite these two would single out as companions - even if it is unlikely that you would go in for seven-hour concerts of fractured classical music much less regard, as they do, Kurosawa's movie The Seven Samurai as the model for living.

These two novelists are a young American woman, Sybilla, living in London and Ludo, the boy she inadvertently conceived. As the book opens, she is turning this demanding four-year-old into a child prodigy. He just won't stop asking questions when she shows him the standard alphabet, then the Greek alphabet, then others, until soon he has progressed from furious questioning like 'Why don't you teach me ONE syllabary?' to regarding Gesenius's Hebrew Grammar as light reading.

The one question she won't answer is 'Who is my father?' In the funny, memorable passage where the reader half finds out, she code-names the inseminator Liberace for his qualities of virtuosity wed to empty-headed, false good-heartedness. Like Liberace, he is famous, in his case for flashy writing that Sybilla regards as embarrassing. She conceives Ludo to shut Liberace up. 'It would be rude to put a hand over his mouth, but if I were to put my mouth on his mouth this would stop him talking.'

Sybilla begins showings of The Seven Samurai to provide Ludo with a male role model. She succeeds only too well. After narrating the opening chapters of the book, much-interrupted by toddler Ludo, Sybilla's voice gives way to his in what becomes a series of tall tales as he pursues one stellar man after another in the hope of finding a father. His actual father he finds in short order and is so repelled that he goes after other famous men. By the the age of 11, he has found and lost one of the best candidates, and Sybilla has all but dropped from the story. There are seven such candidates. But almost every one muffs it with Ludo by committing solecisms of taste, judgement or personal ethics.

The people who want to promote this book violate taste by describing it as a story of a single mother, a term Sybilla would icily find vom-inducing. Even more so would be a phrase like 'a boy's quest for a father', putting off the people who would eat up this novel's crisply entertaining wit. It is about a belief that a sense of correctness is among the highest senses.

No such sense informs the other big (as in 500-plus pages) book being promoted as a Big Fall Book, In the Fall by Jeffrey Lent. Essentially about the glories and trials of miscegenation in post-Civil War America, most of its overwrought, if sometimes trashily pleasurable, paragraphs should have been squeezed down to the sentence or, perhaps, word of meaning they contain.

No one can accuse the author of belonging to the rarefied breed of literary novelists, nor do his characters suggest resemblance to them or living beings of any kind. Whether slave or farmer, they are grander than those around them, and all speak with a ludicrous combination of grandiloquence and anachronistic grossness.

Actually, they don't speak, they declaim, from 1865 to sometime in the 1920s, when the grandson of the runaway ex-slave beauty who married the smitten Vermont farmer journeys south to discover that the man who owned his grandmother was, well, not nice. This is the kind of writer who has learned only the most superficial things from nineteenth-century forebears such as Dickens, such as 'Do not introduce a character unless he will reappear 300 pages later'. The three couples who meet over three generations are always instant, grand, perfect matches, and tend to start poor, do well, and display along the way the highest virtues.

It was a relief, then, to read Diamond Dogs, described as a thriller (if, alas, a 'postmodern' one, a bill it happily fails to fill). Nevada high school football hero kills nerdy classmate, only to have his abusive sheriff father conspire to cover it up. At its best, this has you squirming at feeling sympathetic to the kind of guys you wouldn't give the time of day to.

webTitle: Observer review: The Hill Bachelors by William Trevor

fields.headline: The hills are alive...
fields.standfirst: Personal connections and dislocations fuel the stories in William Trevor's word-perfect collection The Hill Bachelors
fields.trailText: Personal connections and dislocations fuel the stories in William Trevor's word-perfect collection The Hill Bachelors
fields.body:
The Hill Bachelors
William Trevor
Viking £15.99, pp256
Buy it at BOL

These are stories that bear the imprint of habit. They tell of lives casually undone by predictable circumstance and they do so with a grace and a rhythm so long taken to heart that it seems second nature.

The title story is typical. On the death of his father, a hill farmer, the youngest of three sons, returns to the bleak fields of his childhood. He comes back, the only unmarried son in the family, to be by his mother's side, and in the pressing knowledge that his life, which had promised something in the town, will now also be lived on this hillside.

As he reclaims his father's fields from the bog, yard by yard, his inheritance closes in on him in inexorable detail - 'He naturally would know that times were bad, neither sheep nor cattle fetching what they were a year ago, everything gone quiet, the way you'd never have believed it' - until he is himself reclaimed by his fate.

This story, in common with nearly all the stories in this word-perfect collection, takes two people and examines the connections and the dislocations between them, the ways in which ordinary lives are quietly shaped by chance and missed opportunity.

Trevor is a great dissector of intimacy and here he turns the same sharp, humane attention in one tale to Vera and Sidney, bound in an unconsummated 30-year love by a grim secret buried in their past, and in another to the odd congress between a young man and a woman who meet for the first and last time in a restaurant. The woman's husband has fallen down drunk and the young man assists her in carrying him back to her bedroom.

Trevor long ago staked his imagination's claim to dual nationality: his fiction commutes between the blustery lives of rural Ireland, the places of his childhood, and the stiffer formality of small-town England, his adoptive home.

But while Trevor's territory remains constant, his understanding of the unravelling of relationships in these places, by these places, is being constantly refined.

Where there is humour, as in 'Death of a Professor', which is a high-table tale of a man whose obituary appears prematurely in the papers, and who finds his life's work squashed between larger notices about a 'backing singer in a pop group and a bishop, born in Stockport', then it invariably bleaches into something more poignant.

The most remarkable of these stories, 'The Telephone Game', works as a metaphor for Trevor's quiet, affecting vision. On the night before their wedding, a young couple - she German, he English - embark on a game involving calling strangers, playing tricks. The man, for a laugh, sends an elderly woman he doesn't know up into her attic to check her water tank, having warned her of floods. She fails to return, and in the silence on the end of the line the couple suddenly hear all their fears about their impending life together crackling.

For all the cosy-seeming certainties on the surface of his prose, this kind of echoing emptiness is never far from the lives of the people William Trevor creates.

They sometimes seem contented, but mostly they are, like this couple, left to wonder about the lives of others, hoping against hope for the 'far-off rattle of a human voice, faint and small.'

webTitle: Observer review: The Beatles Anthology and Lennon Remembers

fields.headline: May the four be with you
fields.standfirst: Thirty years after the break-up, The Beatles are still in a class of their own. Stephen Bayley on The Beatles Anthology and Lennon Remembers
fields.trailText: Thirty years after the break-up, The Beatles are still in a class of their own. Stephen Bayley on The Beatles Anthology and Lennon Remembers
fields.body:
The Beatles Anthology
The Beatles
Cassells £35, pp367
Buy it at BOL

Lennon Remembers
Jann S Wenner
Verso £13, pp166
Buy it at BOL

In seven years of recording, The Beatles changed the shape and direction of popular cliché. Like Venice, it is impossible to say anything entirely new about them. Their presence, 30 years after their last record, remains enormous, even if their music is played less. But, like Shakespeare, they own sections of the language: just mutter 'Dear Sir or Madam will you read my book?' or 'It was 20 years ago today' or 'Yesterday' or 'Let me take you down' and ineradicable patterns of tune and recollection swirl into mind.

Outrageous comparisons are part of Beatles culture: John Lennon acidly, but not wrongly, claimed parity with Christ in terms of popular esteem while the Times' music critic said Beatles' songs were comparable to Schubert's. That was in 1967 when it was very bold to do so. But there's a big, almost blasphemous, question few dare ask. Do we overestimate their importance?

John, Paul, George and Ringo became council household names in a way that Brian Poole and the Tremeloes did not. Superior artistry is not sufficient explanation; there was something else. The Beatles satisfied appetites other than for music: their (rapid) leaving of Liverpool was an escape all baby boomers wanted to emulate and at the same time the public greedily devoured a credible domestic replacement for dominant American pop.

In addition, The Beatles had a graphic presence. When album covers were customarily cheesy portraits, With The Beatles had dramatic, grainy Tri-X in arty chiaroscuro. Their first movie was a minor classic of contemporary cinema by a real film-maker called Dick Lester, not a Carry On caper. They had pioneering wardrobes, either by Pierre Cardin or Afghan embroiderers. Later, artists including Klaus Voorman and Peter Blake made their own contributions.

Some still say that they were in the right place at the right time and without the management of Brian Epstein or the arrangements of George Martin they would be just another 'group', to use a period term. That's as sensible as saying that every university common room in 1955 had its own Jim Dixon and Kingsley Amis was lucky to find a publisher. Whatever our modern view of their talents, The Beatles are a phenomenon without precedent or successor. How else to explain international pre-publication sales of a million copies of a huge scrapbook which sells for £35?

The Anthology is more a memorial slab than a book, something to be handled, or admired from a distance, rather than read. Here in an anarchic collection of images, personal documents, facsimiles and transcripts is the archive substance behind the songs, the record of the records. Lennon, unavailable for interview since 1980, has his say via an eclectic range of quotations interpolated and dated by the editors.

There's a keen pleasure in the voyeurism of old BOAC itineraries and blush-making images of the lads being playful and coy in Florida surf, but the real fascination is in the definitions of the individual characters. The personalities were deeply satisfying. The B-team of Ringo and George was perfect back-up, but it is the Lennon-McCartney relationship that encourages and repays deep scrutiny.

Here is a debate with an indefinite life. The one a catchpenny tunesmith saved from a sugary descent into mawkishness by the electric presence of an acerbic, surrealist genius? Or a threatening, foul-mouthed hooligan rocker dignified by the moderating influence of a true poet of popular culture? The truth, of course, is halfway between middle and extreme. The years after The Beatles showed that without Lennon, McCartney vigorously pursued a tendency towards kitsch, while Lennon lapsed into gruelling self-indulgence and lost all idea of a good tune. Not exactly Apollo and Dionysus, but it was a nicely complimentary partnership.

Lennon said of McCartney: 'He provided a lightness, an optimism, while I would always go for the sadness, the discords, the bluesy notes.' But Lennon was a more complicated character than he tried to appear: his toughness was a cultivated pose. School was a Gothic villa in a park (not unlike the neighbouring Strawberry Fields) where masters wore mortar boards and spoke Greek. Naturally, he was expelled and sent to art school 'so I can fail there as well'. Instead, Lennon did his learning at home. He lived in suburban gentility and grew up with Thurber, Wilde, Whistler, Fitzgerald and Carroll. McCartney was astonished to find his friend had a typewriter, unusual for a teenager anywhere in the Fifties, but in Liverpool truly astonishing.

The density of data and image in the Anthology would make it fascinating if its subject was a band that played at the end of the pier, but given the epic status of The Beatles' adventure, it prompts that uncomfortable question about how we are to judge their achievement now. Between them, The Beatles made popular art that was good art, even occasionally great art. They had originality, irreverence and authentic style, yet there is something - close to ineffable melancholy - that now makes them difficult to listen to.

Perhaps this concerns a sense of loss. George Harrison said of the mania period that 'the days seemed like weeks' and Lennon added: 'We spent our youth on The Beatles.' Why did they succumb to this collective fantasy? Lennon heartbreakingly explained: 'What success really does for you is to give you a feeling of confidence in yourself. It's an indescribable feeling, but once you've had it, you never want it to stop.'

And then, of course, Lennon brought it to an end, an act of existential destruction that, perversely, proved his creative primacy in the band.When a 22-year-old Jann Wenner, founder of Rolling Stone, interviewed an angry Lennon in 1970 (now reissued with hitherto unpublished material) he asked if, having strangled his darling, he had a picture of 'When I'm Sixty Four'. Lennon replied: 'No, no. I hope we're a nice old couple living off the coast of Ireland... looking at our scrapbook of madness'. Ten years later, we read the news today, oh boy. Lennon was dead.

The Beatles redefined musical categories, elevated the ordinary to extraordinary heights and will be remembered forever (not least because of this astonishing book), but there is a sadness in memorialising a musical form whose very force depends on being both universal and evanescent. Ars longa, Pop Ars brevis.

webTitle: Observer review: Civilisations by Felipe Fernandez-Armesto

fields.headline: When dried fish ruled the world
fields.standfirst: It's on such seemingly trivial items that the world's great cultures have been built as Felipe Fernandez-Armesto reveals in Civilisations
fields.trailText: It's on such seemingly trivial items that the world's great cultures have been built as Felipe Fernandez-Armesto reveals in Civilisations
fields.body:
Civilisations
Felipe Fernandez-Armesto
Macmillan £25, pp636

Once, 'civilisation' was an easy word. It was about how you held your tea-cup, treated your captive, scanned your Alexandrine or flushed away your excrement. Now the term has fallen apart, its fragments stained with subjectivism. As Felipe Fernandez-Armesto says: 'All definitions seem vitiated... I am civilised, you belong to a culture, he is a barbarian.'

He is the most urbane of historians. This is one of those fashionable encyclopaedia-scale tomes (and he has written a few before), but whenever the going gets tough the author jumps forward to charm his reader: witty, sometimes sharply original, often in a gust of rage. Felipe has no patience with prayerful stuff about Western Christian civilisation. 'We Western Europeans are the dregs of Eurasian history and our lands are the sump into which that history has drained.' So is the civilisation word worth keeping at all? And if it is, how should we use it?

Felipe (for short, but not for lack of respect) admits that it is a 'Western' word. The imperial connotations - 'I am civilised, they are barbarians' - simply cannot be rinsed out of it. So why use it when, as he says himself, 'a society' or 'a culture' would do the job better? He derides so-called 'polythetic' definitions of civilisation which set up a checklist of attributes such as cities, writing, metallurgy, division of labour and so on. But then, arbitrarily enough, he selects his own definition. Civilisation is what can happen when humans significantly change their environment: 'a relationship between one species and the rest of nature'.

So the book is divided up into environments (the wastelands of 'desert, tundra, ice', the grasslands, the rain-forests, the mountain plateaux and valleys, the alluvial river-lands and so forth), and into accounts of how human beings managed or failed to transform their landscapes and seascapes. This is why the book does not run chronologically, until the final eruption of European culture and settlement across the globe forces an inevitable climax.

The borderline for Felipe runs between societies which adapt themselves to their surroundings and those which adapt their surroundings. For instance, the medieval Scandinavian settlers who arrived in Greenland established farms on the wintry barrens and built churches of local stone, but the Thule people who entered the region at around the same time came with light umiak boats and hunted over the ice with dog-teams. Ancestors of the Inuit, they survived climatic changes in this extreme environment, while the ambitious and landscape-refashioning European colony did not.

Simply to adapt and stay alive in tundra, swamp or desert may be a much more remarkable achievement than building a city among temperate woodlands. Felipe cites the horrible environment of Frederik Hendrik Island, off New Guinea, a sludge of mud and mosquitoes in which humans improbably invented a sustainable way of living on artificial mounds elaborately layered and manured for a variety of crops. And yet swamps no less repellent generated some of the first urban cultures in Central America.

Civilisations is anything but a hymn to progress. Felipe insists that there is nothing necessarily virtuous or inevitable about changes in material culture. 'If the environment works for you, why fix it?' He quotes the agronomist Jack Harlan, who pointed out the apparent senselessness of moving from a hunter-gatherer economy to settled agriculture. Hunter-gatherers were healthier, less vulnerable to the weather and worked much less hard. In the same way, the Industrial Revolution saw millions of people exchange a bad rural life for a far worse life in the new cities. It doesn't help to use the word 'advance' to describe these changes, as if the shift to greater complexity were planned.

Maybe intensive agriculture did not begin as an innovation for feeding more people, but started as a religious rite to do with death and the earth. Maybe the people who landed up in alluvial flood-plains arrived as unwilling refugees from lost hunting-grounds; they may have built drainage channels and dams simply to protect themselves, and only later discovered that these could be used to irrigate huge and regular crops.

Felipe never allows himself to grow bored with his material. None the less, a historian so lively is bound to find some tracts of world history less exciting than others. His sections on the classical world miss some targets. Surely it would have suited his 'relationship with nature' thesis to discuss how Black Sea dried fish made the Graeco-Roman empires possible. And what about the theory that those empires only happened because the early city-states exploited the fragile Mediterranean soils to death and were forced to expand into Gaul, North Africa or the Levant?

The author's archaeology can be a bit dated too. Diffusionism (the idea that all cultural developments radiated from a single centre by migration or conquest) has not been 'orthodoxy' for a long time. And why does he use the archaic Wade-Giles spelling for Chinese names?

He is at his best in three places: the medieval African states of the Sahel, the opening-up of the Atlantic and the history of the Indian Ocean. 'The precocity of the Indian Ocean as a zone of long-range navigation and cultural exchange is one of the glaring facts of history', made possible by the 'reversible escalator' of the monsoons. Roman, Chinese and Arab trading fleets cruised between the opulent coastal cities of the region, which remained a 'civilised' zone until Vasco da Gama smashed his way into it in 1498. (I cannot understand why Felipe is so charitable to this brutish terrorist.) Soon the coastal states of Europe learnt to 'crack the code' of the Atlantic winds, and a new 'Western' culture arose on both sides of the ocean.

But in the twentieth century that 'Atlantic civilisation' discharged an avalanche of cruelty and destruction. Asking himself 'why progress failed', Felipe suggests that the failure is almost as much an illusion as progress itself. The truth was that human beneficence had been badly over-estimated. And at the end of this long display of learning and passionate intelligence, he sums up: 'If you misrepresent civilisation as progressive, you are bound to disappoint people... scratch it and savagery bleeds out.'
