fields.headline: Turmoil may aid England
fields.trailText: Javed Miandad is not alone in finding the transition from playing to coaching difficult, writes Vic Marks, but the latest ructions in the Pakistan camp may be good news for England.
fields.body:
Monitoring the early stages of a cricket tour can be a tricky proposition for early arrivals among the press corps. Usually nothing much happens, and a tweaked hamstring endured by the first change seamer is regarded as manna from heaven by correspondents trying to fill up the page as they witness the phony war. However this is rarely the case in Pakistan.

Already we have had the suggestion by the chairman of the ECB that key members of the Pakistan team, most notably Wasim Akram, should not be allowed to play in the forthcoming series because they are still under suspicion of betting improprieties - although Lord MacLaurin has since back-tracked. Then there has been speculation that the senior seven members of the Pakistan team will go on strike anyway, since they are in dispute with their coach, Javed Miandad. In these circumstances a tweaked hamstring barely warrants a mention.

In any other country the threat of strike action by the players would be startling, headline news. We have learnt to be more wary when these stories emanate from Pakistan. Their cricket has long been punctuated by rifts and ructions with captains and coaches being shuffled with an alacrity that can only be rivalled by the managerial merry-go-round of English football. Indeed, the Pakistan cricket team often seems to thrive on internal disputes.

Wisely the England players, as they look ahead to the first one-day international on Tuesday, are working on the assumption that the key Pakistani players will all be present and correct when the two teams meet in Karachi. The Chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board, Lieutenant-General Tauqir Ali, is also making that assumption. Last week he eventually conceded that there are minor differences, which will always happen in a family. But they are not the ones that would destroy the unity of the team.

The nub of the dispute within the Pakistan squad appears to be that the coach, Javed Miandad, wants to run everything and that he is diminishing the input of the captain, Moin Khan, and senior players like Wasim. This is not difficult to believe. Brilliant ex-players, such as Miandad, have a problem when they undertake the role of coach.

In their pomp as cricketers they were accustomed to dominating everything and woe betide the coach who tried to interfere too much. Naturally enough when they graduate to a coaching position they tend to continue in their omnipotent ways. So they create a situation that they themselves would not have been able to tolerate in their own playing days. It takes much sensitivity to withdraw and to give the players their head. Moreover, they often find it difficult to understand the limitations of lesser mortals since they had so few themselves.

Miandad is not alone in finding the transition from playing to coaching difficult. Mike Gatting may not enjoy the parallel with his old adversary (Miandad was Gatting's opposite number back in 1987 and cunningly encouraged Shakoor Rana in Faisalabad not to offer any apology so that a day was lost in a Test that England were dominating), but he must have struggled with his new role in the Middlesex dressing room.

Some countries appear to have recognised this pitfall of having a high-profile, ex-player as coach. Instead they have opted for proven coaches rather than plucking out a man whose qualifications are based mainly on scores of Test caps and an outstanding Test record. England's Duncan Fletcher, who is deemed to be doing a good job - his contract has been extended until 2003 - falls into this category; so does David Trist, whose New Zealand side has just triumphed in the ICC Trophy, while cricketing 'nondescripts' John Buchanan and Graeme Ford are in charge of the two best sides in the world, Australia and South Africa. The parallel seems to apply in soccer as well. I have the impression that Alex Ferguson and Arsène Wenger were poorer footballers than Kevin Keegan and Bryan Robson, but as managers?

However, this is not to suggest that the wily Miandad lacks a strategy. He and his selectors know where the strengths and weaknesses of the England touring team lie and the Pakistan squad for the one-day internationals reflect them. They have selected no less than four spinners for the three-match series of one-day games.

As Imran Khan pointed out; England, with renewed self-belief since defeating the West Indies, have a good chance of victory if they can get a talented but susceptible Pakistan team to crack under pressure. Pakistan are seeking to prey on England's weakness against the turning ball right from the start. The Shadow Cabinet probably harbours more live grass than will be evident on the pitch in Karachi on Tuesday.

webTitle: Silvinho adds powder to Gunners' European keg

fields.headline: Silvinho adds powder to Gunners' European keg
fields.trailText: Their hunger for success is still not as great as Man Utd's, but individual skills and a solid system may see Arsenal to the Champions League final.
fields.body:
The most remarkable aspect of Manchester United is that, despite all their success in recent seasons, their players' appetite for honours remains as strong as ever. I really cannot think of any club in England where the hunger for success throughout the first team squad appears to be as pronounced as it is at United - and despite their epic Champions League performance against Lazio in Rome, that even includes Arsenal.

However, it does surprise me that while the bookmakers are quoting 4-1 against United winning the Champions League again, Arsenal are 9-1. For me, the gap between the two has never been as wide as those odds imply.

From what I have seen of Arsenal this season, their chances of making it to the final for the first time are probably better than they were on their previous attempts under Arsene Wenger.

It could be argued that the Gunners have never quite matched the all-round ability of their Championship and FA Cup-winning team of 1998. The key men no longer with the club are Emmanuel Petit, Marc Overmars and Nicolas Anelka. Petit has been particularly difficult to replace. His midfield partnership with Patrick Vieira was unquestionably the best in Britain, if not Europe.

When watching them in action together - and especially the protection they gave to their back four - I was often reminded of the impact of my two tigerish central midfield colleagues, Neil Simpson and Neale Cooper, in Alex Ferguson's old Aberdeen team.

We had a very similar system to Arsenal's, in that while Simpson and Cooper were the equivalents of Petit and Vieira, I filled the Ray Parlour-type role on the right of midfield and Peter Weir - a cross between a midfielder and a winger - was our Marc Overmars on the left. A lot of people referred to it as 4-4-2, but because of Weir, I preferred to describe it as 'four-three and a half-two and a half.' The tough, hard-running figures toiling in our middle of the field engine room were the key to our success.

At Arsenal, Petit and Vieira were the de-luxe versions of this breed; and it is great for Arsenal that Vieira, my favourite in that double-act, is still there. He has to be one of the most influential midfielders in the world. Of all the men I played with or against, the one who resembled him the most was probably Brazil's Cerezo, another powerful figure who was a member of the team who destroyed Scotland 4-1 in the 1982 World Cup in Spain.

To an extent, Graeme Souness could also be compared with him, although Graeme would be the first to concede that while he had Vieira's mental and physical toughness and passing skills, he lacked his athleticism.

Without Petit, it is perhaps only to be expected that Arsenal have not looked as solid in defence as they were. But against that, they have improved their attacking ability. With players like Thierry Henry, Kanu, Sylvain Wiltord - and, of course, Dennis Bergkamp - their options up front seem to have become wider than ever.

The point is emphasised by Henry, who has the same sort of pace as Anelka, but appears to have more strings to his bow in the type of goals he is capable of scoring. He is also a better team player than Anelka. When assessing Arsenal's scoring ability you also have to take into account the tremendous attacking ability of their new Brazilian full-back, Silvinho, and the growing stature of Fredrik Ljungberg in place of Overmars.

As potential Champions League finalists, I feel Arsenal have two other factors going for them. One is that, no matter who they are playing, they have the courage to stick to their usual system as much as possible. They know what suits them - what has worked for them - and while adjustments obviously need to be made from time to time, they do not go overboard.

This is one of the reasons why I was irritated at some of the criticism levelled at Kevin Keegan, over the fact that his England team did not initially line up with the same system as Germany for the World Cup game at Wembley. I know Kevin's approach did not work, but I think it was unfair on him to blame the system he used.

The other plus point for Arsenal is that their home ties are being played at Highbury again. Staging them at Wembley was a handicap, not least because of the distance between the fans and players.

Also, there is a big difference between the playing surfaces. The one at Highbury, in addition to being smaller, seems to me to be quicker than those of other major grounds.

In the attacking sense, Arsenal's present team are possibly better-equipped to capitalise on this than they have been in the past. So perhaps this will be their year.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: No peace until he dies
fields.standfirst: His body wracked by drugs, Argentina's hero would love to return home to a quiet life - but it will never happen
fields.trailText: His body wracked by drugs, Maradona would love to return home to Argentina and a quiet life - but it will never happen.
fields.body:
'It was as if we had beaten a country, more than just a football team,' writes Diego Maradona in his new autobiography. 'Although we had said before the game that football had nothing to do with the Malvinas war, we knew they had killed a lot of Argentine boys there, killed them like little birds. And this was a revenge.'

Like so much else in Yo soy el Diego (I am Diego), the account of Argentina's victory over England at the 1986 World Cup is fresh. 'Sometimes I think that everything in my life has been filmed,' writes Maradona, 'that all my life is in the magazines. And yet it isn't so.' Indeed not. This book reveals a different Maradona to the footballing Saddam Hussein of British perception.

On Friday Maradona turns 40. He is expected to die soon. In Cuba he has ample free time. Perhaps for these reasons, he has told two Argentinian journalists the story of his life.

The autobiography, which has an initial print run in Argentina of 150,000, is due to appear in 80 countries. Last month Maradona flew to Buenos Aires to promote it. Looking thinner than usual, he inveighed against hunger and poverty in Argentina, and after a few days received a phone call from Fidel Castro, who said, simply: 'Come back.' Maradona went.

But in Argentina he is still everywhere. 'Maradón!' the crowd began chanting at the end of the depressing international against Uruguay a fortnight ago. His face appears a dozen times on every newspaper kiosk, and the radios that play non-stop in Argentine houses assault you several times hourly with the singer Rodrigo's ode, La mano de Dios (Hand of God):

In a shanty town he was born,
It was God's will

The shanty town of Villa Fiorito, well-documented as it is, was never so clear as in this account. The eight Maradona siblings growing up in one room; when it rained, more water inside the house than outside; the turquoise corduroys that were his only pair of trousers; his father working from four in the morning until three in the afternoon.

'It wasn't easy, eh? Nothing was easy,' says Maradona.

It helps you understand why Maradona was perennially transporting an army of friends, relatives, and casual bystanders around the world. Snooty Catalonia was appalled when they all turned up in Barcelona in 1982, but Maradona delights in giving things to people. In the book he recounts the first time he took his family to the beach, the day he asked his father to stop working, and the Maradona family's first visit to Disneyworld (or Disneyland; he isn't quite sure).

Yet it was tough. He made his professional debut at 15, his international debut at 16, and by 19 had scored 100 league goals. 'I knew the jealousy of the others... His first World Cup, in 1982, is a deception. Maradona is mediocre, is kicked to pieces, and is sent off against Brazil for kicking the bearded Batista in the balls. As the book reveals, he got the wrong man. 'What few people know is that that kick was meant for Falcao.'

But as he reminds us, when the moment came he shook the hand of General Videla, the dictator.

This time, in the Azteca Stadium, Maradona does exactly that. By the time Butcher lumbers up to clog him, he has already scored. Later, in the changing room, he tells Valdano that he had been watching him all along.

'You scored this goal and you were watching me?' asks Valdano. 'You offend me, you humiliate me, it's not possible.' And Hector 'El Negro' Enrique calls from the shower: 'A lot of praise for him, but what about the guy who gave him the pass?' As Maradona comments in the book: 'Son of a bitch, Negro. In our own penalty area he gave me that pass!'

However, Maradona confesses that at times he prefers the first goal, the one he scored with his hand. 'It was like stealing the wallet of the English.'

No hard feelings, though. His visit to the Oxford Union in 1995 was 'one of the greatest joys of my life'. The crowd gives him an ovation and chants 'Diegouuu, Diegouuu!' in an English accent.

He also offers praise to several British players. Michael Owen is 'for me, the only player who stood out at the World Cup in France. Speed, wickedness, balls. I hope that injuries don't ruin him.' George Best was 'a great player, but even crazier than me'. (For Maradona, 'crazy' is generally a term of approbation.) Kevin Keegan 'was my idol for a long time'.

Only Shilton is castigated for his rage over the handled goal. 'And the other one, Shilton, didn't you see that? He didn't invite me to his farewell match. How many people can go to the farewell of a goalkeeper? A goalkeeper!' David Beckham, finally, is 'too beautiful to go on to the field'. But Maradona loves his passing.

His favourite player, however, seems to be his fellow left-footer Rivelinho. Maradona tells a lovely anecdote about the Brazilian sitting around with Gerson and Tostao at the World Cup of 1970. 'They were doing nothing, because those guys didn't have to do anything to play. Then Pelé turns up. And they think, "This shit black man, what can we say to him? The son of a bitch does everything well!" But Rivelinho always said the right thing. So he looked straight at Pelé, and said: "Tell me the truth. You would have liked to have been a left-footer, wouldn't you?"

Soon Maradona may die. Argentine heroes tend to die young: Carlos Gardel, Eva Peron, Che Guevara, and this year, in a car accident at the age of 27, the singer Rodrigo. Maradona's addiction to cocaine is regarded in Britain as further proof that he is 'mad' (the habitual British tag for wayward foreign footballers) but Argentinians see it differently. They point out that Maradona has been under unusual pressure since his late teens. Rodrigo explains:

He carries a cross on his shoulder
To be the best

Significantly, it was when he moved abroad and joined Barcelona, the biggest club in the world, that he began taking drugs. Or in Rodrigo's words:

Fame presented him with a
white woman
Of mysterious taste and forbidden
pleasure

If Maradona ruined his body with cocaine, and took the banned substance ephedrine to lose weight for the 1994 World Cup, he did it to serve his country. He gave of his flesh. And Argentina, in endless decline since before he was born, demanded it of him. Yes, other great players bore their greatness better than he did, but Johan Cruyff, Franz Beckenbauer and Bobby Charlton were from rich countries where football didn't have to compensate for everything else, while Pelé had the support of a generation so gifted that they won the 1962 World Cup without him. Maradona, however, carried Argentina on his shoulders.

Now he has had enough. In Cuba, he has retreated from the world. The island may not excel at drugs rehabilitation, but it is a small place with few journalists where the national sport is baseball and the political leader a Communist who makes reassuring noises about the poor instead of going on about inflation and the peso-dollar link. Maradona prefers this to a rehab clinic in Canada besieged by journalists with none of his friends around. His unfulfilled dream, he writes, is 'to return to my country and be left in peace'. This will never happen. In Argentina he will only become more legendary until he dies and is given a funeral to dwarf Evita's.

In England, he deserves better than to remain a victim of the fantasy that but for bad luck and cheating foreigners, this country would win more World Cups. Maradona might be a paranoid drug addict (he explains that governments want people to be drug addicts) but most of the time he seems to be a nice man. Sitting next to him at dinner in Oxford in 1995, I was astonished by his kindness. A few years later, I asked his old team-mate Valdano if he liked Maradona.

Valdano replied: 'I love Maradona.'

fields.headline: So, how good are Arsenal?
fields.standfirst: Arsene Wenger privately believes his team are capable of winning the Champions League
fields.trailText: After their cathartic draw against Lazio, there is a quiet confidence at Highbury that Arsène Wenger believes could take Arsenal all the way to Champions League success.
fields.body:
'Johnnie Lukic in goal? You what?' The reaction of a motley crew of Arsenal fans zigzagging towards Rome's Stadio Olimpico revealed a lot about their Champions League neurosis, a paranoia spawned by two humbling seasons of self destruction. First they laughed. Then, fearing the worst, they asked for directions to the airport.

They will be glad they stuck around after all to witness Arsenal complete their rite of European passage, disrobing themselves of any lingering insecurity against the pre-tournament favourites, Lazio. Robert Pires's equaliser did so much more than simply assure qualification to the next phase; it was cathartic, easing every shred of self-doubt about Arsenal's ability to compete with Europe's elite. With that soaring shot you could almost see an albatross disappearing into the Roman hills.

Back in the dressing room the Arsenal players were suffused with aspiration as much as celebration. Lee Dixon, captain on a memorable night, was focusing on the challenge ahead as soon as he was out of the shower.

'It's nice to sit back and feel we have qualified but we want to finish top of the group. That's our next aim. To win next week against Sparta. We're never satisfied at this club. We're not allowed to be satisfied with just qualifying.'

Joining last year's finalists Real Madrid and Valencia as the first to progress from the opening group phase, they deserve to feel smug. Admittedly, having two lightweights in the group was an advantage, as is the fact that Lazio's reputation appears deceptive. Nonetheless, job done. Now they fear no one.

'That was a big thing to come from the game,' said Dixon. 'We beat Lazio well at home and dominated, and I felt we should have won in Rome. We created more chances and never felt in any real danger at the back. We can take great confidence from the way we played against one of the biggest clubs in Europe.'

They don't like to talk up their chances at Highbury but there is a growing feeling that Arsenal have a sporting chance in the competition. Now the impulses behind Arsene Wenger's decision to politely withdraw from the England running become clearer: he covets the Champions League, and he feels closer than ever before.

Although the squad are three players short of ideal (a goalkeeper, centre half and creative midfield player remain on the wish list) Arsenal's strength is that the whole outweighs the sum of the parts; unlike Lazio, who resemble an Italian Chelsea. While Arsenal excelled playing their normal game, the Italian champions stuttered trying to locate theirs. A regular position for Hernan Crespo and Claudio Lopez, the world's most expensive strike force, must surely come soon.

As Dixon points out, 'We have enough experience in the team to know that individuals don't win games. It's how you perform as a team and I thought we performed better than them. That's the key, especially in the Champions League.

'It's a big, big effort to go through. You're playing top-class opposition and everybody has to be on their game or you just get pushed aside. That's what we've learned. It's more of a team game than in the Premiership, where sometimes you can play not so well and win with a touch of brilliance.'

Theses were pertinent thoughts a day later as Milan's flabbergasted San Siro was in thrall. In 22 extraordinary minutes Rivaldo and Demetrio Albertini engaged in a personal duel of free kicks. While they were the cherries the cake was pretty tasty anywhere, as AC Milan and Barcelona indulged in a 3-3 free-for-all of wonderfully open, attacking, committed, breathless football.

' Mamma Mia! ' wrote the journalist next to me who, trying to capture the spectacle, managed to get the Queen of England and James Bond into his eulogy. The expressions on the players' faces - a dramatic intensity sprung from total effort at terrifying speed - were amazing. This was a contest from a different realm to Lazio-Arsenal.

You get the feeling there is so much more to come from these glamorous European campaigners. Thrilling to watch, no question, but neither team possessed the discipline and balance to play ruthless, winning football (though Barcelona were closest and should have won). 'I had the feeling we were a little bit stronger than them but 3-3 is not a bad result,' reflected Frank De Boer.

With the super-powers building up a head of steam Leeds had better beware when Barcelona arrive at Elland Road on Tuesday with victory in mind. De Boer explains, 'We have the confidence to win in Leeds because every game we are improving. We have had bad results and been unlucky, playing well but conceding goals. Our luck has changed. The pressure is on Leeds.'

In fact the greater pressure is on Barca, who dare not fail. David O'Leary's maturing side are sitting pretty, together with Arsenal and Manchester United at the top of their groups. The national team might be ailing but England's clubs are healthy enough. At least one United, perhaps even two, can expect to join the Londoners in the hat for the second phase.

Arsenal are certain to face sterner examinations ahead but their authoritative form so far has at least made Europe's big clubs sit up and take notice. When Sven Goran Eriksson said Arsenal were capable of winning the competition after Lazio lost at Highbury last month it seemed he was trying to steer away from his own team's deficiencies. But the thoughtful Swede might not have been a million miles away. They are so much wiser now.

Tactically, Arsene Wenger is growing in stature by the game. Fielding three forwards - Dennis Bergkamp alongside Thierry Henry and Kanu - to face Lazio at Highbury was brave. In Rome he reverted to a more secure formation but still had the nerve to bring on the wit of Pires and willingness of Sylvain Wiltord, a move which brought rich rewards.

Arsenal's attacking possibilities have more variety and vigour than in previous campaigns. In 1998-99 Nicolas Anelka was still a baby with the modest Christopher Wreh in reserve. The following year Henry was feeling his way into a new role and Davor Suker never worked out. Now, Henry, Kanu and Wiltord have the experience, with Freddie Ljungberg and Pires providing genuine thrust from midfield.

And what an acquisition Silvinho has been. The bright Brazilian full back is influential in both penalty areas. Credit is also due to Oleg Luzhny, who stepped in for Tony Adams with aplomb. The new faces in the famous old defence are clicking and so the rearguard steadily becomes more of a unit. Handy too that they have stopped conceding last-minute goals - one was disallowed in Rome. You need a lucky break or two in the Champions League.

It has been a source of frustration for Arsenal that they feel a close match for Manchester United domestically, yet well in their shadows on the Continent.

'It's about time we qualified,' grinned Dixon. 'We've shown this year that we have learnt something, to be a bit more positive. And we've learned we like playing at Highbury. The two seasons just gone we didn't win our home games even though we did well away from home, like getting a point in Barcelona. But the two results which set us up this season were beating Lazio at home and coming back from 2-0 to beat Shakhtar.

'A lot was made about the Wembley factor and we didn't want to harp on, but I sincerely believe we would have qualified in the last couple of years had we been at Highbury. It makes a great difference to the players.'

Although they lost Petit and Marc Overmars last summer, Arsenal appear to be reinforced. Their collective spirit is back on track, that is why Gilles Grimandi stuck up for Patrick Vieira in the face of racist taunts, why Martin Keown charged around protecting Lukic as if his life depended on it.

'We make no secret of the fact we are quite close as a team,' said Dixon. 'Although we have a few different nationalities, we all get on. It's great at Highbury when we are playing well and everybody's getting a touch. It's when you come to places like Lazio, when your back is against the wall, that's when you see the character of the team. We showed here we never give up.'

Exhausted but exhilarated, he added: 'Now, we've got to do it all again.'

Their collective spirit is back on track, that is why Gilles Grimandi stuck up for Patrick Vieira in the face of racist taunts, why Martin Keown charged around protecting Lukic as if his life depended on it. 'We make no secret of the fact we are quite close as a team,' said Dixon. 'Although we have a few different nationalities, we all get on. It's great at Highbury when we are playing well and everybody's getting a touch. It's when you come to places like Lazio, when your back is against the wall, that's when you see the character of the team. We showed here we never give up.' Exhausted but exhilarated, he added: 'Now, we've got to do it all again.'

webTitle: No brotherly love for Tannadice tyrant McLean

fields.headline: No brotherly love for Tannadice tyrant McLean
fields.standfirst: Glenn Gibbons hasn't a pinhead of pity for Dundee United's deposed despot
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons hasn't a pinhead of pity for Dundee United's deposed despot.
fields.body:
Jim McLean's ignominious departure from Dundee United, charged with assault on a BBC Television reporter, was the seemingly inevitable result of a career spent failing to distinguish between life as he would like it to be and the real thing.

At 63, the club's former manager, chairman and managing director may have been considered by many to have long since passed the stage where a bad temper could lead him into possible prosecution. But such an assumption would betray an ignorance of McLean's reality-obscuring tempestuousness.

Those of us who have been familiar with his modus operandi through almost three decades as manager, director and, ultimately, chairman and major shareholder at Dundee United were not as surprised as those shocked TV viewers watching the incident. His alleged assault on reporter John Barnes, following verbal abuse at the end of an interview in which he seemed to become agitated at being asked about the appointment of his brother, Tommy, as coach and about the future of the manager, Alex Smith, came a few years after he had been accused of a similar loss of temper involving a BBC cameraman at Edinburgh Airport.

The latest episode ended with Barnes being treated by the United club doctor for a cut and badly swollen lip and an on-the-spot apology from Doug Smith, the vice-chairman. The following day, McLean himself made a public apology to Barnes. By then he had resigned, although he remains the owner of 41 per cent of the club's equity. He has resolved to sell his shareholding to complete the severance.

Curiously, many professional commentators discovered 'sadness' in the manner of McLean's departure, recalling his outstanding success is transforming Dundee United from and old-time Scottish Second Division team into one capable of winning the championship and reaching the semi-finals of the European Cup as well as the Uefa Cup final.

McLean's achievements were undeniable, but the many who could claim to have been victims of his ruthlessness since his appointment at the end of 1971 would find it difficult to muster so much as a pinhead of pity.

McLean, a lifelong non-smoking teetotaller, was born into a Plymouth Brethren family in Lanarkshire, whose religious fundamentalism may have contributed to his own tendency towards a kind of vengeance that was pure Old Testament. Insults and injustices may have been real or imagined, but they were invariably magnified to the point where they could only be met with controlled retaliation.

These were no heat-of-the-moment altercations. Rather they were the result of McLean's clincial planning. Most of this was possible in the days when clubs had unbreakable control over players' contracts and insurrectionists could be deprived of their livelihood unless they conformed. For example, a few years back, one foreign player was involved in a vendetta that lasted so long that the rest of the United squad on more than one occasion had a whip-round so their clubmate could buy food. On another occasion, a promising young player's bad experience at the club reached the ears of his father, who arrived at the door of McLean's office one day, barged in and exacted physical retribution.

Another player became embroiled in the manager's rule about where players should live - many clubs have similar criteria. In this case, McLean insisted his players should live within a 30-mile radius of Dundee.

The player had a home he loved in Glenrothes, in Fife. He argued that he was 29 miles from Dundee. He related later his incredulity when McLean climbed into his car and drove to the player's home, announcing tri umphantly that the distance was exactly 30.1 miles. The player had to move house.

Allowed this kind of autocratic totalitarianism by a feudal, anachronistic contract system, it was hardly surprising that McLean should encounter insurmountable difficulties in handling the great changes which have transformed the business of football in the past decade.

As his team under a succession of different managers have slithered into decline on the field and the financial soundness of the club has been disrupted, McLean has been besieged in recent years by United For Change, the fans' pressure group seeking his removal, the disposal of his stock, and the release of 13,000 shares which have remained unissued for years, effectively helping to strengthen Mclean's power base.

All of their objectives are now likely to be achieved, ironically through the misadventures of their target rather than their own actions.

webTitle: Fruitless search for a miracle manager

fields.headline: Fruitless search for a miracle manager
fields.trailText: The FA's publicity machine may be doing a fine job of whittling down the options but it is unrealistic to expect miracles until England begin producing more players.
fields.body:
The Football Association has become vastly more publicity conscious over the past 10 years, no longer blinking under unwanted spotlights but positively enjoying the interregnums between England managers when they become the focus of attention.

In the process they have become much slicker. Last week they managed to rule out the 'people's choice' - or at least the candidate half the nation's back pages have been promoting since Kevin Keegan's departure - without even mentioning Terry Venables' name.

Howard Wilkinson too has been ever-so-gently shafted, first by his deliberate inclusion on the committee set up to find the next manager, then by the pointed reference in the newly adopted criteria to 'ability to inspire a team'.

It is easy to imagine every manager in the country except one having a good laugh on reading that. Next England manager must have the ability to inspire a team. Whatever next? Own tracksuit an advantage? Familiarity with offside rule essential? It might have been kinder just to stipulate the next man's initials must not be HW or that applicants from Yorkshire need not bother. For now Wilkinson not only knows he won't get the job, he knows exactly why he is not wanted.

Lazio's Anglophile manager Sven-Goran Eriksson appears to be the man the FA do want - the appointment of a caretaker this week notwithstanding - though naturally no one is saying so at this stage. If you look closely at the seven-man committee's criteria, the two managers who spring immediately to mind, apart from the Swede, are Arsène Wenger and Sir Alex Ferguson. These are the two the FA are believed to have been most keen on from day one, but the last thing they want is to be seen to be desperate.

Putting all their effort into a siege of Highbury or Old Trafford, only to receive the most public rebuff when a manager opts to stay with his club, is so 20th century. Much better just to let your man know he is wanted then keep your distance. It might not succeed, but at least you aren't embarrassed and the eventual manager does not know he was third or fourth choice.

So when the FA let it be known they would love to consider Ferguson, but don't see any point in pursuing him because he intends to retire, it may not be the end of the matter. All Ferguson has to do now is indicate there are some challenges that would persuade him to postpone his retirement, and business could result. There is still the obstacle of his being a proud Scot to overcome, but how much prouder could a Scot get than being asked to rescue English football?

More or less the same applies to Wenger, though it is difficult to see too many other coaches matching to the FA's superhuman criteria. The assumption seems to be that since England have not won anything for 34 years, and since the job has taken a visible toll on most of the incumbents since 1966, the new man must be at the very peak of his profession with the medals to prove it.

Yet there is evidence from all over the world that club success does not always translate onto the international stage. From a managerial point of view the two jobs are totally different, and many countries see nothing wrong in appointing relative unknowns as national coaches. Mighty Brazil have just appointed such a manager; Emerson Leao would not fulfil any of the FA's criteria for achievement or integrity, as in a modest club career the only reputation he has acquired has been for the thuggish nature of his teams.

None of the French World Cup winning triumvirate of Aime Jacquet, Gerard Houllier and Roger Lemerre got their jobs by carrying off the major European prizes; and Humberto Coelho, who took Portugal in some style to within a golden goal penalty of the final of Euro 2000, had no club background whatsoever before taking over the national side and has since disappeared back into obscurity.

It appears that the best sides are still the ones with the best players. If you have a generation of talent like France, or outstanding individuals like Portugal, the guy in charge does not necessarily have to be the most decorated or well-travelled manager around. He just has to be a proficient coach. There is no reason why England should not go out and get the best man they can find, but they will be getting a football coach, not an alchemist.

It is unrealistic to expect miracles until England begin producing more players.

fields.headline: Thompson fells the fall guys
fields.trailText:
Celtic 2 - 1 Dundee United
Thompson fells the fall guys
fields.body:
Stretching away into a 12-point lead over Rangers in the championship would warm Celtic fans more thoroughly than the manner of its achievement. Another patchy, workmanlike performance on a day when a massacre of the league's bottom club had been anticipated was rescued by the goals from Henrik Larsson and Alan Thompson - the latter becoming a handy contributor - which preceded the aberration which brought Paul Lambert an unwanted credit as Dundee United's scorer.

But expectations of landslide victories are rarely fulfilled, especially when the nominated victims are fighting for survival. On these occasions, fear lends strength to their endeavours, leading to the kind of resolute resistance which creates seemingly interminable periods of stalemate.

United showed that they would not be easily subdued, demonstrating a commitment to the cause which amounted to a virtual guarantee that Celtic would have little room in which to manoeuvre.

By the time Larsson scored, the legions in the stands were consciously raising short-lived chants, as if realising that their own anxiety had become palpable, likely to be transmitted to the players. Thompson's supplementary effort in the second half dispelled the fretfulness.

They could hardly be criticised for their lengthy, watchful silences, the league leaders having induced in them an apprehension which could be relieved only by a tangible sign of superiority. Territorial advantage really had to be accompanied by at least one goal.

Larsson, despite looking relatively pedestrian - at times even uncharacteristically disoriented - could have scored five minutes before he gave the home side the lead, but sent his header against Alan Combe's right post after stooping to meet Thompson's corner.

Larsson's goal also came from a set piece, this time a corner on the left, which Petrov played short to Thompson, who teed it up for the Bulgarian. His centre found Larsson diving into space to bullet the header past Combe from six yards.

With their defence policy violated, United resorted to the contingency plan, clearly based on making quick headway towards Gould whenever a break in the pressure occurred. Predictably, they managed to create some alarm in the Celtic defence, which, with only Tom Boyd, Johan Mjallby and Joos Valgaeren patrolling the area, tended to be strung out by the Parkhead side's own emphasis on attack.

On one sortie, Jonathan Gould was required to make a very handy save from Craig Easton, diving right at full stretch to push away a powerful low drive from the Scotland under-21 midfielder which would have brought the equaliser but for the goalkeeper's intervention.

But John Licina clearly believed he had provided the goal with the last action of the first half, meeting a corner kick from the right and directing an intelligent header past Gould. It was stopped by Bobby Petta and, ultimately, gathered into the arms of Gould, but Licina made the kind of prolonged appeal to the referee which suggested he believed the ball had crossed the line.

Thompson's goal would be met with raucous acclaim not only for its meaningfulness, but because it was so attractively constructed and sweetly executed during a match that had become rather bland. Lambert began the mischief by sliding the ball short to Mjallby and the big defender's cross from the right was high and looping. Chris Sutton, almost invariably the master in these situations, won the aerial joust with Jason de Vos and nodded the ball into the path of Thompson, whose beautifully-controlled, low, right-foot drive skidded at pace to the left of Combe and into the corner of the net.

The goal which brought United previously unsuspected encouragement could hardly have been more different. A seemingly harmless cross from the left fell to John McQuillan, but he was easily dispossessed as he tried to control the ball and take aim at Gould's net. Lambert, coming across to complete the clearance, simply lashed the ball into his own net from six yards.

If the scoreline looked distorted, it should still serve to encourage a United side still seeking their first league victory of a tortured season. There was evidence enough through the 90 minutes of their desire and resilience. A sprinkling of good fortune seems overdue.

fields.headline: Svensson adds edge
fields.trailText:
Charlton 1 - 0 Middlesbrough
New boy Ehiogu injured as Boro lose away record.
fields.body:
There is a fine line between confidence and arrogance, so Matt Svensson must have been delighted to justify his pre-match claims that the Premiership is easier than the First Division for forwards by heading Charlton's winning goal.

The Swedish striker, who had previously been out of action after breaking his arm in pre-season, claimed that forwards were given more time and space in the top flight than the First Division, where he had played for Portsmouth and Crystal Palace.

As if to back up his words, Boro's defenders obliged by leaving Svensson unmarked at the far post to head home Claus Jensen's deep free-kick in the 68th minute, just moments after going on as a substitute for his Premiership debut.

His joy was in stark contrast to the look on the face of fellow debutant Ugo Ehiogu, Boro's £8m signing from Aston Villa, who limped off with a calf strain just five minutes into his first appearance for the club and could be out of action for a month.

As his manager Bryan Robson lamented: 'It obviously wasn't going to be our day when that happened. We were very solid and deserved to win, but Charlton scored with their only effort on target and we were denied a blatant penalty.'

Robson was critical of referee Mike Riley, who waved play on when Boro striker Andy Campbell appeared to be tripped by Mark Kinsella inside the penalty area in the closing minutes of a first-half almost devoid of incident.

Indeed Charlton were more like the away side for most of the game, defending in numbers and attacking on the break, which was a sensible tactic given Boro's previously unbeaten away record.

Even without injured top scorer Alen Boksic, Middlesbrough had the best of the chances, forcing Charlton's goalkeeper Dean Keily to make sharp saves from Paul Ince, Hamilton Ricard and Brian Deane.

Charlton, by contrast, hardly threatened Mark Crossley in the Boro goal but as their manager Alan Curbishley said: 'I asked them to dig in and that is exactly what they did.We were desperately short of strikers but Svensson answered the call and we always planned to get him on at some stage. I'm really pleased for him. He's still not fully fit and is playing with a shin pad on his arm, but he really wanted to be part of it and those are the sort of players I need.'

fields.headline: More woe for Rio
fields.trailText:
West Ham 1 - 2 Arsenal
Arsenal keep pace as the Hammers battle to save a point.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger was man enough to betray his relief at hearing the final whistle. West Ham, bereft of confidence when they were played off the pitch in the opening exchanges, were now bombarding the Arsenal goal in search of an equaliser and blood was beginning to boil.

Martin Keown was so hot he appeared to self combust, pumping his fists warrior-like to Arsenal and West Ham fans in equal measure. Mind you, he had been called 'Monkey Head' for most of the first half.

The atmosphere gets so tense in these games at Upton Park that only the weird would not react to it in some way - no blood was actually spilt.

The more lasting consequences of this match are the three points which help Arsenal keep pace with Manchester United and a defeat which leaves West Ham without a home win and locked in the bottom three.

'The final whistle came at the right moment, in many ways,' Arsene Wenger said afterwards. 'It was Fifa's Fair Play Day and I feared the worse. Sometimes these occasions can bring a surprise. But I thought the referee kept it quiet.'

The referee was not alone in his attempt to promote goodwill. Six women clad in Abba's Eurovision cast-offs held Fifa's Fair Play banner up to the crowd before the kick-off.

West Ham's show of peace was not totally unified - before the teams emerged the crowd were shown footage of recent clashes between the clubs, culminating in a close-up of Patrick Vieira spitting at Neil Ruddock last season. So much for letting the past rest.

The crowd may have been revved up, but the players seemed calm. And while West Ham finished the stronger, they had only themselves to blame for chasing a near-impossible task.

Trevor Sinclair gifted Robert Pires the chance to score Arsenal's opening goal in the 12th minute and Rio Ferdinand headed in an own goal 11 minutes later. Had Shaka Hislop not made a couple of good saves from Sylvain Wiltord and blocked Patrick Vieira when clear on goal, Arsenal could have been five up.

fields.headline: Ipswich eye Europe
fields.trailText:
Bradford 2 - 0 Ipswich
The Ipswich success story continues.
fields.body:
Ipswich continue to surprise everyone in the Premiership - except perhaps themselves.

Manager George Burley has already raised eyebrows this season by claiming his newly-promoted side are capable of qualifying for Europe.

After strolling past consistently disappointing Bradford to claim a third away victory in succession and climb to sixth, however, the evidence is starting to build up.

He said: 'I was brought up in the 70s and 80s in the Ipswich side which played in Europe and played attractive football and that's where I want to take the club back.

'Over the last few years, the players have created a system everyone is comfortable with, and I'm very pleased with the way they have adapted this year, they don't fear anybody. Yet, we were poor in the second half , we'll play better and lose this season.'

Burley clearly sets extremely high standards. Bradford did mount something of a charge after the break, but a late goalmouth scramble apart, Ipswich always looked comfortable.

The visitors passed the ball better, defended better and reduced Bradford to pot shots from distance. The best of those, a terrific 25-yard Stuart McCall volley, was well saved by Richard Wright.

The opener may have been somewhat fortunate, Matt Holland's cross spinning in from Dan Petrescu's deflection, but Ipswich's all-round superiority was finally illustrated with two minutes to play when Jamie Clapham's superb 20-yard free-kick curled into the bottom corner.

A minute earlier, Matt Clarke had pulled off a breathtaking save from substitute David Johnson's header, described by Burley as 'world class'. The result does not send Bradford back to the bottom, but with just one win all season and four goals scored in the league, Chris Hutchings' first two months of management have been something of a baptism of fire.

He was the first to admit his side's shortcomings afterwards and said: 'You can't fault the players for effort, but you need more than that at this level.

'When we beat Chelsea here, we set our standards for the season, but we've just not matched those since. I wish I knew why.

'But we'll keep working hard. If we get a couple of wins under our belt, confidence will soon return.'

If they keep performing like this, it is difficult to see where even two wins are going to come from.

fields.headline: Ingledow swoops
fields.trailText:
Chesterfield 1 - 0 Brighton
Chesterfield stay calm to remain on top.
fields.body:
It'ss tight at the top. They had to delay the kick-off for a quarter of an hour to cram everyone into Saltergate yesterday and, considering the length of these teams' unbeaten runs, perhaps it was no surprise that it took Chesterfield until the 91st minute before they finally broke Brighton's resolve to extend their lead at the top of the Third Division.

Brighton, losing for the first time in 11 games, survived for 40 second-half minutes with ten men after Charlie Oatway, on Fifa's fair play day, was sent off. But then Ryan Williams, Chesterfield's chief creator, dribbled his way to the byline and crossed to the far post where substitute Jamie Ingledow, only on for the final nine minutes, crashed in the winning header.

Chesterfield have plans to move to the greyhound stadium while Brighton are already playing at their local athletics venue. But neither is going to the dogs; both certainly appear right on track.

The first half was a tightly-contested affair, epitomised by a challenge eight minutes before the break when the ball was fortunate to come out left with any air in it. Ryan Williams, Chesterfield's busy winger, and Oatway, one of Brighton's skin-headed hard men, went in completely fairly on that occasion. But when they rumbled in stoppage time, the tension spilled over. All but three player rushed in to give their version of events which ended with Oatway being booked. But it was Brighton who edged the first period, eight-goal Bobby Zamora swivelling on to a loose ball after eight minutes to shoot wide.

Unfortunately Oatway could not dim his combative-ness and six minutes after the break, as Sean Parrish broke clear of him in the centre circle, the Brighton midfielder clipped his opponent's heels.

Both clubs have known how it feels to prop up a division, Chesterfield having finished bottom of the Second Division last May while Brighton, three times in five seasons, finished in penultimate spot. This year however, things have been looking up.

Ambition has been reflected in investment. No club in the basement division has outlaid more than the £150,000 Chesterfield spent on Luke Beckett, missing with a thigh injury yesterday, who scored 19 goals for doomed Chester City.

But expectation was also high for Mickey Adams' team this season, after they finished last term unbeaten in 14 games, though this season started off at a trundle before this long unbeaten run. The first goal they had conceded in ten hours was even credited to their own goalkeeper, on Wednesday, when Michel Kuipers fumbled a Hartlepool cross over his own line.

Chesterfield meanwhile, under the guidance of former captain Nicky Law, immortalised at Saltergate for leading the team to Wembley triumph five years ago in the Third Division play-off final against Bury, have exceeded hopes. They had won six games on the bounce before two draws culminated in a 2-2 share at Rochdale on Tuesday.

But Chesterfield, despite being pinned back in their own half for much of the early action yesterday, at least held their own in the first period. They tore into Brighton and were unfortunate when Marcus Ebdon, with 20 minutes remaining, collected the ball off David Reeves, composed himself and curled a shot towards the top corner only for Kuipers to save in spectacular fashion. Brighton defended with resolve but after 84 minutes were again grateful for their reserve goalkeeper when Kuipers tipped Ebdon's 25-yard volley aside.

fields.headline: Chelsea banish blues
fields.trailText:
Chelsea 6 - 1 Coventry
Hasselbaink scores four as Chelsea step up a gear.
fields.body:
If communication between Claudio Ranieri and his Chelsea players really is as difficult as it was made out to be last week, heaven help the rest of the Premiership when they reach a common language.

Certainly everyone was on the same wavelength yesterday, notably Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, who helped himself to four goals as 10-man Coventry were out-classed in an embarrassingly one-sided match.

Granted, there was a major question mark over referee Steve Lodge's decision to dismiss 19-year-old Chris Kirkland for bringing down Hasselbaink and awarding the penalty which opened the floodgates. Television replays seemed to confirm the initial impression that the goalkeeping, deputising for the injured Magnus Hedman, got a hand on the ball before the Chelsea striker went tumbling over midway through the first half.

In truth, however, Coventry were already in a mess. They had no shape, were being overrun in the middle of the field and Hasselbaink had already wasted two golden opportunities. There was no doubt that they were heading for a beating and manager Gordon Strachan acknowledged that afterwards, while insisting that Lodge was wrong.

Strachan, a model of diplomacy who may try to have the dismissal rescinded said: 'You knew by the lad's reaction that he did touch the ball. It was one of those days when everything that could go wrong did so. We all have to be responsible - myself, the coaching staff and the players. It was a horrible experience which we must learn from. We all made mistakes. At times like this, I can usually find some humour, but not today.'

Ranieri, who thought it was a penalty, was all smiles, declaring through an interpreter that he was impressed by his team's 'mentality' and the scoring prowess of Hasselbaink.

The only blot on his afternoon was Coventry's consolation goal scored by substitute Cedric Roussel, who punished goalkeeper Ed de Goey for juggling with a back-pass from Frank Leboeuf instead of whacking the ball clear.

Gustavo Poyet returned after a six-week absence to dominate proceedings, laying on the through ball which brought the penalty, dispatched by Hasselbaink past Kirkland's replacement Alan Miller, just signed on loan from Blackburn Rovers.

The red-card seemed to demoralise Coventry completely and just before half-time, Dennis Wise and Gianfranco Zola combined to feed Hasselbaink, who cut in from the left touchline to beat Miller with a sharp, low angled drive.

In the second half Strachan tried to prevent the match from becoming a rout by bringing on Richard Shaw and reverting to a three-man defence but it made no difference. Almost immediately Zola scored the goal of the game, accepting a 40-yard cross-field pass from Sam Dalla Bona on his chest without breaking stride and scoring off the far upright.

From a ball played in by Poyet, Zola then had a shot saved by Miller, the ball rebounding for Hasselbaink to complete his hat trick into an empty net. By now Chelsea were strolling as a mistake by the Coventry captain Moustapha Hadji enabled Mario Melchiot and Tore Andre Flo to set up Hasselbaink for 5-0 with an emphatic finish. Flo himself got the sixth with a far post header from a centre by Celestine Babayaro and Chelsea could have finished with a 10 on the board.

They were guilty at times of over-elaboration and, perhaps understandably, trying to simply walk the ball into the net. But such was their dominance that the only semblance of a Coventry chance, apart from Roussel's gift, was at the start of the second half when Craig Bellamy set up Hadji who was denied thanks to the alertness of Marcel Desailly. For the rest Strachan's side never got a look in.

On its own, this performance will not be enough to restore Chelsea's title pretensions but at least it's a start.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Activist urges Burma protests
fields.standfirst: Fugitives tell of Burma's jungle reign of terror
fields.trailText: James Mawdsley yesterday called on activists to follow his lead and protest in Burma against the military junta. He revealed the extent of physical and mental abuse he suffered during 60 weeks of solitary confinement.
fields.body:
James Mawdsley yesterday called on activists to follow his lead and protest in Burma against the military junta. He revealed the extent of physical and mental abuse he suffered during 60 weeks of solitary confinement.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer , the 27-year-old Briton told for the first time how he was deprived of human rights.

Mawdsley, a physics student who dropped out of Bristol University after one year despite being tipped for a double first, described how he was kept under 24-hour observation in a cell flooded with light and beaten by guards with truncheons and gravel-filled stockings.

He told how, on one occasion, 15 guards burst into his room after he had written the Burmese word for 'peace' on his cell door in water and illustrated it with the symbol of a cross. They left him semi-conscious in a pool of blood.

But he said that every privation was worth the pain if it helped the country escape the military dictatorship that has ruled since Aung San Suu Kyi, leader of the opposition National League for Democracy, was prevented from taking office after winning a 1990 election.

Emotional and weary after his 36-hour journey from the remote Keng Tung prison, Mawdsley arrived back home in Britain in the early hours of yesterday morning to adulation and applause.

He said that he had been 'absolutely delighted' when the Burmese court had condemned him to 17 years in jail in August 1999.

It was the third time in two years that the human rights activist had been arrested in Burma for trying to highlight the genocide of 30,000 members of the Karenni tribe and displacement of 600,000 more.

He had been 'frustrated', he said, when deported in 1998, but felt that he was 'finally getting somewhere' when he was imprisoned after returning a few months later without a passport. He was then sentenced to five years' solitary confinement, but told The Observer that he had been disappointed to be deported again after 99 days.

'I'm drawn to Burma not by the suffering, but by the Karenni people and their strength despite the relentless oppression. By returning to Burma for the third time and getting the staggeringly hysterical sentence of 17 years, I finally managed to highlight the madness of the regime,' he said. 'Getting released after 15 months has shown that the international community can move the junta if they put their mind to it.'

The deeply religious Roman Catholic pledged to continue the fight from outside the country. 'My strength came from St Paul,' he said. 'God was protecting me every moment, down to the most absurd details and in the most unpredictable ways.'

Mawdsley believed his action had been a success in terms of bringing the troubles of the people in Burma to international attention. 'I've shown that this is an incredibly powerful and worthwhile form of protest, but if anyone needs encouragement to go out and do what I did, they shouldn't go,' he said. 'You need to, despite family and friends saying: "You're crazy".'

fields.headline: Black day for crumbling Palace
fields.trailText:
C Palace 2 - 3 Portsmouth
Pompey come from behind to increase Palace's woes.
fields.body:
So Steve Claridge's Portsmouth miracle continues. Three games, three goals, three wins reads his record as player-manager, and he is obviously perfecting the art of motivation. Two goals down and outplayed in the first half, his team in the end won easily.

Both sides, looking for positive pre-match omens, could seek some solace in statistics. Portsmouth, with a 100 per cent record since Steve Claridge's appointment as manager, were the team in form. Palace, meanwhile, had lost their last four league games.

But statistics cannot sustain either club, and both are struggling to haul themselves out of financial troughs. While Portsmouth have produced the results, Palace have been spending money - this week they signed Latvian winger Andrejs Rubins for £2m, and Liverpool's Steve Staunton, whose transfer was free but whose wages are anything but.

The home side had the better of a first half in which neither side excelled, and while both new signings played well, it was Tommy Black, a £500,000 summer purchase from Arsenal, who stood out. After half an hour he ended a good run by playing Morrison through, but the home-grown striker's shot was headed off the line by Michael Panopoulos.

The deadlock was broken four minutes later when Black picked up the ball and took two steps forward before sending a fine shot into the top right corner from 20 yards. Five minutes later he scored again. Forssell this time was played through on the left, and when he screwed his shot across goal Black reached the loose ball first to tap into an empty net.

In first-half stoppage time Portsmouth undeservedly pulled a goal back. Aleksandr Kolinko looked to have caught the ball but dropped it when Lee Bradbury appeared to shove him. Steve Claridge duly knocked in his third goal in as many games.

So Palace spent half-time brooding over their misfortune, Portsmouth laughing at their luck. Certainly, the game was transformed as the second period began, and Pompey had their first period of dominance. Enjoying himself more than most was Ceri Hughes, a half-time substitute for injured captain Darren Moore, who, within 15 minutes, created the equaliser.

Given room on the left to cross, Hughes picked out Thomas Thogersen, who rose unchallenged six yards from goal to leave Kolinko help less. It was, sadly, to be the highlight of Hughes' day, as 10 minutes later he sustained an injury and was replaced.

Portsmouth knew the game was theirs for the taking, and with 10 minutes remaining they took it. Again the goal came from a left-wing cross, Nigel Quashie this time providing the service, and Mike Panopoulos meeting it with a mishit shot which bounced over Kolinko.

While Portsmouth have produced the results, Palace have been spending money - this week they signed Latvian winger Andrejs Rubins for £2m, and Liverpool's Steve Staunton, whose transfer was free but whose wages are anything but. The home side had the better of a first half in which neither side excelled, and while both new signings played well, it was Tommy Black, a £500,000 summer purchase from Arsenal, who stood out. After half an hour he ended a good run by playing Morrison through, but the home-grown striker's shot was headed off the line by Michael Panopoulos. The deadlock was broken four minutes later when Black picked up the ball and took two steps forward before sending a fine shot into the top right corner from 20 yards. Five minutes later he scored again. Forssell this time was played through on the left, and when he screwed his shot across goal Black reached the loose ball first to tap into an empty net. In first-half stoppage time Portsmouth undeservedly pulled a goal back. Aleksandr Kolinko looked to have caught the ball but dropped it when Lee Bradbury appeared to shove him. Steve Claridge duly knocked in his third goal in as many games. So Palace spent half-time brooding over their misfortune, Portsmouth laughing at their luck. Certainly, the game was transformed as the second period began, and Pompey had their first period of dominance. Enjoying himself more than most was Ceri Hughes, a half-time substitute for injured captain Darren Moore, who, within 15 minutes, created the equaliser. Given room on the left to cross, Hughes picked out Thomas Thogersen, who rose unchallenged six yards from goal to leave Kolinko help less. It was, sadly, to be the highlight of Hughes' day, as 10 minutes later he sustained an injury and was replaced. Portsmouth knew the game was theirs for the taking, and with 10 minutes remaining they took it. Again the goal came from a left-wing cross, Nigel Quashie this time providing the service, and Mike Panopoulos meeting it with a mishit shot which bounced over Kolinko.

webTitle: Fugitives tell of Burma's  jungle reign of terror

fields.headline: Fugitives tell of Burma's  jungle reign of terror
fields.standfirst:
Idealistic young Britons have risked their freedom to campaign against Rangoon's repressive regime. Yesterday James Mawdsley flew home after his release from jail. Last month another former prisoner, Rachel Goldwyn , returned to the region to record the destruction of a persecuted hill tribe. This is her poignant account

Activist urges Burma protests
fields.trailText: Idealistic young Britons have risked their freedom to campaign against Rangoon's repressive regime. Yesterday James Mawdsley flew home after his release from jail. Last month another former prisoner,  Rachel Goldwyn , returned to the region to record the destruction of a persecuted hill tribe. This is her poignant account
fields.body:
As I scrambled through the mud towards the refugee camp, the sounds and scents overwhelmed me. I could hear logs being chopped, children playing, pigs squealing, cockerels squawking, and could smell the woodsmoke and the wet jungle. Memories came flooding back and I found myself terribly anxious.

Would people remember me? Would they be happy to see me? But my welcome at the camp in Thailand, near the Burmese border, could not have been warmer. Many of the students I had taught English now had children. One was named after me, born while I was in jail. 'Gold Rachel' was delightful and, unlike most Karenni babies, didn't scream at the sight of a white face.

And then there were the new arrivals, with terrible tales of persecution and suffering. They had been living in the jungle for several years, having fled the relocation decreed in the Nineties by Burma's military dictatorship, one called 'Slorc' and now known as the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC).

Their individual stories formed a picture of genocide. In the jungle they had to move five or six times a year, and slept without a roof over them. Their hiding place was discovered when their fifth child had just been born. Samuel is a skinny, unusually tall Karenni. 'The placenta hadn't even come out yet. I was terribly worried about my wife, I carried her through the streams as I was afraid about her walking through the cold water. But when we got to the border I couldn't carry her as we had to walk in the stream a long way. Now she gets migraines all the time.' The family walked for three weeks. They had to evade not just troops but mines and had to rely for guidance either on hired guides or resistance army soldiers.

The Karenni are among the many persecuted ethnic minorities in Burma. Those that have no ceasefire agreement with the dictatorship have had their areas declared free-fire zones. Human rights abuses are rampant and hundreds of villagers victimised in an attempt to turn them against the resistance. The so-called 'Four Cuts' campaign tries to stop food, recruits, information and money reaching the resistance armies.

Forced relocation began in 1974 in Karen and Chin State. In 1996 the scale of relocations increased dramatically, with 25,000 people forced into 'relocation centres' within Karenni State: roughly one eighth of the Karenni people torn from their ancestral lands in 12 months.

Many areas of Karenni State, as well as other parts of Burma, have been cleared: 30,000 people used to live in an area approximately 100 miles by 30 miles in eastern Karenni, now it is completely depopulated. Escapees described to me the appalling conditions in relocation sites. There was no access to clean water, no land to cultivate, no materials for housing. Troops were everywhere.

The old villages were burnt down and the remains mined to stop people returning, animals were slaughtered, and those determined to stay in their homes were burnt alive. Torture, beating and arbitrary execution accompany the SPDC soldiers wherever they go.

When Paw Moo, now in her thirties, decided to go to a relocation camp, they had five days to vacate their own village four kilometres away. They had to do forced labour at the military base.

She said: 'About six months ago the soldiers called all the villagers together, and arrested all the men. They took some as forced porters and others to Loikaw - the capital of Karenni State. Some managed to escape, others were put in jail, about 20 men disappeared. My husband hid in the jungle, many men did. After they arrested the men, they called the women together and said "if we hear gun shots or that rebel groups are in the area, then we will kill you".' When she and her family made the treacherous journey to Thailand, many of the men were still in jail.

Sonny, from the same village as Paw Moo, confirms her story. 'The SPDC arrested 32 men and one woman because of fighting near the border. The resistance troops came near to our village, but they didn't come in or get food.'

As we sat in the early-morning mist, Mee Reh told me his painful story. He was a subsistence farmer relocated from a village called Wha Lo. 'In 1995 the SPDC burnt down our village. Some people were killed, we ran away.' The years of sleepless nights and desperate poverty were written on his face. His youngest child, now two but the still the size of a six-month-old baby, will never fully develop, physically or mentally.

They dodged troops, hiding in the jungle or in a cave. Often the sound of shooting kept them awake all night. They drank rice water and ate bamboo shoots. Because of malnutrition a child died. 'I became very depressed.'

Mee Reh's wife breastfeeds her underdeveloped child. His infant features sit uncomfortably on his baby-sized face. She describes the story of her cousin's family, also in hiding, camped on the riverbank. They were hit by a flash flood.

'All the children and Htoo La Paw were washed away, but two children were thrown to safety on the land. Htoo La Paw was badly injured. Later they found the elder girl under a log, her feet were sticking out from the freshly deposited sand and mud. They dug out her body, her head was crushed. The youngest daughter they found hanging in the bushes, dead, after the flood receded. They have been internally displaced people for five years, and want to come here. Everything they had was washed away, so they have no money to pay for a guide, or to be able to buy food on the way.'

Mee Reh's wife reflects on how lucky they are that her eldest child is attending school. The village school in Wha Lo was closed by the SPDC before the village was burnt down, and there are no schools in the jungle for those in hiding.

Villagers are forced to work without payment on government 'development projects' like building roads and barracks, farm clearance and cultivation.

Mary was only 19 years old. She had been forced to work for the soldiers 20 days per month, mainly in digging and building projects. She was terrified, particularly after two women in her village were raped by soldiers. They asked her father, an old man, to fetch bamboo and beat him with their gun butts. They had to leave him behind because he was too old and frail to walk. Mary was clearly depressed by her feelings of helplessness. 'I'm not happy here, but I feel better than in my village. Our life is just waiting and eating donated rice.'

For villagers asked to carry arms and supplies, it was a terrifying prospect. Tired porters are beaten or killed. Many of them never return. One escaped porter showed me the scars on his shoulders from the tremendous weight he was forced to carry. Porters are often marched in front of advancing battalions as human minesweepers. Gang rape of women porters is common.

Bor Reh was forced to be the village headman, as he was the only person who could speak Burmese, and so translate the labour demands of the SPDC to the locals. The village head was once a pres tigious post to hold, now it is a responsibility better avoided.

The SPDC's General Aung Gyi, head of Light Infantry Battalion Number 54 operating in this area, is infamous for his cruelty in punishing villagers, and for administering the punishments personally. Brutality against ethnic minorities is commonplace. Regular taxes, in the form of money and rice, are collected by SPDC troops, who also demand free food and alcohol when passing through the village. Curfews are often imposed.

Deforestation, initially from low-impact logging by the Karenni but now widescale by the SPDC, has led to decreasing rainfall, which also has had impacts on rice yields. All these compound major food shortages for even those who still have land.

Kyaw Te's trembling hands spoke of his life of fear in hiding. 'When we stayed there we were afraid all the time. The Burmese government, they want to destroy our people, to kill us all off.'

The refugee camp is an increasingly insecure haven. Thailand's attitude to the ethnic minorities is changeable. Previously considered as a necessary buffer zone between Thailand and its aggressive neighbour, Burma, the resistance forces and the asylum-seekers are now deemed a nuisance in the growing closeness between the two nations.

Hundreds of asylum-seekers have been forcibly repatriated, and new arrivals find it increasingly difficult to enter. Thailand and Burma have brokered a number of huge cross-border projects, fostering closer relations through economic ties. Two major gas pipeline projects, Yadana and Yetagun, including Total (France) and Premier Oil (Britain), are already complete and functional in an area south of Karenni State.

Their impact on the local area has been devastating. There are plans afoot to dam and divert the Salween river that flows through Karenni State, feeding it into Thai waterways and starving three million people in downstream Burma of water. Among them are the Karenni.

Last year I went to Burma to make a solidarity action for the many peoples of Burma. It was a simple act of defiance: to sing songs about democracy and freedom. The military response was rapid. I was arrested within 13 minutes.

Official statements from Myanmar regime

fields.headline: Heskey the hero
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 1 - 0 Leicester
Heskey puts one over his old club.
fields.body:
Fifa's World Fair Play Day was taken too literally by Leicester City as they presented their former team-mate Emile Heskey with a goal that keeps Liverpool, nominally, in contention for the Premiership title.

Having shaken hands and embraced Heskey in a stage-managed team presentation before the game, the spirit of giving continued throughout a match in which the £11 million striker should have repeated his hat-trick of last weekend. Fair play to them.

The fact that the goal came against the club Heskey left seven months ago and against Peter Taylor, a manager who appears to have every chance of being involved in the new England management structure, was an added bonus.

There should have been further goals, too. Twice after his 69th-minute opener he was played clean through, and twice Tim Flowers denied him. If Taylor is to become a coach under caretaker national manager Bobby Robson and eventual alleged permanent successor Sven Goran Eriksson, he will surely make a strong case for the employment of his club goalkeeper.

After a near-faultless display, it was ironic that Flowers was eventually thwarted by a team-mate's glaring error. Markus Babbel's deep, hanging cross was missed by def-ender Matt Elliott with Flowers out of position, allowing Heskey a simple conversion.

It was, however, an eye-catching, if flawed, performance by Heskey and his unaccustomed partner Robbie Fowler, making his first start of the season in the absence of injured Michael Owen.

'Emile is still young and far from the finished article,' said manager Gerard Houllier. 'There are quite a lot of things we still have to work on.

'But he has bedded into the team, he's got pace and power, and his reading of the game is improving. All he has to do is keep believing in himself. That's his biggest problem because I believe he can really achieve far more than he has.'

The same could be said of this Liverpool side who are slowly, but perceptibly, winning over doubters and looking like a team capable of breaking the monopoly Manchester United and Arsenal are beginning to share at the top of the Premiership.

It was put to Houllier that this was a game Liverpool would not have won 12 months ago, especially given a rousing Leicester finish in which they forced four corners in quick succession and defender Phil Gilchrist almost scored.

'Maybe with more experience we have in the team, we have more composure,' he replied. 'We don't panic and lose silly goals. So, yes, maybe we would have drawn or lost this game last year.'

But championship contenders? It would have been a sterner examination of that question if Gary Rowett had scored with a free header in the second minute, instead of heading it straight at Sander Westerveld.

As it was, a Leicester team who defended stoutly, and needed to, have clearly to find a successor for Heskey in attack, and the issue quickly boiled down to whether Liverpool would become the first team this season to score against City away from home.

Flowers was a pressured figure from the early moments, when he was forced to borrow a cap from a Leicester supporter because of the autumnal sun. He showed few effects from prolonged exposure to Liverpool attacks, making spectacular first-half saves from former Leicester favourites Gary McAllister and Heskey in quick succession, followed by tipping away thunderous efforts from Patrick Berger and Heskey, again. Fowler, also, was denied, this time by Rowett's outrageous goalline clearance.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk
