fields.headline: No, wait. It'll come to me
fields.standfirst: A revenge thriller about a man with amnesia rings all the right bells
fields.trailText: Philip French: The photography, editing and production design are of the first rank... and the performances have a strange intensity
fields.body:
Thirty-three years ago, after making his cinematic debut with a small-scale black-and-white movie in Britain, John Boorman went to the States and became a world figure overnight directing Lee Marvin in Point Blank, a very European treatment of an archetypal American subject.

The 29-year-old Christopher Nolan has done something similar. Last year he made an auspicious debut with the zero-budget Following, shot in black-and-white on London streets. He has now written and directed one of the year's most exciting pictures, Memento, which is, like Point Blank, a revenge thriller set in southern California that repays with interest its debts to Alain Resnais. Also like Point Blank, its progress is circular, ending where it begins.

The movie (based on a story by the director's brother, Jonathan Nolan), uses a favourite plot device of postwar Freudian film noir, the hero suffering from amnesia. Hitchcock's Spellbound is perhaps the most celebrated example. But Leonard Shelby (Guy Pearce), the protagonist of Memento, suffers from a special form of amnesia. Due to a blow received from the man who raped and murdered his wife, Leonard suffers from short-term memory loss. He can recall his life up to the murder, but thereafter he can't remember anything for more than a few minutes at best, though he's painfully aware of his condition.

As he pursues the killer he's reduced to making notes, annotating Polaroid pictures, having essential information tattooed on his body either by a professional in a tattoo parlour or with his own needle. He also has to depend on others, all unreliable - the devious desk clerk at a seedy motel, attractive barmaid Natalie (Carrie-Anne Moss), who may be using him for her own ends, the slimy, ubiquitous Teddy (Joe Pantoliano), who claims to be a solicitous cop but might well be a crook.

Like Following, the story is told out of sequence, with some scenes in monochrome, and at a hectic rate. This gets us involved by forcing us to exercise our own memories in reconstructing a chronological narrative. The scratches on Shelby's cheek - where did they come from? The bruises on Natalie's face - who gave them to her and when? As Leonard goes about his desperate quest around Los Angeles, we question our own perception of the world.

There is another layer to the story that relates to Leonard's earlier life as an ace insurance investigator in San Francisco, the same profession Edward G. Robinson followed in Double Indemnity. The job requires a combination of intuition and ratiocination, both underpinned by the necessity to be eternally mistrustful.

On Leonard's left hand is tattooed the admonition 'Remember Sammy Jankis'. Sammy, a certified public accountant (movingly played by Stephen Tobolowsky), was incapacitated by short-term memory loss after an accident. In order to frustrate his insurance claim, Leonard had to prove either that Sammy was bluffing or that his condition was psychological, not physical. The tragic destruction of Sammy and his wife, as narrated by Leonard, is a parallel story in a different register, which unfolds in sequence and makes Leonard believe that he's the victim of poetic justice.

The photography, editing and production design are of the first rank, belying the film's modest budget, and the performances have a strange intensity. Guy Pearce brings total conviction to Leonard, making an everyman of this bewildered questor. 'If you get your revenge, you're not going to be able to remember it,' Natalie tells him.

There is another layer to the story that relates to Leonard's earlier life as an ace insurance investigator in San Francisco, the same profession Edward G. Robinson followed in Double Indemnity. The job requires a combination of intuition and ratiocination, both underpinned by the necessity to be eternally mistrustful. On Leonard's left hand is tattooed the admonition 'Remember Sammy Jankis'. Sammy, a certified public accountant (movingly played by Stephen Tobolowsky), was incapacitated by short-term memory loss after an accident. In order to frustrate his insurance claim, Leonard had to prove either that Sammy was bluffing or that his condition was psychological, not physical. The tragic destruction of Sammy and his wife, as narrated by Leonard, is a parallel story in a different register, which unfolds in sequence and makes Leonard believe that he's the victim of poetic justice. The photography, editing and production design are of the first rank, belying the film's modest budget, and the performances have a strange intensity. Guy Pearce brings total conviction to Leonard, making an everyman of this bewildered questor. 'If you get your revenge, you're not going to be able to remember it,' Natalie tells him.

fields.headline: Gazza: There's life on Mars
fields.trailText:
Newcastle 0 - 1 Everton
Newcastle need Bobby Robson more than ever after Campbell's winner.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
Newcastle United will be even less inclined to let manager Bobby Robson become involved with England after this setback There is clearly still a lot of work to be done at St James' Park, where the last three league games have earned United a solitary point.

An 80th-minute goal from Kevin Campbell proved decisive and, inevitably on a day when there were reminders of Robson's international achievements, Paul Gascoigne played a significant part.

There were echoes of 1990 and all that in an instinctive backheel from Gazza, instigating the break which ended with Campbell turning in Alex Naysmith's low cross. Gascoigne's elaborate celebrations showed what it meant to him, and his reception at the final whistle showed what he still means to Newcastle fans.

Mars bars may have rained down on Gascoigne from the terraces when he last played a league game here, shortly after deserting them for Tottenham - but not this time. The supporters have clearly forgiven him and apparently suspected this might be the last opportunity to acknowledge one of their own in the Premiership.

Then again, perhaps it will not be his farewell. There is clearly reduced demand for Mars bars nowadays from the slimmed-down Geordie. And, while he - unlike Robson - surely can't ponder the possibility of an England recall at the age of 33, Gascoigne did exert considerable influence on a largely moribund affair.

He was part of a five-man midfield employed by Everton manager Walter Smith in the wake of six games without a win. Their objective was to stifle Newcastle, a task successfully accomplished apart from two Alan Shearer free-kicks which Paul Gerrard dealt with capably. Smith said: 'We stopped them passing the ball and Paul played his part. It's never easy to get a steady job from him - but we set him a task and he did it.'

Indeed, Smith's packed midfield - with Israeli international Idan Tal making an encouraging debut - also provided the solid base for breaks which produced openings for Alex Nyarko and Campbell.

Nyarko's 28th-minute effort was turned away by keeper Shay Given, while Campbell's glaring miss from Steve Watson's 59th-minute cross was accompanied by justifiable penalty claims.

Lomano Lua Lua's exciting mixture of pace and mobility was needed long before the Newcastle substitute made an appearance on the hour. The crowd's response indicated they already regard him a natural successor to Gallowgate entertainers such as Gascoigne - and he did produce several moments of trickery. But even he couldn't find a route past a sturdy defence and it was left to Campbell to have the final say.

With Robson having talks with his chairman, it was left to his No 2, Mick Wadsworth, to explain Newcastle's failure to maintain the fluency shown in Monday's classy win at Middlesbrough. He said: 'Everton set out to stifle the game. They saw Monday's game and only a fool would have let this be an open match. Walter Smith is no fool. It's true our home form is giving us concern but, compared to a year ago, the curve is still rising steadily.'

Everton were grateful for an overdue victory. 'We played consistently throughout the 90 minutes for the first time this season,' said Smith.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Derby bottom out
fields.trailText:
Tottenham 3 - 1 Derby
Jim Smith celebrates being 60 by plumbing record depths.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
The Derby manager, Jim Smith, found an unusual way of celebrating his 60th birthday last week, taking his squad on a paintball excursion as a bonding exercise. This week it will be back to drawing board and training ground in an attempt at some much-needed bonding on a football field.

If Smith gets the chance, that is. It is now 10 games without a win, the worst start to a season in Derby's 116-year history, and he is coming under increasing pressure. 'You always fear for your job in our position in the league,' he said afterwards. After fighting their way back into the game, his porous team again caved in to leave another under-siege manager grateful that they were this week's visitors to White Hart Lane.

Tottenham fans have been critical of George Graham over the past week - actually, make that the past year - after one point from four previous games. But yesterday he got in his retaliation, accusing them of undermining the team after Derby had equalised. 'I was very disappointed with the crowd,' said Graham. 'They never got behind the team when the boys needed them. There's a section - because we are under-achieving, and we accept that - who are quick to criticise. I don't mind taking it, but they should get behind the boys on the pitch.'

Perhaps they sensed it would be the same old story; Spurs flattering only to surrender dominance clumsily. Certainly their start fuelled expectation of a rout. For those who question Graham's ability to send out a side with lilywhite-remembered skills, here was a riposte.

A lead came after only three minutes. Darren Anderton took on Stephen Clemence's short corner but after being tackled by Craig Burley, no Derby player closed down Oyvind Leonhardsen and he drove home a powerful shot from more than 25 yards.

It should have been a prelude to a hatful. Somehow still in touch, though, Derby regrouped and Chris Riggott ran in unchallenged to glance home a header, fuelling the home mumblings again.

The game turned in added time at the end of the first half, however. Clemence, enjoying space in midfield, found Stephen Carr wide on the right and the full-back sent an arrow-straight shot just inside Mart Poom's right post.

Deflated, Derby conceded another within minutes of the restart. Riggott's header clear from Anderton's free-kick found only Clemence, who nodded it forward to Tim Sherwood. He neatly slipped in Leonhardsen for his second goal.

'There's enough there in midfield and attack to get results, but we've got to sort the defence out,' said Smith. 'We need to change the personnel in defensive areas, but we'll have to do some wheeling and dealing.'

In truth, the midfield were never strong enough or sufficiently manned, Smith playing three up front, and Spurs were allowed too much time and space to create and finish. Paintball? Derby would struggle with painting by numbers.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Robson: FA move fails
fields.trailText: Newcastle have rejected the FA's move to have Bobby Robson stand in as manager of England for the next seven games.
fields.body:
Bobby Robson is wanted by the Football Association to manage England for the next seven games - but Newcastle last night rejected the move.

The remarkable development emerged after specualtion yesterday that the FA wanted Robson and Leicester's young manager Peter Taylor to step ito the breach on a temporary basis. But Newcastle's expalanation suggested Robson is required on a much more long-term basis.. taking in all England's games up to the double World Cup clash with Germany and Albania next September.

If the Football Association now try again - on a more short-term basis - it is clear that both Robson and Tayulor will be keen to oblige.

Last night Newcastle initially refused to comment - saying there had been no approach for Robson. But after post-match talks between the manager and chairman Freddy Shepherd, a spokesman said: 'The Board of Newcastle United Football Club have been approached by the Football Association for the services of Bobby Robson on a part time basis for a total of seven games. The Board have unanimously rejected the Football Association's request for the release of Mr Robson. He has been informed and has accepted the Board's decision.'

Yet if the FA mofify their request, the proposed partners helped smooth the way for a successful outcome earlier yesterday.

Tabloid speculation yesterday suggested Newcastle's veteran boss Robson and up-and-coming Leicester manager Taylor were being lined up this week to guide England temporarily while Lancaster Gate set up a more permanent appointment.

Taylor even suggested his Leicester employers would welcome his involvement with the national side.

Robson, who has seen more than one national crisis in his long career, left the FA in no doubt that he will be interested in helping out - in the short-term. He is the popular choice as a stop-gap coach for next month's friendly against Italy, and he said earlier yesterday: 'I've always said that if the FA ask for any help - whether it's at that level or a bit less - then I would never let my country down.

'It's as simple as that. I would always try to help, but I've not been asked. So it's the same position and that's all it amounts to. It's happened to me several times before when things haven't gone right and they've changed the manager's job. They see me as a bit of a Steady Eddie who had the job for eight years.'

However, Robson has ruled himself out of the job on a permanent basis.

He insisted: 'The FA, if they pick the right guy, want somebody to try and get them into the World Cup. And I'm not the long-term view of an England manager, am I? I'm 67 years of age and I need to find, somewhere in my life, a bit of time for myself.'

Adam Crozier, the FA chief executive, had one opportunity to approach Newcastle about Robson's availability. Crozier chatted with Newcastle chairman Shepherd on Thursday but the subject was apparently not discussed.

The next generation's choice - Taylor - does not appear to have the same in-house concerns at his club. He repeated his offer to work in a part-time capacity in a new England management structure yesterday and revealed that his club, Leicester City, will comply with his wishes.

The Leicester manager, speaking after his team's 1-0 defeat at Liverpool, also stated that he has yet to receive any contact from the FA, official or otherwise.

He said: 'A couple of weeks ago I was asked if I'd be prepared to help on a part-time basis, and I said I definitely would. But I was very surprised this morning when the newspaper came under my hotel room door. It certainly woke me up.

'I have spoken to the chairman and told him if he was happy and it did not interfere with my job at Leicester City I would do it. If there was going to be an approach, I have no doubt he would see it as a very good thing for me and Leicester City.

'I would hope it would not cut across my job with Leicester. The last time we had international matches, we only had one day of training with the full squad anyway.'

And while the FA's stumblings still look cack-handed, their position is healthy compared with developments in Germany where, remarkably, their controversial coach-in-waiting was dropped like a hot brick yesterday by the national federation and fired by his club Bayer Leverkusen after a positive drug test that stunned almost everyone in German soccer.

Daum volunteered to take the hair test after allegations of drugs abuse and partying with prostitutes.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: From hero to villain
fields.standfirst: He was the darling of the Holte End but then Gareth Southgate asked to leave
fields.trailText: Gareth Southgate was the darling of the Holte End until he asked to leave. Ian Ridley hears him talk about frustration at Villa Park and a future away from it.
fields.body:
For someone who conducts himself with understated dignity on and off the field, Gareth Southgate has found himself at the centre of some clamourous, unseemly events these past few months.

It seems that in English football, some are born to controversy (Stan Collymore), some achieve it (Gilles Grimandi), while others, like Southgate, have it pinned on them. There was that comic cut on the Charleroi touchline, when Kevin Keegan tried to explain to Southgate that he wanted him to sit in front of the defence as a holding midfield player to stem the Romanian tide, a position he was also fatefully asked to fulfil against Germany a fortnight ago amid mumblings of discontent within the England squad. Another of his quietly efficient performances in his rightful defensive position ensued against Finland four days later.

It was followed by a majestic performance for Aston Villa against Arsenal at Highbury, all against a backdrop of discontent with a club he still wants to leave. But then, his professionalism produces a mix in him of not allowing his standards to drop as well as wanting to show the very best clubs what he is capable of. It is astonishing that none has yet seriously sought to sign him.

'I'm a bit up and down to be quite honest. Some days I'm very positive and giving it my best shot. Other days I get a bit cheesed off with it,' he says, referring to the twin facts that neither he, nor Villa, are moving along his own ambitious lines. 'I understand that I am going to be here for a little while but it's particularly difficult to stomach these weeks when everyone is playing Champions League games.'

Apart from a poor 45 minutes at Liverpool, Southgate has continued to perform with consistent excellence in Villa's defence and it will be another rare blip if he doesn't do so today against Sunderland. 'It's for my own self-respect really and the fact that I am here so I want it to be as good as possible. After the Liverpool game John Gregory and the coaches had some things to say to me in the dressing room and I probably wasn't as focused as I normally am. I was a bit down at the time.

'I knew that there would be questions about me right from our game early on against Chelsea and if I put a foot wrong fingers would be pointed. But I've played around 12 games now and I think I've proved myself.

'All along my aim has been to help Villa breach the gap and get in the top two or three. I would love nothing better than for that to happen because of the hard work I have put in here but at the moment we are still a fair way short. I wanted to be involved with England as well so I had to maintain my form for that but I also didn't want people to say I was not giving my all. I am a stronger person than that.'

Frustrated by Villa's inability to sign top players and join the elite of the Premiership, Southgate requested a transfer in May. Chelsea and Deportivo La Coruna showed interest but the £10 million price tag and the current transfer market uncertainty has cooled interest. Despite that, he remains outspoken about Villa's limitations.

'If you are detached from Villa, and it's probably the same for five or six clubs, you would say "yes, they are a top six side but nothing more is expected of them." When you are involved in it, you try to be as positive as possible and wave the flag but aiming for the title - which is what you have to do, because simply trying to get a Champions League place is a bit of a get-out now - is quite a way from our grasp.

'Signing a top-quality striker would go some way to achieving the goals we are capable of but, again, you have five or six clubs who are probably two players short,. The difference between us and the big boys was shown at Arsenal last week. They had four current internationals on the bench. We had four on the field.'

Given his stance, Southgate initially found it difficult to remain as captain. 'Because I am strong on principles and I thought it was hypocritical. But once we started playing, I was focused, as any athlete would be, and it's not caused me a problem. I realise players speaking out is frowned upon but I am not trying to undermine the club, just calling it as I see it. I would like to win some honours before I retire.

'There's almost a 50-50 split with the fans. A lot of people agree with what I say but naturally hard-and-fast Villa fans don't agree. In the main though, they can see the way I have been playing, the effort I put in, and they can't criticise me on that front.'

He also escaped criticism for England's defeat by Germany, that falling to Kevin Keegan for playing him out of position. 'Once he had named me there, a lot of people had written their post-mortems and I was expecting that myself. I knew it would be a surprise and people would wonder why Paul Ince or Dennis Wise weren't playing there. I desperately wanted it to work. Three years ago what was said on the Saturday morning would have been hard to take but I've been around long enough now. I just had to concentrate on the game.'

Was Keegan's resignation a shock later that day? 'The timing of it was. The way he spoke in the dressing room afterwards was very dignified and honourable. A lot of people have said that he jumped ship but if he felt he had gone as far as he could, it was better that he went before the Wednesday.

'It would be easy for me to criticise him because I wasn't a first-choice under him but I still believed we could have produced more as players, regardless of tactics and coaching.

'Kevin has spoken about his own shortcomings so that doesn't require comment from me.'

Southgate is also a voice of realism and restraint in the debate about Keegan's successor. 'If the right English person isn't available, or the FA don't want to appoint the right English person,' he says in veiled reference to Terry Venables, 'then I don't see why we shouldn't appoint a foreigner. Our island mentality has set us back decades, not just within football.

'We have a lot of talent though sometimes we overstate it and oversell ourselves. The Premiership is very exciting but we do go overboard at times. A lot of foreign players have enjoyed coming here because they wouldn't have been as successful in Italy or Spain. We can be a narrow-minded nation.'

Not the quietly controversial Gareth Southgate.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

I realise players speaking out is frowned upon but I am not trying to undermine the club, just calling it as I see it. I would like to win some honours before I retire. 'There's almost a 50-50 split with the fans. A lot of people agree with what I say but naturally hard-and-fast Villa fans don't agree. In the main though, they can see the way I have been playing, the effort I put in, and they can't criticise me on that front.' He also escaped criticism for England's defeat by Germany, that falling to Kevin Keegan for playing him out of position. 'Once he had named me there, a lot of people had written their post-mortems and I was expecting that myself. I knew it would be a surprise and people would wonder why Paul Ince or Dennis Wise weren't playing there. I desperately wanted it to work. Three years ago what was said on the Saturday morning would have been hard to take but I've been around long enough now. I just had to concentrate on the game.' Was Keegan's resignation a shock later that day? 'The timing of it was. The way he spoke in the dressing room afterwards was very dignified and honourable. A lot of people have said that he jumped ship but if he felt he had gone as far as he could, it was better that he went before the Wednesday. 'It would be easy for me to criticise him because I wasn't a first-choice under him but I still believed we could have produced more as players, regardless of tactics and coaching. 'Kevin has spoken about his own shortcomings so that doesn't require comment from me.' Southgate is also a voice of realism and restraint in the debate about Keegan's successor. 'If the right English person isn't available, or the FA don't want to appoint the right English person,' he says in veiled reference to Terry Venables, 'then I don't see why we shouldn't appoint a foreigner. Our island mentality has set us back decades, not just within football. 'We have a lot of talent though sometimes we overstate it and oversell ourselves. The Premiership is very exciting but we do go overboard at times. A lot of foreign players have enjoyed coming here because they wouldn't have been as successful in Italy or Spain. We can be a narrow-minded nation.' Not the quietly controversial Gareth Southgate.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Curtis Hanson: Success is better late  than never

fields.headline: Success is better late  than never
fields.standfirst: Before LA Confidential,  director Curtis Hanson was a Hollywood also-ran. His follow-up,  Wonder Boys, proves he's an A-list talent
fields.trailText: Before LA Confidential, director Curtis Hanson was a Hollywood also-ran. His follow-up, Wonder Boys, proves he's an A-list talent.
fields.body:
In Wonder Boys, Grady Tripp, the middle-aged novelist played by Michael Douglas, has got a problem. The inkwell of inspiration has run dry. He hasn't published anything in seven years since his last book, an acclaimed bestseller. There is an all too obvious comparison to be made with Curtis Hanson, the middle-aged director of Wonder Boys: the curse of the onerous follow-up.

Until the release of his last film Hanson was not a critics' darling, but a well-regarded journeyman, best known as the director-for-hire of hit thrillers, The Hand That Rocks The Cradle and The River Wild. Then in 1997, after 20 years of hurt and humbling experiences in Hollywood, he finally got to make the film he wanted. The result was L.A. Confidential, the glorious neo-noir thriller adapted from James Ellroy's labyrinthine novel. Conventional wisdom suggested it was too dense for the screen; not so, the tour-de-force was one of the shining films of the Nineties. Critics universally hailed it the best thriller since Chinatown, perhaps even better. Suddenly Hanson was on the A-list.

So how do you follow that up? Obviously the weight of expectation has not unduly burdened the shoulders of this slim, 55-year-old dressed head to toe in black. 'I had been in this business trying so hard for so long, rather than paralysis me with fear it did the opposite,' he explains in measured tones. 'It actually liberated me. I used that success to make the kind of movie I had always wanted to do before.'

His response, Wonder Boys, adapted from Michael Chabon's novel, is a work of obvious assurance. The pleasure is in the pacing and the details. It's an offbeat, languid and dark comedy set in a wintry Pittsburgh campus during a literary festival. Douglas is the slowly unravelling Tripp, an English professor and author of The Arsonist's Daughter, the literary sensation that sealed his reputation.

The movie follows him over the course of what turns out to be a lost weekend, starting inauspiciously for him when his wife walks out. Douglas heads the cast although this is an ensemble piece with a fine cast. Robert Downey Jr is Tripp's desperate agent, Tobey Maguire, the freakish, introverted star pupil, Frances McDormand, his mistress and Katie Holmes, his seductive student lodger.

The bizarre parade of events in Wonder Boys would make the plot read like a screwball comedy. Accidental shootings, illicit trysts and zany misunderstandings are de regueur. But it was the characters that attracted Hanson. 'Michael Chabon presents these characters to us in a completely non-judgemental way. I liked the fact that there was an absence of attitude from the storyteller's point of view.' Likewise with L.A. Confidential, which he does not consider to be a noir film, Hanson was really interested in the ambiguous cops. 'I wanted to tell the story of the case but what really interested me was the emotional life of the cops. I was intrigued by them the same way I was about Wonder Boys - the difference is here they made me laugh.'

Hanson sees himself as an actors' director. Working with them is his favourite part of the process. He persuaded Meryl Streep to get buff and ride the rapids in The River Wild. He later coaxed an unanticipated Oscar-winning performance from Kim Banister in L.A. Confidential. Simultaneously he persuaded Warner Bros. to hire two relative unknown Australian actors, Guy Pearce and Russell Crowe, for the leading roles.

It's a measure of Hanson's post- L.A. Confidential status that while the convincing executives to back the unconventional project proved tricky, the cast happily signed on. 'Actors don't necessarily care, thank God, how well certain things do at the box office. But they care how the performances look and after L.A. Confidential actors started to want to work with me,' he says. Douglas took a hefty paycut to play the pot-smoking campus romantic who grows steadily more tousled with each passing frame.

Seeing Michael Douglas flirt with Middle American mores is nothing new, but here he is stripped of his movie star sheen. But his apparent lack of vanity is appealing and why, one suspects, he leaped at the chance.

Wonder Boys wasn't a success with American audiences when released earlier this year. Despite strong reviews, the movie failed to open at the box-office and in an unusual move was swiftly pulled from all cinemas. The studio hadn't lost faith; this was damage limitation. It will get a second chance in the States next month in competition with the award season's other contenders.

The release and marketing cock-up clearly rankles. Hanson gives a detailed account of the dispute with the studio over selling Wonder Boys. It was, he concedes, a tough sell, but that's their job. The low point was the misleading poster; a profile shot of a smirking, self-satisfied Douglas that 'looked like he was trying to be Robin Williams'. He can't think of an adjective kind enough to describe the marketing campaign.

In 1993 when The Hand That Rock The Cradle, a low-budget, two-dimensional suspense emerged as an unexpected blockbuster he was entrusted to make L.A. Confidential. A couple of years after his 50th birthday, Hanson's serious directing career began. So what took him so long? 'I've always been interested in going my own way. It may not have appeared that way but I've always been picky in what I've done. That's why I haven't done more movies,' he says. (He has directed only 10) 'I did those that appealed to me the most.'

But surely there is a big difference between The Hand That Rocks The Cradle and L.A. Confidential? 'My last two films were labours of love in the sense that I had control from start to finish. There were still battles, but both times I won the important battles as opposed to losing them,' he says.

The son of Los Angeles schoolmaster, Hanson passed on the chance to attend film school with the Scorseses, Lucases and Spielbergs. His cinema education came while editing the influential journal, Cinema. Using his day job as cover he would ring his idols and request interviews and set visits from the likes of John Ford, Vincente Minnelli and Samuel Fuller.

Gradually he picked up screenwriting work. His first film, a superior B-movie called Sweet Kill, was made in 1972 but it was eight years before he completed his next feature. 'I know I took the long way round,' he laughs ruefully. 'But I kind of pursued two routes at the same time - writing and directing. It wasn't until The Bedroom Window in 1987 that I could persuade someone to let me do both together.' Along the way there were hiccups. Roman Polanski was set to film his script of White Dog hot off Chinatown. 'I thought 'fantastic' because I was a fan. Could it be this easy that I'm going to get to do this fantastic thing.' It wasn't. Charged with having sex with an underage girl, Polanski skipped bail and the country in 1978. Hanson eventually collaborated with his mentor, the irascible Fuller on the allegorical film in 1982.

So Hanson strikes a dissonant note. At a time when many of his peers have made their best movies, Hanson is in his prime, fusing a winning mix of studio gloss and indie sensibilities. The actors and critics like him, audiences are apparently divided.How long will Hollywood support him?

He is philosophical: 'I know the leverage I've got now is fleeting. You lose it as easily as you get it so I appreciate it. I look at it as 'okay, now I can do one more movie in the way that I want'. You know, I approach it all one at a time.'

Hanson's track record

The Hand That Rocks The Cradle (1992)
A prosperous suburban family face the ultimate nightmare: a duplicitous nanny worms her way into their home and affections with evil intent.

The River Wild (1994)
Meryl Streep turned action heroine in this tense drama about a family's rowing holiday ruined by the presence of a menacing stranger. Impressive set pieces on water.

L.A. Confidential (1997)
The stunning adaptation of James Ellroy's intricate police novel. A superior thriller that exposed the corruption and sleaze behind the myth of booming post-war Los Angeles.

 Wonder Boys opens on 3 November.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Pelé and Maradona get stuck in, England and the Berti factor, Lazio not racist but 'stupid', and Anelka pants - it's official. David Hills rounds it all up.
fields.body:
Pele gay slur: Maradona bites back

Just to balance today's front page story, here's Maradona - alleged spreader of 'worldwide Pele gay slurs' - proving his own heterosexuality with Claudio Caniggia in 1996. Afterwards, Caniggia's supermodel wife, Mariana Nannis, broke the pair up, banned all lip-kissing, and threatened to leave the country: 'At times I believe Diego is in love with my husband,' she said. 'It must be the long hair and big muscles.' The Caniggias are now happily settled in Dundee. Four thousand, four hundred and fifty-three miles away.

Mihajlovic, Lazio 'not racist'

A different perspective on last week's Lazio racism row came from Italian long jump idol Fiona May. May - a Fiorentina fan born in Britain to Jamaican parents - told the Italian press on Wednesday that the behaviour of Lazio's fans and of Yugoslav Sinisa Mihajlovic, who called Patrick Vieira a 'shitty black monkey', was simply 'antagonism' and 'stupidity' - 'not racism'.

'One sentence or a few chants at a football match are not examples of racism,' she explained. 'These were only gestures from people with brains like children. They need to mature and grow culturally but racism is another thing.' So Lazio - whose fans last season idolised Yugoslav warlord Arcan and Mussolini, waved fascist banners, linked coloured skin to Aids, chanted Nazi slogans and in 1996 desecrated Jewish tombs - aren't racist after all, just high-spirited. Mihajlovic agrees: 'I called him Vieira a black shit,' he admitted after the game, 'but my insult was certainly not racist.'

England job: FA getting Berti

News that Berti Vogts has been approached by an FA spook about the England job has got to be good: on paper he's the only man worth a look. Before Vogts jumped from the German job in 1998, the German press rated his unique coaching style as totally English. 'Vogts molests Germany with stinking soccer,' pointed out Bild . 'How much longer, how much longer will he stay?' 'He has us back in the Stone Age' said Sueddeutsche Zeitung . 'This insane coach has no support from his players,' wrote the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung . And, as, the Frankfurter Rundschau put it, 'Vogts is the symbol of the death of football.' When he finally did go, the press were devastated. 'Thank God. Vogts has finally done German soccer a good service,' said Bild . Added to this media savvy is a keen view on England's skilled youngsters: 'Joe Cole is good, but needs more meat,' and a fine line in self-serving drivel ('Kev-speak'): 'If I walked on water,' Vogts said recently, 'my accusers would say it's because I can't swim.' Unpopular, monolithic and irritating - is Berti coming home?

Anelka pants - it's official

Inspired by Tomas Brolin's online shoe and hoover business, Nicolas Anelka is about to launch a product range of his own - Nicolas Anelka pants. Announcing the plan on his official website ('I have some super news for you') Anelka revealed he'll be teaming up with a designer friend to produce the range. 'I don't know if you remember my buddy Harry Arcole the designer,' Anelka wrote, 'But he has just made me a line of undergarments, a complete collection called 'Nicolas Anelka'. Harry is a superb designer - these will be superb pants.' Anelka has promised pictures of the finished article on his website soon - multilingual surfers and perverts should click on www.nicolasanelka.net. 'When they arrive,' he adds, 'it will be time for a fashion parade.' Anelka's PSG teammates, no doubt, can't wait.

Win: new Championship Manager

It's back: the latest version of best-selling PC game Championship Manager is launched on Friday - we've 10 copies to give away. CM 00/01 now includes 75,000 players, managers and coaches, first team, reserve and international teams plus player power and probing journalists from the local and national press, including The Observer . To enter, answer the following question and book three weeks off work in case you win.

How many copies of Championship Manager have been sold since it's first appearance in 1992? a) 700,000 b) 1m c) 1.55m.

Write to CM00/01, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 5RS, or email sport@observer.co.uk.

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: A week's worth of tittle-tattle, just for you.
fields.body:
Leeds chase Zoran
Leeds hope to sign Dinamo Zagreb midfielder Zoran Pavolvic after chairman Peter Risdale promised to start spending: 'The money is always there - David O'Leary knows that.' The Pavlovic deal was suggested by Mark Viduka - according to Zagreb's Marijan Vlak 'there is a big possibility that he signs very soon'.

Boro: Baggio no go
Middlesbrough's attempts to land Parma star Dino Baggio have been hit by last-minute interest from Milan. 'Baggio has been requested by Middlesbrough,' says agent Angelo Cascelle, 'but would prefer to remain in Italy. But, of course, if the offer from the English club were to increase, this viewpoint may change.'

TV: Ferdi outrage
Tottenham's Les Ferdinand has admitted his part in the 17-year-old mystery of the vandalised Blue Peter garden. Ferdinand owned up to 'giving a few people a leg up over the wall', but wouldn't confirm or deny Dennis Wise's involvement. BBC bosses are now deciding whether to involve the police.

And the rest...

Edu's revived move to Arsenal has got the Brazilian excited: 'I always knew it would happen. I apologise for the embarassment I caused before, but now I cannot wait.' 3,000 web surfers, meanwhile, have signed an online petition to bring Kanu's parents to England.  Aston Villa boss John Gregory is ready to blow his Ugo Ehiogu money: 'The top Premiership clubs are always the ones who have spent the most money'.  Bradford winger Lee Sharpe is heading to Portsmouth for £500,000.  Charlton have pulled out of a deal for Bolton's Mark Fish, and Karim Bagheri is weighing up a Bundesliga offer.  Gustavo Poyet says Chelsea won't start winning until Claudio Ranieri learns to speak English: 'The sooner the better'. Ranieri plans to sell Gabriele Ambrosetti to Fiorentina.  Coventry's loan move for Blackburn keeper Alan Miller came after Manchester United's Mark Bosnich refused to join.  Derby could sell Dean Sturridge to Blackburn if Graeme Souness sells Matt Jansen to Fulham - a swap deal with Christian Dailly could be on the cards.  Everton are ready to release Mark Hughes to Cardiff.  Ipswich won't be signing £2m Cardiff striker Robert Earnshaw.  Leeds chairman Peter Risdale says David O'Leary can spend as much as he likes: 'So for all those fans craving a new face, at some point it will happen but we want the right people.'  Stan Collymore should leave Leicester within the next seven days.  Perugia are trying to sign Liverpool defender Rigobert Song on loan.  Man City's attempts to land Laurent Charvet are ongoing - Joe Royle says he's 'hopeful' of a deal this week.  Man Utd are ready to bid for Stuttgart defender Pablo Thiam.  Middlesbrough's efforts to carry on spending have stalled: Zvonimir Boban is unlikely to move this year.  Newcastle are back in for Honduran star Milton Reyes.  Matt Le Tissier could still quit Southampton: 'This is the best I've felt for a long time but they won't discuss a new contract.' Crystal Palace are still keen.  Sunderland have denied chasing Swedish U21 striker Fredrik Berglund: 'I have no interest in Berglund, I have never seen him play and I have no intention of bidding for him,' says Peter Reid.  Tottenham are continuing talks with Stephen Carr - Carr wants £16,000-a-week.  West Ham target Ragnvald Soma has joined Anderlecht on trial, and backup striker Omar Riza has gone to Barnet for a month.

I apologise for the embarassment I caused before, but now I cannot wait.' 3,000 web surfers, meanwhile, have signed an online petition to bring Kanu's parents to England.  Aston Villa boss John Gregory is ready to blow his Ugo Ehiogu money: 'The top Premiership clubs are always the ones who have spent the most money'.  Bradford winger Lee Sharpe is heading to Portsmouth for £500,000.  Charlton have pulled out of a deal for Bolton's Mark Fish, and Karim Bagheri is weighing up a Bundesliga offer.  Gustavo Poyet says Chelsea won't start winning until Claudio Ranieri learns to speak English: 'The sooner the better'. Ranieri plans to sell Gabriele Ambrosetti to Fiorentina.  Coventry's loan move for Blackburn keeper Alan Miller came after Manchester United's Mark Bosnich refused to join.  Derby could sell Dean Sturridge to Blackburn if Graeme Souness sells Matt Jansen to Fulham - a swap deal with Christian Dailly could be on the cards.  Everton are ready to release Mark Hughes to Cardiff.  Ipswich won't be signing £2m Cardiff striker Robert Earnshaw.  Leeds chairman Peter Risdale says David O'Leary can spend as much as he likes: 'So for all those fans craving a new face, at some point it will happen but we want the right people.'  Stan Collymore should leave Leicester within the next seven days.  Perugia are trying to sign Liverpool defender Rigobert Song on loan.  Man City's attempts to land Laurent Charvet are ongoing - Joe Royle says he's 'hopeful' of a deal this week.  Man Utd are ready to bid for Stuttgart defender Pablo Thiam.  Middlesbrough's efforts to carry on spending have stalled: Zvonimir Boban is unlikely to move this year.  Newcastle are back in for Honduran star Milton Reyes.  Matt Le Tissier could still quit Southampton: 'This is the best I've felt for a long time but they won't discuss a new contract.' Crystal Palace are still keen.  Sunderland have denied chasing Swedish U21 striker Fredrik Berglund: 'I have no interest in Berglund, I have never seen him play and I have no intention of bidding for him,' says Peter Reid.  Tottenham are continuing talks with Stephen Carr - Carr wants £16,000-a-week.  West Ham target Ragnvald Soma has joined Anderlecht on trial, and backup striker Omar Riza has gone to Barnet for a month.

fields.headline: Claudio is on a loser
fields.trailText: Premier League Motherwell mar Claudio Caniggia's Dens Park debut and Dunfermline hold Aberdeen to a draw while the Danish Lovenkrands brothers prepare to meet taday at St Johnstone.
fields.body:
The Claudio Caniggia show failed to produce the curtain calls anticipated as lowly Motherwell marred his Dens Park debut with a 2-1 win.

Motherwell signalled their intent as party-poopers early, with two goals in the opening five minutes from winger Stuart Elliott. Both goals were set up by Derek Adams.

Caniggia brought Dundee back into the game in superb fashion, but then showed himself to be human by missing a good chance to make it 2-2.

From a free-kick by manager Ivano Bonetti, the Argentinian headed over from just six yards out.

Aberdeen were held to a goalless draw by Dunfermline, while Kilmarnock came from behind to overcome St Mirren 2-1.

Kilmarnock always looked the better team, but had to wait until the second half for the goals from Andy McLaren and Alan Mahood that cancelled out Mark Yardley's opener and took them into third place.

The Lovenkrands brothers, Tommy and Peter, are hoping to come face to face in a competitive match for the first time in today's St Johnstone-Rangers clash.

Peter, the younger of the two Danes at 20, made his first appearance in Rangers' starting line-up in last Saturday's 1-0 defeat at Hibernian and kept his place for the goalless draw at home to Galatasaray in the Champions League on Tuesday.

Tommy, who had to be content with watching a video recording of the match because of St Johnstone's match against Celtic the same night, said: 'He did OK. It was a difficult game for him because he is so young.'

One common denominator between the brothers is that that they both have a lot of pace.

In Tommy's case, Peter says: 'He does have his ups and downs, but if he plays one of his good games, I think our defenders will have trouble catching him.'

webTitle: Pelé blames 'jealous' Maradona for gay slur

fields.headline: Pelé blames 'jealous' Maradona for gay slur
fields.trailText: Pelé has accused Maradona of spreading rumours that the Brazilian once had a homosexual affair with a coach, and blames jealousy for the washed-up star's actions.
fields.body:
Pelé blames Maradona for spreading worldwide rumours that the Brazilian had a homosexual affair with a coach - and claims the reason was jealousy.

The spat between the world's two most famous footballers emerges in a new book to be published next week in Britain.

Pelé and Maradona both have autobiographies released this month. In Pelé: His Life and Times the great man dismisses the story that he had confessed to a gay affair with one of the coaches in charge of young players at his Brazilian club, Santos. Pelé claims Maradona was jealous of his status - and that led to him starting the rumour last year.

Pelé, who co-operated with English author Harry Harris, chose to leave the detailed explanation to his close friend Celso Grellet. But Grellet's version of events has been read and authorised by Pelé.

Grellet insists Pelé thought hard about a response at the time but did not want a direct confrontation with Maradona, who had serious drugs-related heart problems earlier this year.

Grellet explained: 'One day I was very surprised to receive a number of calls from journalists for my com ment because Maradona had said that Pelé had had a homosexual experience. It was never true but Pelé is a big man and he decided that he would not respond and create a big battle between himself and Maradona.

'Pelé is heavily involved in the anti-drugs campaign, particularly the abuse of drugs in sport, and Maradona was clearly an ill man. Pelé felt it was best not to respond because no one could possibly take Maradona seriously. There is no doubt from my point of view that Maradona has made ludicrous accusations, the one about Pelé's sexuality being just one of many, as a result of pure envy.

'Maradona was very jealous of Pelé and has been ever since Carlos Menem, the for mer Argentine president, invited Pelé to the country as his special guest because Pelé was his favourite player. It angered Maradona that the Argentine people might place Pelé above him.

'Pelé has a lot of respect for Maradona as a player but felt that he media should not give any credence to the comments of an ill man. It would have been too easy to have said bad things about Maradona in return, but Pelé would not do it ... for me it was a very sad episode because I have always thought that Maradona was the best footballer in the world after Pelé.'

The Pelé biography, published by Robson Books, is available on the web through sportal.com, while the Maradona autobiography, I am Diego is serialised on umbro.com. In it, Maradona lists his 100 favourite players and accords Pelé number one status - but his appreciation is spiked with criticism :

'As a player he had it all but didn't make the most of it to raise the status of football. I'd have liked to see him put himself forward as president of an association to defend players' rights - like I did. I'd like to have seen him look after Garrincha and not let him die in misery. I'd like to see him fight the rich and powerful that are damaging football.'

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Hyde has Hornets creeping up
fields.trailText: Watford creep up the table, struggling Stockport come up trumps and Gillingham continue to hold their own.
fields.body:
While Fulham lost their 100 per cent record, after a goalless draw at Wolves, Watford crept to within two points of them at the top of the table with a 2-0 win at Nottingham Forest. Watford, having survived some early scares, seized the initiative through two strikes by Micah Hyde.

The most Dramatic First Division win of the day was that of struggling Stockport County at home to Bolton. Despite their crippling injury problems, Stockport seemed virtually certain of victory when they went 3-0 ahead. Bolton then made it 3-3, but were sunk by a last-minute goal from Aaran Wilbraham.

The programme enlivened by two other comebacks, with Portsmouth and Norwich recovering from two goals down to get maximum points at the expense of Crystal Palace and Sheffield United.

Palace, in control through two goals by Tommy Black, were sunk by replies from Steve Claridge, Thomas Thorgersen and Mike Panopoulos. Norwich got the better of Sheffield United with two goals in two minutes from Tony Cottee and Chris Llewellyn. In addition to their 4-2 defeat, United had Marcus Bent sent off.

Also shown the red card was Wimbledon's Chris Willmott, at Crewe. However, the Dons could afford to be a man light - they romped to a 4-0 victory; Jon Harley, on loan from Chelsea, with two of the goals.

If any team looked as if they might struggle to hold their own this season it was Gillingham. The fact that it has not yet worked out that way following the departure of Peter Taylor to Leicester has been due not so much to the work of his successor, Andy Hessenthaler, but the influence of Hessenthaler's backroom support duo of Richard Hills and Wayne Jones.

Hessenthaler, who is continuing as a player at the age of 35, admits that he would not have been able to combine the two jobs but for the help of Hills, Gillingham's assistant manager, and Jones, their first-team coach. 'The one drawback of being in my position is that you do not see the full picture in a match. This is where they take so much of the pressure off me.'

Hessenthaler admits that he might not have taken the plunge as early as he has but for the encouragement of Taylor. Previously Taylor's assistant, he recalls: 'When Peter left for Leicester, he was the one who urged me to have a crack at it. I wanted to play for as long as I could - I still do - but he felt that I could combine the two jobs.'

He and Taylor, of course, go back a long way. Taylor signed Hessenthaler for Dartford, when he was player-manager of the non-league club and they worked together when Taylor was assistant manager at Watford. After Hessenthaler had moved to Gillingham, he was instrumental in Taylor getting the opportunity to succeed Tony Pulis there last year.

Not surprisingly, Hessenthaler likes to think that what he has learned from Taylor is bound to stand him in good stead as a manager himself.

'The main thing about Peter is his honesty,' he says. 'I think that if you are up front and straightforward with them, they will always respond in a positive manner. I just try to be as honest with the players here as he was.'

fields.headline: Late ticket charges 'a rip-off'
fields.standfirst: Tour operators are being accused of 'ripping off' late-bookers by charging them to pick up their tickets from the airport.
fields.trailText: Tour operators are being accused of 'ripping off' late-bookers by charging them to pick up their tickets from the airport.
fields.body:
The practice of charging holidaymakers for issuing 'tickets on departure' on last-minute bookings has become widespread among the big tour operators in the last two years. Travel agents say charges of £10 per person on bookings made three weeks in advance are unjustifiable.

'They could just as easily put the tickets in the post to arrive the next day,' said travel agent Peter Hawke of Travel Experience in Kent. David Whitaker, manager of Andrews Worldchoice in Camberwell, London, said: 'It's just another way of ripping the public off.'

Often the extra charges do not appear in the initial quote for a holiday.

Airtours, which was the first operator to introduce these charges, levies £10 per customer for bookings made less than 21 days before departure. The operator says the charges cover the cost of staffing a ticket desk at airports and installing airport ticketing machines. A spokeswoman for Cosmos, the most recent tour operator to charge, said: 'People want to be able to book holidays and travel at the last minute and we have to cover the cost of investing in the technology to enable them to do that.'

fields.headline: Get a sleigh from it all
fields.standfirst: So what's it to be this year? A Christmas tree and a glass of sherry or a palm tree and a piña colada?  Sarah Vickery presents 15 top seasonal breaks
fields.trailText: So what's it to be this year? A Christmas tree and a glass of sherry or a palm tree and a piña colada? Sarah Vickery presents 15 top seasonal breaks.
fields.body:
1. Five-star luxury in Madeira

With temperatures in the high 60 Fs and a display of fairy lights that makes Regent Street look about as exciting as a 40-watt lightbulb, the Madeiran capital of Funchal has plenty to offer in December. Prestige Holidays (01425 480400) is promoting the five-star Cliff Bay Hotel, a 20-minute walk from the centre of town. The hotel features an indoor pool and spa facilities and offers 30 per cent off green fees at the Palheiro Golf Course. With departures available on 21 and 25 December there's also the chance to witness Madeira's lively New Year festivities. The price of £1,069 per person includes bed and breakfast, flights, transfers and a Gala Dinner on 24 or 31 December.

2. Disney magic in Paris

Recommended for hardcore Santa devotees of all ages, Disneyland Paris really lights up at Christmas. The park is open until 8pm every evening, and if the Electrical Parade and tree lighting ceremony fail to get you in the festive mood then you're a lost cause. Cresta Holidays (0870 1610 910) is offering three nights at the Hotel Santa Fe for two adults and two children under 12 for £726. The price includes breakfast, entrance to the park for the duration of your stay and a Dover-Calais crossing with Sea France on Christmas Eve. The same package based on Air France flights from Heathrow costs £1,142.

3. Cottage hideaway in Somerset

By the time Christmas Day finally heaves into view most of us are ready to get away from it all. Helpful Holidays (01647 433593) has the ideal retreat: a remote gamekeeper's cottage in Somerset, hidden among pine trees, nearly a mile from the nearest village, yet an easy walk to the pub. The cottage sleeps seven in four bedrooms and costs £316 for the week beginning 22 December. The company has more than 450 holiday homes for hire in the West Country.

4. Indian winter

If you'd rather be sitting under a palm tree than carrying home a fir tree then consider Goa. Located in the livelier north end of the resort, the Goan Heritage Hotel sits in gardens that lead down to the Calangute Beach. The property has a gym, beauty parlour, pool, restaurant and offers evening entertainment. Hayes and Jarvis (0870 89 89 890) has flights departing from Gatwick on 21 December. A seven-night break costs £689 including flights, transfers and bed and breakfast accommodation.

5. Meet Father Christmas in Lapland

Eclipse Holidays (0870 5010 203) is offering short active breaks to Lapland. The three-night stay features guaranteed Santa sightings, husky dog safaris, snowmobiling and reindeer sleigh rides, with optional extras including a night in an igloo hotel and skiing in Yllas. Flights depart from Manchester or Gatwick between 6 and 24 December and the package, which includes full-board accommodation and transfers, costs from £485 for adults and from £310 for children.

6. York country house retreat

Middlethorpe Hall (01904 641241), a country house hotel on the outskirts of York, is offering a traditional festive package. A three-night stay costs £595 per person, which includes a champagne and carols reception on Christmas Eve, early morning tea served with a present on Christmas Day, traditional lunch and a light tea. There's also the opportunity to attend the Christmas morning service in York Minster. Boxing Day dawns with a champagne brunch before a race day excursion to Wetherby.

7. Motoring in New Zealand

Swap grey skies and teeming high streets for sunshine and open roads; New Zealand will be at the height of its summer over the Christmas period. Austravel (0117 933 0450) has a 12-day package for people wanting to explore the North Island by motorhome. Also included in the price of £940 are scheduled flights and three nights' accommodation in Auckland, giving you time to explore the City of Sails before setting off around the North Island. Departures are between 12 and 24 December.

8. Short breaks in Istanbul

Legend has it that Father Christmas hailed from Turkey. He started life as a fourth-century bishop - later St Nicholas - who would give anonymous gifts to dowryless village girls. Sovereign Cities and Short Breaks (0870 576 8373) has availability on a range of short breaks to Istanbul. The four-star Hotel President, located in the rambling old town, costs from £419 per person from 15 December, based on bed and breakfast accommodation, flights from Heathrow and transfers.

9. Escape to Dubai

If you want to escape from tinsel and twinkly lights this year, then try Dubai - the Muslim state does not officially celebrate Christmas. Crystal Cities (0870 888 0022) has availability at the four-star City Centre Hotel, which features a rooftop pool, squash and tennis courts and is adjacent to the shopping mall if you want to treat yourself to a few Christmas presents. Departing between 25 and 31 December, the price of £615 per person includes flights from Gatwick and three nights' bed and breakfast accommodation.

10. Farm holiday in Cumbria

Enjoy the privacy of your own cottage with the luxury of having the cooking done for you. Stay on a Farm (0845 600 3201) offers a range of accommodation across the north of England, including seven cottages at Long Byres in Cumbria where the farmer provides a home-made meals service. This North Pen nines hill farm is ideal for walking and cycling excursions and is right next door to a birdwatching reserve. The cottages sleep from two to five people and prices start at £180 for the week beginning 22 December.

11. Christmas in Las Vegas

Known for its year-round glitziness, Las Vegas goes into overdrive at Christmas. Gamble away the Christmas Club money with a 14-night fly-drive Airtours holiday available from Travel Choice (0870 900 5833), departing from Gatwick on 12 December. Prices start at £679 per person and include four-star accommodation and a car.

12. Skiing in France

Get together a group of friends and head off for the slopes. The French resort of Serre Chevalier offers 250km of piste, with a good combination of blue and red runs that will keep most intermediate skiers happy. First Choice Ski (0870 754 3477) is promoting the four-star Chalet Asters, which sleeps up to 17 people and is located 400 metres from the ski lift. Seven nights cost £429 per person for half-board accommodation, based on two people sharing. If you can fill the chalet with friends you'll be rewarded with one free place. Flights depart Gatwick for Turin on 24 December and transfers are included.

13. Winter sun in Gambia

If you are looking for guaranteed winter sunshine without guaranteed jetlag then Gambia may fit the bill. The flight is six hours but no time zone changes mean that you can make the most of the 80 F temperatures from the moment you arrive. Direct Line Holidays (020 8239 3399) is offering two weeks at the two-star Hotel Badala Park for £629 per person on a bed-and-breakfast basis. Departure is on 15 December, from either Gatwick or Manchester, returning in time for the New Year celebrations.

14. South African adventure

Sample the best South Africa has to offer with a package from Tailormade Holidays (020 8398 4464). Start your holiday with two nights at the Sabi Sabi Private Game Reserve, where Land Rover and walking safaris provide an excellent chance of encountering the 'big five'. Move on to the Irene Country Lodge for a night then board the historic Blue Train to journey overnight from Pretoria to Cape Town before rounding off the trip with three nights at the five-star Htel Le Vendme in Cape Town. Prices start at £2,299 per person for departures on 22 December.

15. Everest trek

The idea of walking off the turkey dinner takes on a whole new dimension with Worldwide Journeys & Expeditions (020 7386 4646). The India specialist is organising a 12-day trek to Everest, following the expedition route up the Dudh Kosi Valley as far as the monasteries of Tyangboche and Pangboche. Christmas Day will be spent at Khunde, a Sherpa village with panoramic views of the south face of Everest. The 17-day expedition includes time in Kathmandu and leaves London on 17 December. The price of £1,525 per person includes flights, accommodation and meals.

A three-night stay costs £595 per person, which includes a champagne and carols reception on Christmas Eve, early morning tea served with a present on Christmas Day, traditional lunch and a light tea. There's also the opportunity to attend the Christmas morning service in York Minster. Boxing Day dawns with a champagne brunch before a race day excursion to Wetherby. 7. Motoring in New Zealand Swap grey skies and teeming high streets for sunshine and open roads; New Zealand will be at the height of its summer over the Christmas period. Austravel (0117 933 0450) has a 12-day package for people wanting to explore the North Island by motorhome. Also included in the price of £940 are scheduled flights and three nights' accommodation in Auckland, giving you time to explore the City of Sails before setting off around the North Island. Departures are between 12 and 24 December. 8. Short breaks in Istanbul Legend has it that Father Christmas hailed from Turkey. He started life as a fourth-century bishop - later St Nicholas - who would give anonymous gifts to dowryless village girls. Sovereign Cities and Short Breaks (0870 576 8373) has availability on a range of short breaks to Istanbul. The four-star Hotel President, located in the rambling old town, costs from £419 per person from 15 December, based on bed and breakfast accommodation, flights from Heathrow and transfers. 9. Escape to Dubai If you want to escape from tinsel and twinkly lights this year, then try Dubai - the Muslim state does not officially celebrate Christmas. Crystal Cities (0870 888 0022) has availability at the four-star City Centre Hotel, which features a rooftop pool, squash and tennis courts and is adjacent to the shopping mall if you want to treat yourself to a few Christmas presents. Departing between 25 and 31 December, the price of £615 per person includes flights from Gatwick and three nights' bed and breakfast accommodation. 10. Farm holiday in Cumbria Enjoy the privacy of your own cottage with the luxury of having the cooking done for you. Stay on a Farm (0845 600 3201) offers a range of accommodation across the north of England, including seven cottages at Long Byres in Cumbria where the farmer provides a home-made meals service. This North Pen nines hill farm is ideal for walking and cycling excursions and is right next door to a birdwatching reserve. The cottages sleep from two to five people and prices start at £180 for the week beginning 22 December. 11. Christmas in Las Vegas Known for its year-round glitziness, Las Vegas goes into overdrive at Christmas. Gamble away the Christmas Club money with a 14-night fly-drive Airtours holiday available from Travel Choice (0870 900 5833), departing from Gatwick on 12 December. Prices start at £679 per person and include four-star accommodation and a car. 12. Skiing in France Get together a group of friends and head off for the slopes. The French resort of Serre Chevalier offers 250km of piste, with a good combination of blue and red runs that will keep most intermediate skiers happy. First Choice Ski (0870 754 3477) is promoting the four-star Chalet Asters, which sleeps up to 17 people and is located 400 metres from the ski lift. Seven nights cost £429 per person for half-board accommodation, based on two people sharing. If you can fill the chalet with friends you'll be rewarded with one free place. Flights depart Gatwick for Turin on 24 December and transfers are included. 13. Winter sun in Gambia If you are looking for guaranteed winter sunshine without guaranteed jetlag then Gambia may fit the bill. The flight is six hours but no time zone changes mean that you can make the most of the 80 F temperatures from the moment you arrive. Direct Line Holidays (020 8239 3399) is offering two weeks at the two-star Hotel Badala Park for £629 per person on a bed-and-breakfast basis. Departure is on 15 December, from either Gatwick or Manchester, returning in time for the New Year celebrations. 14. South African adventure Sample the best South Africa has to offer with a package from Tailormade Holidays (020 8398 4464). Start your holiday with two nights at the Sabi Sabi Private Game Reserve, where Land Rover and walking safaris provide an excellent chance of encountering the 'big five'. Move on to the Irene Country Lodge for a night then board the historic Blue Train to journey overnight from Pretoria to Cape Town before rounding off the trip with three nights at the five-star Htel Le Vendme in Cape Town. Prices start at £2,299 per person for departures on 22 December. 15. Everest trek The idea of walking off the turkey dinner takes on a whole new dimension with Worldwide Journeys & Expeditions (020 7386 4646). The India specialist is organising a 12-day trek to Everest, following the expedition route up the Dudh Kosi Valley as far as the monasteries of Tyangboche and Pangboche. Christmas Day will be spent at Khunde, a Sherpa village with panoramic views of the south face of Everest. The 17-day expedition includes time in Kathmandu and leaves London on 17 December. The price of £1,525 per person includes flights, accommodation and meals.

fields.headline: It's all a blur...
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt  saw the birth of Reykjavik's rave scene 10 years ago. She returns to find its reputation for hard partying intact, visits Damon Albarn's bar - and warns you to remember your credit cards
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt saw the birth of Reykjavik's rave scene 10 years ago. She returns to find its reputation for hard partying intact, visits Damon Albarn's bar - and warns you to remember your credit cards.
fields.body:
It's four o'clock in Reykjavik's main shopping street, and the road is choked with a slow procession of cars, checking out the action on the crowded pavements. Iceland's young are out in force, parading up and down, colonising street corners in small groups, laughing, joking and admiring each others' new clothes. It's the same weekend scene you'll see on any main street in Europe's capital cities - except here, the shops have been closed for hours. It's four o'clock in the morning. And no one looks like they're ready to go home.

At first glance, Iceland is an unlikely destination for ravers. A country with a population of only 280,000 and a language that has barely changed since the sagas were written down in the thirteenth century, until recently its main attraction for tourists was its awesome landscape. When I first visited in 1990, beer had been legal for less than a year, all-night clubs were unheard of, and our party of 40 or so regulars from a Soho club called The Brain, there to enjoy a weekend's dancing in Reykjavik's now-defunct Moon Club, were considered a great novelty.

Those of us who'd come expecting an isolated, unsophisticated backwater were in for a surprise: the clubbers we met were mostly well-travelled, cool and cosmopolitan. But the real eye-opener was the crowd circulating in the streets outside on a Friday and Saturday night. A rowdy but good-looking mass drunkenly staggering round the city centre in search of fun, their energy, friendliness and lack of inhibition made for a memorable weekend. Except in the short summer months, Icelanders don't have a great deal of daylight, and so they make the most of every second of it. Their attitude to youth seems much the same: it doesn't last, so you should enjoy it to the full.

It's little wonder that revellers from other parts of Europe came to join in. In fact, Iceland has a long history of partying hard. Reykjavik's oldest surviving building at 10 Aoalstraeti was once occupied by Bishop Geir Vídalín (1761-1823), so famous for his hospitality that he once boasted: 'There are two places where the fires never die down - Hell and my house.'

Sadly, the cleric's life had other parallels with modern Iceland, where many live beyond their means and the biggest shopping day of the month is the day after the credit card bills are issued. The bishop's love of the good life led him to be declared bankrupt. (The house is now a restaurant although the stories surrounding it are more interesting than the building itself.)

There are a few rules to a night out in Reykjavik. First, dress up. This is a fashion-conscious city, and you're not going to get into many places unless you've made an effort - anoraks, cords and comfy jumpers just won't cut it. Second, take your credit cards or some serious cash: drinks are expensive. Mainly though, get used to being pushed around. If jostling were an Olympic sport, young Icelanders would come home bearing gold every time. They will lurch into you drunkenly, push past you to the bar or wherever else they want to go, dance on your table or on your feet without noticing.

Patiently waiting to get into Kaffibarinn, the funky, fashionable and over-crowded bar part-owned by Blur's Damon Albarn, we protested to the doorman about queue-jumping. 'Here, it is the survival of the fittest,' he shrugged, and didn't object when one of our party subsequently shouldered past him. All of this can be uncomfortable at first, but relax, learn to dodge and you'll see that the activity is usually boisterous rather than aggressive.

Our night started high up at Perlan (The Pearl), a spectacular glass dome built on top of a circle of shiny metal canisters storing some of the hot spring water that heats the city's homes and its seven outdoor swimming pools, leaving the airclear and unpolluted. Inside there's an artificial geyser that shoots up five storeys, a swish cocktail bar on the top floor, a revolving restaurant below it, and a café with an outdoor balcony below that. There's no better place to watch the sun set into the sea, after which lights come on all over the dome, and you're sitting under your own artificial stars.

There's no point in anything except a long, leisurely dinner afterwards. Alco hol is still prohibitively expensive, so most revellers enjoy a few drinks at home before going out, and the bars are dead until midnight. Indeed, with night action mainly limited to Friday and Saturday nights, most of them lead double lives: they are coffee houses and restaurants in the day, and on week nights the few that are open at all are often taken over for school dances.

After midnight, it's really a matter of personal choice: the bars are nearly all on or just off Austurstraeti and Laugavegur, and it's normal to move to several in the course of a night: just follow the crowds, look through windows or listen to the music coming out of the open doors until you find something you like. We passed establishments playing funk, hip hop, salsa, jazz, techno and reggae, places that looked small and cosy, an Irish bar, an English pub, designer hang-outs and others that were satisfyingly seedy.

We stopped several people in the street to ask for advice and directions, and though a few turned out to be too drunk to direct themselves, let alone a stranger, all were chatty, happy to help - and nearly all spoke excellent English.

After an expensive but memorable seafood dinner at the upmarket and ultracool Apótek (Austurstraeti 16), we continued our bar crawl at Skuggabarinn (Shadow Bar) in Hotel Borg in Pósthússtraeti (the best hotel to stay in if you're planning a night out since it's right in the middle of the action, but the worst venue you could choose at weekends if you were thinking of sleeping). Catering to a mainly older, but very chic crowd, it's a big, comfortable old place full of oil paintings, velvet drapes and gilt mirrors with MTV flickering in one bar, a small dancefloor where they are playing up-to-the-minute American R&B hits in another, and lots of cosy side rooms and alcoves with sofas and tables. Nearby Rex (9 Austurstraeti) is a modern bar/restaurant designed by Terence Conran catering to a similarly sophisticated crowd, most of them sitting at tables with an ice bucket of wine or champagne.

Ten minutes walk away, some drunken students at the small, crowded two-tier Vegamót (4 Vegamótastig) shouted into my ear over the vintage funk and soul soundtrack with their own bizarre theory about the older crowd at these two establishments. Everyone there must be gay, insisted my new friend. Why would any women over the age of 25 or men over 30 want to go out, unless they were unable to marry and settle down? One of them also claimed to feature in Dancer In The Dark , the film starring Björk which was advertised on posters all over town. He changed his story, however, on hearing I'd seen it, and loudly insisted instead that Björk was, in any case, overrated. Many of the crowd seemed to spend as much time hunched over their mobiles as they did drinking, frantically text-messaging friends in other bars or those outside on the street, unable to find a fake ID to say they were 20 and old enough to buy drinks.

After that, the night blurs. Kaffibarinn (1 Bergstadastraeti) was crowded but very cool, a two-storey house decorated with a huge London Tube symbol. Further back down the hill, Kaffi Thomsen (17 Hafnarstraeti) doesn't really warm up until 3am, when its cover charge goes up from 500 króna (£4) to 1,000 and the banging techno and house mix starts to fill up the rough wooden dancefloor. When I asked when it closed, replies were vague. 'Whenever,' said one. 'Or maybe never.'

By 4.30am, I'd had enough. Leaving most of our party waving their hands in the air like they just didn't care, two of us left for a delicious hotdog from the stalls near the shed-like Parliament Building, then took a slow walk back to our hotel. The air was crisp, clear and still, the night silent except for the hooting of swans on the lake by the ultra-modern City Hall. There are taxis everywhere, but few cities feel as safe to walk in at this time of night. Or as beautiful.

 Sheryl Garratt travelled as a guest of Icelandair (020 7874 1000) which has 12 flights a week from Heathrow and daily flights from Glasgow to Reykjavik. Fares start at £179.
