fields.headline: D.I.V.O.R.C.E
fields.standfirst: ...still spells a rotten deal for women
fields.trailText: You and your current life-partner may already have had a heated debate over whether our story on the financial impact of divorce can possibly be true.
fields.body:
You and your current life-partner may already have had a heated debate over whether our story on the financial impact of divorce can possibly be true. The respected Institute of Social and Economic Research found that men's fortunes improve (over time) by about 15 per cent following a failed marriage, while their former wives become 28 per cent poorer. 'Nonsense,' said the men in this office. 'Obvious,' said the women, demonstrating that subjectivity and certainty reign supreme in matters of Sex and Money.

But men should not be surprised. The disparity in post-divorce fortunes merely mirrors that in male and female earnings. Men's careers continue on an upward trajectory after a break-up. It is not so for women with children. Honest advice to young couples in the face of this evidence would be to encourage women to marry and hang on to their husbands, and men to stay single or get divorced. We do not expect to have a great impact, though: 75 per cent of divorces are initiated by women, 98 per cent of marriages by men.

fields.headline: Burma: From paradise to pariah
fields.trailText: Brief history
fields.body:
Brief history

1886: The country is colonised by British.

1948: Independence is followed by period of democracy.

1962: Prime Minister U Nu deposed in coup by General Ne Win. Repression and isolationism sends the 'rice bowl of Asia' into a period of sharp economic decline.

1988: State Law and Order Restoration Council (Slorc) seizes power. Changes country's name to Myanmar to reflect its rich mixture of ethnic groups. Change not generally recognised.

1990: Election called which National League for Democracy wins by a landslide. Military declares result void and reimposes repression.

Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, NLD founder and the daughter of assassinated independence hero Aung San, is held under house arrest for six years. Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, released in 1995, but her activities and freedom of movement are still heavily restricted.

People 67 ethnic groups, including the Burmese, mostly hill tribes in jungles and mountains. They include the Karen, the Shan, the Kachin, the Mon, the Akha, the Pulau, the Arakan and the Rohingya.

Internal and external links The junta is forming economic links with South-East Asian nations, who believe 'constructive' engagement is more effective than sanctions. Ceasefires have been signed with nine rebel groups. Karen guerrillas have virtually been wiped out.

Drugs Burma provides half the world's heroin and 60 per cent of the heroin that enters the United States. Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, has accused the junta of profiting from the drugs trade rather than trying to suppress it.

fields.headline: Master chef with a relish for spending
fields.standfirst: John Burton-Race tells Natalie Sutton how he mixes fast cars with haute cuisine
fields.trailText: John Burton-Race tells Natalie Sutton how he mixes fast cars with haute cuisine.
fields.body:
John Burton-Race, 43, is well known in epicurean circles as one of Britain's top Michelin-starred chefs. Egon Ronay, founder of the re-staurant guide, describes him as 'one of a handful of truly great chefs in this country' and Lenny Henry's character in Chef was based upon him. But are his fi-nances as beautifully plan-ned as his menus?

'I'm spend, spend, spend,' he admits. 'I spend 75 per cent on one credit card alone and that's American Ex-press. Paying it all off at the end of the month is essential for me because otherwise I would just keep on going.' John's wife, Kim, holds the purse strings in the Burton-Race household which, with six children, is a big responsibility. Burton-Race earns more than £100,000 but still feels he needs to boost his income with various consultancy jobs.

Earlier this year, he moved his famous restaurant at L'Ortolan in Shinfield, near Reading, to the Landmark, a London hotel. Financially, he says, the move was a nightmare. 'Everything was done in such a hurry with nothing but a wing and a prayer.' With 23 days to go be-fore he took control of the kitchen at the Landmark, the sale of L'Ortolan had failed to go through after several abortive efforts. 'I had to get a bridging loan and put my house in Chiswick on the market. I have to say my branch manager at Barclays was absolutely brilliant. In the end we decided to sell the Chiswick house and move the family out to L'Ortolan. It's a big place but with six kids, we need the space and it's just perfect.

'Everything seems to have worked out for the best. But it hasn't always been this way. My first salary as an apprentice chef was £9 a week and I had to spend £4.50 a week on travelling to and from work. It's five or six years before a chef starts seeing any real financial reward, rather like a young doctor or a vet. Rents, particularly in London, are absolutely crippling. I pay my young lads around £17,000 but from that they need to buy their uniform, their knives and pay their rent.'

Now he pays about £950,000 a year in wages to his team of 41 based at John Burton-Race at the Landmark. It's probably one reason for the restaurant's prices being about as 'haute' as cuisine can go. There is a set-price lunch for £28, set dinner for £45 and a menu gourmand for £160 for two without wine. The restaurant will eventually become his flagship as he also has plans for two or three sim pler brasserie-style venues around London.

This winner of various stars and awards also has a penchant for fast cars. He sheepishly admits that commuting between home and work is something he enjoys. 'It's not so bad in a Porsche,' he says.

His major expenditure apart from the Porsche? 'My kids would represent 60 per cent on a graph of outgoings. I like taking the children on one nice holiday abroad a year. My wife probably spends 35 per cent, which leaves 5 per cent for me.' And the Porsche presumably.'We love eating out. Going to the Gavroche is something which Kim and I enjoy often.'

And does he miss the re-staurant at L'Ortolan? 'It's harder here because it's just beginning,' he says. 'August was a bit iffy but then August is always a bit iffy in London. It's generally much more exciting, more of a gamble.'

webTitle: Marriage of fashion and art on rocks

fields.headline: Marriage of fashion and art on rocks
fields.standfirst: The scent of couture's cold cash leaves the purists feeling that they have sold their soul
fields.trailText: The designer Giorgio Armani is at the centre of a row convulsing New York about whether art, which increasingly seems to resemble showbiz, has made a Faustian pact with fashion and the dollar.
fields.body:
The designer Giorgio Armani is at the centre of a row convulsing New York about whether art, which increasingly seems to resemble showbiz, has made a Faustian pact with fashion and the dollar.

When Armani swept into the Guggenheim Museum for a star-studded soirée to celebrate a major retrospective of his career last week, the scent of insurrection was in the air. Amid the accolades and air-kisses, Armani - who described the event as 'the crowning moment of my life in fashion' - might have felt surprised that anyone could question the inclusion of his clothes in the same building as modern master painters.

'Fashion is at the heart of human expression and is a mirror that reflects society and its culture', Armani, designer of the Eighties power suit, said, flanked by Hollywood stars like Robert De Niro, Michelle Pfeiffer, Lauren Bacall and Richard Gere. 'It's a great honour to know that my designs stand alongside the work of some of the most influential artists of the twentieth century.'

But some art critics charge that the custodians of art have been blinded by the glitz of fashion. 'These are very cynical decisions,' says New York art critic Hilton Kramer. 'Frankly, I don't know of any serious art critic, art historian or artist - or serious art collector, even those collectors that wear those clothes - who regard Armani's suits as works of art.'

Fashion exhibitions have almost turned Manhattan's museums into catwalk shows. French designer Azzedine Alaia has a major exhibition of his flirty designs, there are any number of fashion photography exhibits in art galleries and an exhibition for the Japanese cosmetics giant Shiseido at a gallery owned by New York University.

Next year the Metropolitan Museum of Art will mount 'Jacqueline Kennedy, the White House Years' featuring the first lady's wardrobe (except, of course, her most famous outfit: the pink Chanel outfit she wore on 22 November, 1963). The art world's discomfort lies in the fear that it will be exposed for having prostituted itself. 'Fashion wants the legitimacy and authority of art. It's looking for absolution from transience,' says New York curator Neville Wakefield. In exchange, he says, 'the art world wants fabulousness, and better parties'.

But it is the scent of cold cash that has most upset art critics. A month after the Armani exhibition was announced, the Guggenheim revealed the designer was making a three-year, $15 million donation to the museum. 'It's creating the impression that the museum is for sale, and that if you have enough money and if you're an important enough company, you can buy the museum to promote your product,' says Kramer.

Neither is the fashion world wholly in favour of a marriage with art. Last May, the Metropolitan cancelled a Coco Chanel retrospective after a spat between Chanel designer Karl Lagerfeld and the museum over creative control of the exhibition.

In a review of Armani's show, Herbert Muschamp, art critic for the New York Times , wrote that he had no objection to fashion-as-art: 'Historical amnesia, intellectual pretension, cronyism, promotion, delusion, sycophancy, bribery, betrayal ... these are some of the lubricants that make the wheels of fashion turn.'

But, he added, 'If you enjoy the fashion spectacle, you wouldn't want to miss one treacherous moment.' He might have added that these values also hold true in the art world.

webTitle: Money writes: Lost holiday a pet peeve

fields.headline: Lost holiday a pet peeve
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
In July we cancelled a holiday at short notice as our dog, a nine-year-old boxer bitch, had an initial diagnosis of bone cancer. A confirmatory biopsy was urgently required before proceeding with any treatment.

I was resigned to losing the cost of the holiday but noted that our dog insurance covered holiday cancellation due to emergency life-threatening operations.

However, my claim to Equine & Livestock Insurance was rejected because a biopsy was not considered to be life-threatening. I countered that the operation was life-saving and a biopsy is always required before major surgery. The unrecoverable costs being claimed were £845.
DR, Weymouth

Equine & Livestock is sticking to the letter of its policy, which confines payment to limited dates and narrow circumstances. The company says holiday cancellation is a small part of the policy: it receives just a small proportion of the premium so the cover is restricted.

Policies pay only if you have to cancel a holiday because a pet has emergency surgery within 14 days of departure and you must inform the company immediately an illness is discovered.

Equine & Livestock says you should have told them on 20 June, the day you first took your dog to the vet or, at the latest 6 July, when she had the X-rays and not, as you did, on 1 August, which was the day after the biopsy results confirmed bone cancer. But, even if you had rushed to the insurer immediately you knew your dog was seriously ill, you still could not have met the conditions.

The biopsy results came through on 31 July, the day after you should have left on holiday. The vet recommended amputation in the hope of saving your dog's life but obviously this could not have been done within 14 days of your planned departure.

The insurer refuses to accept a biopsy as a qualifying operation. If your dog's illness had become apparent just one week earlier, and she had had the operation between 16 and 30 July, you could have claimed £845.

Education in the cost of college

We are surprised at the amount we are being asked to contribute to our son's university costs - £1,050 tuition fees and £6,175 to living expenses. On top of that, we have had to buy him cutlery, crockery and a kettle and he still has to pay for food, clothes, books and entertainment.

Not wishing to disadvantage him financially, we have arranged monthly payments to cover these amounts but we have read about the expensive cost of studying in London at only a fraction of what we are paying. Are we paying too much?
CP, Kibworth

You have misread the assessment form. The 'total assessed contribution' of £6,175 is based on your income and is a theoretical figure, which is causing a lot of confusion.

The maximum any parent has to pay for tuition fees is £1,050. Parents on comparatively high income also pay £930 towards living costs but you are not asked to hand the money over. Instead it reduces the size of student loan available to your son, leaving him able to borrow £2,795, which is 75 per cent of the loan. The maximum contribution of £1,980 (£1,050 plus £930) is reduced by £77 for each dependent child you have.

You can of course continue to pay him £6,175 in monthly instalments, but you do not have to.

Mastering the pensions game

My niece, 28, is leaving her job and returning to university for a year to pursue a master's degree. She had been contributing to an occupational pension for three years and wonders what to do with it as she is unlikely to return to the same employer.
IC, London

She can leave it where it is, transfer to a personal pension or transfer to a new employer's scheme.

A final salary scheme is probably best left because the benefits are guaranteed. If it is money purchase she should ask where it is invested and whether she can switch between various funds.

At her age, she can afford to take risk and could put some in, say, a technology fund.

If she is unhappy with the existing pension provider, the choice of funds or their performance, she can switch to a personal pension.

Paying the price for power failure

Through my local water company, I have been getting electricity from Independent Energy. There have been numerous problems. The most recent was a cheque from from the company for £20 which bounced. I gather it is now in receivership. Can you investigate?
KD, Cambridge

Receivers appointed on 8 September sold Independent Energy's assets to Npower. But the problem of Independent Energy's debts, including bounced cheques, is with the receiver and you should write to KPMG, 20 Farringdon Street, London EC4A 4PP to lodge a claim, although realistically you are unlikely to get your money back.

If the £20 was a refund for an overpayment by direct debit, you can claim against your bank under the direct debit indemnity scheme.

Endowment conundrum

Last year I needed to cash in an endowment policy to use as a deposit on a new home but the house purchase fell through. The surrender value was £4,750.

In May, we considered selling again and the surrender value was £4,922. In June we were told that the endowment would fall short of our home loan so we decided definitely to get rid of it as it was not needed for the mortgage.

But now no auction house wants to sell it, despite their willingness last year, because the surrender value is 'too generous'. The surrender value has fallen to £4,635.
DO'N, Radcliffe on Trent

The market in selling second-hand life insurance policies relies on investors paying more than the surrender value of a policy, after taking an intermediary's charges into account.

When surrender values fall, investors obviously want to pay less and, particularly with small policies like yours, there is little margin left for profit.

The number of policies up for sale also affects prices. More have come on to the market recently as homeowners lose confidence in endowments that might not repay their mortgages and this too has depressed prices.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Less is more | To your health | Egg the pudding
fields.body:
Less is more
A new logo will help you recognise the most energy-efficient domestic appliances on the market. Washing machines, fridges, freezers, dishwashers and lightbulbs that make the grade will all carry the orange and blue Energy Efficiency Recommended logo. It is being launched to kick off energy efficiency week tomorrow, which aims to raise awareness of the importance of energy efficiency in reducing climate change.It is the brainchild of the Energy Saving Trust, a government body set up to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

To your health
If you don't want to wait for medical treatment on the NHS, Health Care Navigator will help you weigh up the private healthcare options. Health Care Navigator is a database which informs you of where treatment is available for any ailment, and how much it costs. It draws on more than 300 private hospitals nationwide as well as on NHS private pay units. The service costs £60 for each household for one year's subscription. Application forms are available on 0870 727 0140.

Egg the pudding
Egg, Prudential's internet banking arm, is offering new credit card customers 0 per cent APR for the first six months. But if you are transferring a balance from an existing credit card the APR is 2.5 per cent. After six months all cards revert to Egg's standard rate, currently 11.9 per cent. The new rates are available until 31 December 2000. The Egg card has no annual fee, and customers receive 2 per cent cashback on all purchases in the Egg shop which gives access to over 150 retailers . All other purchases receive 1 per cent cashback. Egg can be reached at www.egg.com.

Join the club
Online broker iDealing.com is launching an investment club service which it says is the cheapest in the market. Investment clubs are groups of up to 20 people who combine funds to invest in shares online. For a charge of £10 per deal plus £5 annual management fee, iDealing will administer the club and analyse the portfolio's performance. The minimum investment is £500 per club. The service can be found at www.iDealing.com.

Getting personal
Teachers looking for resources with which to teach personal finance can find them on the website of the charity Personal Finance Education Group. The website, at www.pfeg.org, contains a directory of resources classified according to the age and key stage of the children. Some of the resources are free. There is also a selection of case studies for classroom use. Personal finance became part of the school curriculum for the first time this September under personal, social and health education.

See the future
You will soon be able to see how much income you can expect in retirement with a pension statement from the Government. These estimate an individual's income in retirement by combining their state and private pension provision for the first time. They also show how the income can be boosted. The statements will be available to everyone from next October. They are being piloted with several companies, including Sainsbury's and Prudential. The Government intends 15 million people to receive them by 2005 in a bid to drive home the need to save for retirement.

Balance of risk
Confused about the best type of credit card for your circumstances? An index from GM Card compiled with research by Steve Worthington, professor of financial services at Staffordshire University, shows that the the best bet at present for people who never pay off their balance is the Sainsbury's Bank card, while those who pay their bills in full each month should go for NatWest Bank's card. Those who sometimes clear their balances should go for the Tesco card.

Code to speed up claims
A new code outlines the speed with which you can expect an insurer to deal with your general insurance claim. The Association of British Insurers' claims code, due out in mid-November, will require companies to acknowledge the claim within five days and send out a cheque within 10 days of you agreeing to the settlement. The compulsory code also requires companies to keep you informed of any delays. A range of general insurance policies comes under the code including household, motor, pet, travel, mortgage protection and private medical insurance. The code is part of the ABI's drive to raise standards across the industry. ABI says the best performing companies have been used as a benchmark. Royal & Sun Alliance, Norwich Union, CGU and Direct Line are big players in the general insurance sector.

webTitle: Scorsese tells Leo: 'Life's not a beach'

fields.headline: Scorsese tells Leo: 'Life's not a beach'
fields.trailText: It was not the showdown scriptwriters had in mind. Leonardo DiCaprio was supposed to fight knife-wielding thugs, not a raging Martin Scorsese.
fields.body:
It was not the showdown scriptwriters had in mind. Leonardo DiCaprio was supposed to fight knife-wielding thugs, not a raging Martin Scorsese.

But when two of Hollywood's powerful men clashed on the set of their latest film, the cast knew what to blame: Rome.

For Scorsese, The Gangs of New York is one of the biggest blockbusters that he has ever directed, an $80 million gamble to show he can make a box-office hit.

For DiCaprio, it is a chance to regain the worldwide acclaim - and lust - that has ebbed since Titanic . It is also a chance for Rome's fabled Cinecittà studios to recapture the magic of its golden age, when stars flocked to its giant sets to make epics such as Ben-Hur and Cleopatra .

Producers overlooked the lure of la dolce vita. Not the film, the reality, for Rome is indeed the sweet life and DiCaprio has been partying hard, too hard. With his Brazilian model girlfriend, Gisele Bundchen, he has been hitting one nightclub after the other with the paparazzi in pursuit.

Shambling bleary-eyed from his Hilton hotel suite into a limousine, he has been chronically late for morning shoots. The schedule slipped and Scorsese flipped.

DiCaprio arrived on set last week to a public roasting in front of cast and extras. The director of Raging Bull, Taxi Driver and Goodfellas let loose a 10-minute tirade that left his leading man speechless. An Italian extra, who plays a rival gang member, said: 'I couldn't understand it all because he was speaking so fast, but he was very angry. We didn't know where to look.'

Since then DiCaprio has been punctual and large set-pieces are scheduled to begin shooting tomorrow. Set in the Bronx slums in the 1850s, the film tells the story of rival Irish, Italian and Chinese immigrants fighting for control during Tammany Hall's political corruption. As violence escalates, DiCaprio, playing a gang leader, Amsterdam, becomes entangled with a thief, played by Cameron Diaz.

DiCaprio's lifestyle echoes the stars of the Fifties and Sixties, who made Hollywood on the Tiber a byword for glamour and hedonism. While Federico Fellini's La Dolce Vita immortalised Marcello Mastroianni and Anita Ekberg frolicking in the Trevi Fountain, celebrities partied on Via Veneto.

Bosses at Cinecittà hope Gangs will inject cash and confidence into an ailing Italian film industry. Conceived by dictator Benito Mussolini as a vehicle for Fascist propaganda, the 600-acre studios nurtured directors and producers such as Fellini, Pier Paolo Pasolini, Carlo Ponti and Dino De Laurentiis. Cinecittà was reborn post-war as the cradle of Europe's best talent and hosted classics such as War And Peace, Spartacus, Quo Vadis? and A Farewell To Arms, as well as spaghetti Westerns.

The privatisation of Cine-città and the amending of tax laws have coincided with Hollywood's quest for cheap foreign locations. 'Italian film-making is beginning to pick up. This has come at just the right time,' said Tony Villani, film professor at the American University of Rome.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ebola death toll reaches 47
fields.body:
Ebola death toll reaches 47

A team of health experts are working to isolate an outbreak of the lethal Ebola virus in northern Uganda as the death toll increased to 47. Six more people died from the virus in the northern district of Gulu. The number of cases reported so far stands at 122.

Death for Chinese abductors

A court in eastern China sentenced to death four leaders of a gang which abducted, raped and then sold poor rural women as brides in the city of Suqian. Two others were given death sentences, suspended for two years, and 12 others were jailed.

Wolf killer is jailed

A man was sentenced to four months in prison and six under house arrest for shooting a grey wolf in Catron County, New Mexico.

Police shooting

An undercover policeman in Brooklyn shot dead a man who tried to rob him of heroin he had just bought from a street vendor.

Divers cut into Kursk hull

Russian and Norwegian divers yesterday entered the waters where the Kursk nuclear submarine sank after an explosion in August and began cutting into the hull. They hope to recover the bodies of the 118 crewmen who died inside the Russian vessel.

Turks cooped up for census

Turkey's streets will be deserted today, under a curfew to allow officials to conduct a door-to-door census. Many are outraged at being forced indoors for an entire day and blame the government for failing to fulfil its promise to carry out the census electronically.

Colombian rebels kill 71

Colombian government forces lost 52 soldiers and 19 policemen killed in three days of fierce fighting against the rebel Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc). Rebels shot down a helicopter, underlining their growing military power and the government's tenuous control over much of the Colombian countryside.

Basque bomb in French town

A bomb exploded in the French town of Cambo-les-Bains, near the Spanish border. Police blamed Basque separatists who want a homeland comprising parts of both countries. No one was injured.

Mexican mafia manhunt

Mexico City police ordered the arrest of an alleged mafia leader, owner of a popular nightclub which burnt down, killing 40 people.

Casino probe

British Columbia's former Premier, Glen Clark, has been charged with fraud over casino licence allegations.

Carter protest

Ex-President Jimmy Carter has left the Southern Baptist Church because it won't allow women to become pastors.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: If you get an email telling you how to earn $50,000 or more in 90 days, you would be right to be wary.
fields.body:
If you get an email telling you how to earn $50,000 or more in 90 days, you would be right to be wary.You will be entering into a modern day pyramid-selling scheme over the internet, or what the anonymous US mailers behind the scheme call the 'multi-level email order marketing programme'.

The scheme works by a process of downline selling. First, you have to stump up $25 in cash for five reports on various aspects of online marketing such as The Insider's Guide to Sending Bulk Email on the Internet . Then you have to email a certain number of people advertising the reports, the idea being that some will reply and pay you $5 for a copy of one of the reports. You are also invited to make money by introducing people to the pyramid. The mailers claim you can rake in 'hundreds of thousands of dollars'.

The claims are backed up by personal testimony of how your initial $25 investment can roll up for 'only one or two hours work a day'.

But the Department of Trade and Industry warns people to think carefully before joining. A spokesman says the majority only make money for the people behind the schemes, although some are legitimate.

Regulations from the Office of Fair Trading mean it is a criminal offence for schemes to make money solely from other people joining - they must offer some product or service. The DTI spokesman says: 'It depends how the scheme is marketed. This one sounds like it does not fall foul of the regulations because it is offering a product.' But he says it is wise to be cautious if the scheme is based overseas. 'If a scheme based overseas falls foul of the regulations, strictly speaking they are outside our remit.'

There is a trading schemes' guide on the DTI website which can be found at www2.dti.gov.uk.

 Seen a mailshot or advertisement that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

The claims are backed up by personal testimony of how your initial $25 investment can roll up for 'only one or two hours work a day'. But the Department of Trade and Industry warns people to think carefully before joining. A spokesman says the majority only make money for the people behind the schemes, although some are legitimate. Regulations from the Office of Fair Trading mean it is a criminal offence for schemes to make money solely from other people joining - they must offer some product or service. The DTI spokesman says: 'It depends how the scheme is marketed. This one sounds like it does not fall foul of the regulations because it is offering a product.' But he says it is wise to be cautious if the scheme is based overseas. 'If a scheme based overseas falls foul of the regulations, strictly speaking they are outside our remit.' There is a trading schemes' guide on the DTI website which can be found at www2.dti.gov.uk.  Seen a mailshot or advertisement that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

fields.headline: How the peace was wrecked
fields.standfirst:
View from the front line: John Sweeney reports from Nablus on a battle which began with Jewish settlers trying to visit a shrine and ended with Israeli helicopter gunships blowing apart homes

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: I watched the life drain from a young man who had been shot in the face by the Israeli Defence Force: his skin colour fading to ash while frantic paramedics fought without hope under a darkening sky.
fields.body:
I watched the life drain from a young man who had been shot in the face by the Israeli Defence Force: his skin colour fading to ash while frantic paramedics fought without hope under a darkening sky.

A swirl of onlookers surged towards the open-air first aid station, a few hundred yards back from the battle of Nablus: the stink of burning tyres, the sky racked with gunshots cracking out, a whoop-whoop of sirens, groans of the wounded and the dying, screams of angry men, fizzing with fear, grief, helplessness, rage.

It was the 48th hour of the 48-hour deadline for peace to break out as set down at the Sharm el-Sheikh summit and a terrible paroxysm of anger was surging through the crowd. A youngster, no more than 12 years old, hammered a red-bereted Palestinian soldier carrying a Kalashnikov. He wanted the gun so he could avenge the dead - and the soldier backed away, terrified of the lad, of the vortex of emotion circling around him.

Then the crowd surged towards the first aid station, some men in their rage fighting the paramedics maintaining a ring around the man with the hole in his face.

I was standing on the balcony, watching the scene from 20 feet away, and the lady of the house screaming in terror grabbed me and pulled me away from view, lest the mob focus its rage on the outsider. More gunshots, more terror and then I watched the dying man all but thrown into the back of an ambulance.

It was four o'clock on Friday afternoon and the man with the hole in his face was one of dozens of wounded and five dead Palestinians who paid the price of Israel's decision to take a 'time-out' from the peace process.

It is dead. Whatever the fine words of UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and President Bill Clinton, the news from the ground, from behind the Palestinian barricades in the West Bank, is that the peace process is dead. As the United Nations voted to condemn the 'excessive use' of Israeli force in the past three weeks the question is: who murdered the last best chance for peace?

Look at the numbers. Since the visit to the mosque in Jerusalem on 28 September by the right-wing Israeli opposition leader Ariel Sharon, 119 people have been killed. Seven Israelis dead, and 112 Palestinians. Look at the ages. All the dead Israelis have been men old enough for military service. Quite a few of the stone throwers picked out in the gun-sights of the Israeli Defence Force have been boys, not men. On Friday on the West Bank they slotted a 13-year old boy with two bullets to the heart.

The Israeli Defence Force is one of the best armies in the world. The optics of their weapons are the very best American technology. When the 13-year-old was shot dead, the soldier knew exactly who he was shooting. The target's young face would have loomed large in the gun-sight. It is stupid and wrong for mothers and fathers to allow children out onto the streets to fight an army, but that is not an adequate excuse for killing a child.

Look at the economics. Since Oslo, there has been no serious peace dividend for the Palestinians of the West Bank, only more unemployment, less work, less business, more refined restrictions, more imaginative curbs on their freedom of movement, their ability to trade as equals. The Palestinians have given up on the peace process because it wasn't giving them what they wanted - their own country - and they have nothing to lose. The Israelis have much to lose, but they never gave enough to make peace work.

And for all the intricate power play between Ehud Barak, the Israeli Prime Minister, President Clinton the peace-maker and Chairman Yasser Arafat, they could not overcome the forces ranged against them.

All Sharon had to do was visit the wrong place at the wrong time and the delicate balance of peace was crushed to matchwood.

In this climate of hopelessness, all that was needed was an excuse for more killing to take place. The madness in Nablus on Friday came at the end of two funerals for men who had been shot dead in a gun battle occasioned by a 'hike' by Jewish settlers, right-wing religious fundamentalists who choose to live in the West Bank. They had decided to go towards Nablus - a hotbed of Palestinian anger since the time of the British Mandate in the 1930s.

The hike was to view Joseph's Tomb, in which stood a sarcophagus thought to house his bones. The site is one of three that Jews claim because they were bought for the 'Jewish people' by characters from the Bible, in this case Jacob, who bought a nearby well from Hamor for 100 pieces of silver (Genesis 33:19). That claim, in the eyes of the settlers, overrides the reality that the Tomb is in a Palestinian-controlled town.

The result is that Joseph's Tomb has been a running sore down the ages. In the 1996 disturbances, Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinian rioters near the tomb. After Sharon's visit to the mosque three weeks ago, Palestinian fundamentalists - and there are many in Nablus - wrecked the tomb, and tortured and killed a rabbi who had come to check on it.

The tomb today is an empty hulk, freshly white-washed, with only a couple of charred wooden frames evidencing the atrocity.

The settlers came armed with M16 automatic assault rifles. They were 40 strong, bringing their women and children too.

They were given permission to go towards what is, for a Jew, probably the most dangerous place on earth, Nablus, while the leaders of the world were hoping and praying that the Sharm el-Sheikh summit in Egypt would work its magic on a troubled land. It was a provocation, carried out in righteous conviction by fanatics.

So why did the Israeli Defence Force give permission for it to go ahead? 'This was not an attempt to defuse the situation and bring calm,' said Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat. 'When they permitted the hike, they allowed the match to light the explosive.'

The gun battle raged for one long hot afternoon last Thursday, the settlers high up on a bluff overlooking Joseph's Tomb, the Palestinians taking cover below them. One Palestinian soldier, Mohammed, 22, told The Observer: 'What happened was that as the settlers were coming down the mountain, what they call Mount Ebal, a white car drove towards them. In it were four Palestinians, men and women, on the way to pick olives. The settlers opened fire first, on this car.'

There was no way of checking his story, but what is true is that, pinned down, the settlers used their mobile phones to call for help. 'It is really scary. There is one per son injured and we are waiting for help,' one woman said, four hours into the fighting.

There is no good road up there, and the Israelis were forced to call in the helicopter gunships. They opened up on the Palestinian fighters below, on the houses they were taking cover in.

And living in those houses, of course, were hundreds of Palestinian civilians. The old woman showed me the gutted ruins of her parlour and the hole in the window where the 50mm armour-piercing bullet had entered and shredded her sofa. The children, aged two, three, four and five, were cowering next door. They had been hurried off to hospital, but had only suffered from smoke damage. 'Thank God,' she said.

Two men died in the shoot-out, Rabbi Binyamin Herling, 64, and Palestinian Zahi al-Arda, 34.

On Friday morning, before the madness began, both sides buried their dead. The Palestinians processing the cold form of Zahi around Nablus, his face open to the sky.

They chanted, and fired gunshots in the air and waved freshly-minted pictures of the martyr in the air. No pictures of Yasser Arafat were on display - the single exception being his 10ft tall smiling face staring out from the Palestinian Ministry of Interior building. Arafat's police watched the mourners pass in an uneasy silence. Many in Nablus believe that the Chairman gave away too much at Sharm el-Sheikh.

I drove across the front line - burnt-out tyres, tank tracks on roads chillingly empty of life - and up into a Jewish settlement directly overlooking Nablus called Itmar, looking like nothing more than a spanking new Wimpey-style estate in a war zone.

The streets were empty apart from a few kids, one of them a little girl playing on her micro-scooter. On Thursday night some settlers had put up a road-block, using an Austin Montego to create havoc. The road-block's leader roared: 'Welcome to the Wild West Bank.'

A woman, originally from New York, made me a cup of tea. She was a sweet woman, still trembling from having seen the gunships fire at the hillside across the valley from her neighbour's porch the previous day.

Had I driven alone? I explained that I had left my Palestinian driver in Nablus, having promised him that I wasn't going to steal his taxi. She flashed back: 'It's probably one of ours anyway.'

And that was almost as bad as the man with the hole in his face: a transparently good woman, mouthing hate for a taxi driver she'd never met simply because he was of another race.

Yesterday morning there were five more funerals in Nablus. So it goes.

fields.headline: A full and franc exchange
fields.standfirst: Colin Frier  on how to make the most of that fistful of leftover pesetas
fields.trailText: Colin Frier on how to make the most of that fistful of leftover pesetas.
fields.body:
The last desperate spending spree of Britons anxious to get rid of their 'worthless' foreign currency before they get home is a familiar end of-holiday-scenario. But while many indulge in buying luxury items, and others donate to charity collections on the plane, ship, or at the airport, many holidaymakers return to the UK with unwanted foreign notes and coins. And sometimes in quite significant amounts.

According to holiday company Lunn Poly, the average amount of foreign currency converted back into sterling by its customers is £150. And an NOP report in July found returning Britons stash away a total of £31.9m in coins alone around their homes.

Dave Sharp from Walthamstow always has foreign cash left over from his holidays in Europe, but he doesn't bother converting it back to sterling. 'I often donate to the charity on the flight home,' he says. 'But any unused notes and coins I keep in little pots around the house, ready for when I go back.'

He admits that he has no idea how much the accumulated lira, pesetas and French francs are worth, and that as he may never return to certain destinations, he could lose out. But assuming you have a sum worth counting up, and that, unlike Sharp, you would prefer not to have foreign cash laying around collecting dust, what options are available?

Many bureaux de change providers, such as Thomas Cook, American Express and the Post Office, provide a buy-back service free of charge up to the amount originally purchased - provided you show your receipt. Thomas Cook customers must also have purchased a minimum of £100 worth of foreign currency. You will usually get the prevailing rate on the day you convert back. However for an initial charge of £2.50, Travelex guarantees to buy back at the same rate you paid.

But you might as well forget about the coins. Almost. The cost and bother means that most bureaux de change won't accept them. And there are numerous opportunities to donate to charity long after your holiday has finished. For example, Boots accepts foreign coins in all its stores on behalf of the Cancer Research Campaign. To date this has raised over £1m.

However, if you don't wish to give to charity, Thomas Cook will take back coins in denominations of at least one mark and one French franc. And P&O will convert all coins in major European currencies at full note value on its Dover to Calais route.

You may also have difficulty changing some low denomination notes. For example, Thomas Cook will not accept any Japanese notes under 500 yen, or any Australian notes worth less than$5. While those returning with Russian roubles may find themselves stuck as the rouble is currently off the Amex list of convertible currencies. Anyone hoping to convert some of the world's more obscure notes over the counter may have to wait until head office has confirmed their validity.

Those with small amounts of cash in a number of different foreign currencies may be hit especially hard, as some outlets make separate charges on each currency. The Post Office charges 1 per cent, subject to a minimum £2.50 and a maximum of £20 for each currency. American Express and Thomas Cook charge £2 and £3 respectively, with Thomas Cook's charges subject to a minimum of 2 per cent. However, the Halifax imposes only a single charge by allowing notes from different currencies to be lumped together. These charges, which also apply to any foreign currency in excess of the amount originally purchased, can make converting back to sterling hardly worth the effort.

However, if you have three or more currencies, some bureaux de change may be prepared to drop the charges on at least one of them. Travel agency Going Places will buy foreign notes without charge, irrespective of where they were purchased. Converting foreign notes at any of the 'big four' banks, is likely to result in a mini mum charge of £2.50-£3.00, and a maximum of £15, or commission of 1.5 per cent- 2 per cent, whichever is the greater. This is not dependent on having an account or on purchasing the currency at the bank. However, some accounts, such as Natwest's advantage gold, entitle customers to sell surplus foreign notes commission-free.

The Halifax and Abbey National will only accept unused foreign notes from account holders. The amount you receive can depend on where the bureau is located. Those at Heathrow, Stansted and Edinburgh airports operate within guidelines set by the airports' owners, the BAA. A spokesperson for the BAA said: 'It is our policy to match one of the big four banks.' Put another way, three of the 'big four' banks are likely to offer more competitive deals.

Anyone selling foreign notes at a BAA airport will be charged 1.5 per cent commission, unless they bought them from the same company at a BAA airport. Bureaux de change at non-BAA airports such as Luton operate independently, and have greater freedom to set their own pricing structure, as do smaller independent bureaux and hotels.

Bureaux have to make their money one way or another, either through the exchange rate or through charges. But it can still pay to shop around. For some customers, an attractive rate of exchange will not necessarily represent better value for money once charges have been taken into account, while those with a large amount of currency to convert back may benefit more from a low maximum charge than a low commission rate.

webTitle: Help: Can I get tax relief on letting a room?

fields.headline: Help: Can I get tax relief on letting a room?
fields.trailText: Homeowners up and down the country have just begun renting out spare rooms to students. But many may not realise they could be in line for one of the most generous tax reliefs available.
fields.body:
Homeowners up and down the country have just begun renting out spare rooms to students. But many may not realise they could be in line for one of the most generous tax reliefs available - the 'rent a room' exemption, which allows you to claim up to £4,250 a year in rent without paying tax. This translates into charging up to £81.70 a week. For a basic-rate taxpayer, this could save you £935 in tax (or £1,700 if a higher-rate taxpayer).

The charity TaxAid believes the exemption was introduced 'to recognise a fait accompli', says director David Brodie. 'A lot of people were probably not declaring the income anyway. So, rather than make them all criminals, this exemption was introduced.'

The rules - as explained in IR87, 'Letting and your home' - are fairly strict. The tenant should be 'someone who pays to live in your home, normally with meals provided, and who often shares the family rooms'. The Revenue will want the room to be physically part of your house. Also, the property should be 'your only or main home _ where friends and correspondents would expect to find you and your family.' Some people have tried to claim this exemption when, for instance, they have moved out of their Wimbledon home to let it to tennis players. But the Revenue will not grant the exemption in this instance and insists the landlord should be living in the property at the same time as the tenant.

Landlords who qualify do not have to disclose the income if the rent is less than £4,250. If they complete a tax return, they would need to tick a box saying that they are using the exemption - without further details.

If the rent is higher than £4,250, there are two options. You can declare and pay tax on the excess amount. Or you could forget about the exemption and simply work out your taxable profit (after deducting your letting expenses) and pay the tax on it in the usual way.

Free copies of IR87 are available from tax offices or through www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk.

TaxAid can be reached at www.taxaid.org.uk or on 0207 624 3768 on Mondays to Thursdays, between 10 and 12 noon.

But the Revenue will not grant the exemption in this instance and insists the landlord should be living in the property at the same time as the tenant. Landlords who qualify do not have to disclose the income if the rent is less than £4,250. If they complete a tax return, they would need to tick a box saying that they are using the exemption - without further details. If the rent is higher than £4,250, there are two options. You can declare and pay tax on the excess amount. Or you could forget about the exemption and simply work out your taxable profit (after deducting your letting expenses) and pay the tax on it in the usual way. webTitle: Wealthcheck: 'Fed up' shift worker tempted by prospect of early retirement

fields.headline: 'Fed up' shift worker tempted by prospect of early retirement
fields.standfirst: Can investments alone keep this family afloat for five years?
fields.trailText: Can investments alone keep this family afloat for five years?
fields.body:
Noel and Noreen Simpson

Ages 47 and 45

Live in Newtownards, Northern Ireland

Occupations Belfast Harbour Police Sergeant and housewife

Earn £27,200

Mortgage None

Debts None

Investments Peps, Tessas, Isas, building society account and endowments

Pensions Noel - occupational scheme; Noreen - several years' membership of former employer's scheme

Aims For Noel to try to stop work as near to 50 as possible and to generally improve the return on their investments

Noel Simpson would like to retire early and he probably has a better reason than those who work an ordinary nine to five. He has been working shifts for the past 29 years - daytime, evening and night, and only has one weekend off every six weeks. 'I am fed up working in this way,' he says.

One of the advantages of having stuck it out this long is that he can look forward to a decent pension in retirement, but he is not allowed to start drawing it until he is at least 55. His ideal would be to retire at 50 or soon after. He estimates his family would need an income of around £15,000 to keep themselves going. He thinks he might still do some work to keep himself 'ticking over' but would like to know if his investments will keep him afloat until his pension comes into effect at 55.

Noel and his wife, Noreen, have managed to save a fair amount. They both took out Peps with Bradford & Bingley, which are now worth around £22,000. Both have deposited the maximum in mini cash Isas with Nationwide for this tax year and the year before and they now have a total of £12,000 in these accounts.

Noel is always on the lookout for the best interest rates and he recently transferred money from an Egg account into the Nationwide's internet based 'e-account', which pays a better rate. This account is held in Noreen's name to take advantage of the fact that as a non-taxpayer she does not have to pay any tax on the interest. It contains £19,500, although Noel says they will be withdrawing £5,000 next year for a new car.

Noreen has £10,000, which she inherited, in a one-year Woolwich fixed interest bond. She is a housewife and mother to the couple's children, Nicola, 12, and Thomas, 10. She also works a few hours a week as a school dinner supervisor, but does not earn more than £1,000 a year doing this. When she was younger she was employed by Abbey National, where she accumulated around eight years' worth of pension.

One thing they will not have to worry about if Noel stops working is their mortgage repayments, as they have already paid off their loan. Sensibly, they continued with the endowments they had taken out initially to cover their loan. The first of these, with Scottish Provident, is due to mature in 2002 and Noel expects it to be worth around £20,000. A policy with Royal London that comes to an end six years later is likely to be worth a similar amount.

Adviser 1: Andrew Jones

Noel's long-lasting pension contributions should provide him with a pension of nearly two-thirds of his final salary that will increase annually with inflation.

To help bridge the five-year gap between Noel's desired retirement age of 50 and his pension starting age of 55, the couple will have their joint savings of £58,500, after they have bought their new car, which will rise to £78,500 once they receive the proceeds of their Scottish Provident endowment. This means they could not survive for five years without spending capital.

If they were to invest their savings for income, they could expect to receive an income yield of approximately 6.5 per cent from conservative investments such as corporate bonds. This would generate a gross annual income of £5,100, which would not be sufficient to meet their needs.

Noel mentions he may take up another job and this is likely to be the key to his plans. If it is assumed he can earn £10,000 per year the requirement to earn £15,000 in total is more easily achieved. Rather than focus on using all their assets to generate income, they should consider taking their income initially from their taxed savings accounts and the proceeds of their endowment policies. They could also use some of this capital to buy further Isas.

In the case of their existing Tessas, Peps and Isas the income should ideally be left untouched to maximise the tax benefits. In future years these can be used to produce a tax efficient income.

Andrew Jones works for chartered accountants Blick Rothenberg.

Adviser 2: Gillian Cardy

Noel and Noreen should try to avoid dipping into their capital to support themselves. They would be better investing the capital to generate tax-free income. This is important from Noreen's point of view as she will be vulnerable in the event that Noel dies before her. Although she will be eligible for a widow's pension, it will be less than his and to have the invested capital will provide her with greater protection.

They really need to maximise their Isa investments so they can generate as much tax-free income as possible if Noel stops work. They have invested in mini cash Isas already this year, so they can invest £1,000 each into an insurance Isa (i.e. a single premium with-profits investment with a company such as Sun Life) and a further £3,000 each into a stocks and shares Isa. They could consider investing for growth now with companies with a good range of funds, such as Aberdeen or Fidelity, switching into income-generating funds later.

They should put £5,000 each into stocks and shares Isas next year and the proceeds of the Scottish Provident policy in 2002 could go towards the Isas for that year and the one following. If Noel stops work, there is the option to switch all these stocks and shares Isas and the Bradford & Bingley Peps into higher income generating funds. Once Noel and Noreen's pensions come into play, they can adjust their investments, perhaps switching back into some more growth oriented or balanced funds.

Gillian Cardy works for financial advisers Professional Partnerships.

Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Off the rails in a throwaway world

fields.headline: Off the rails in a throwaway world
fields.standfirst: Affordable chic has brought high fashion to the high street. But capricious spending may be wiping out any price savings
fields.trailText: Affordable chic has brought high fashion to the high street. But capricious spending may be wiping out any price savings.
fields.body:
The way we look and dress has a vital role to play in self-image and self-worth. It can therefore make demands on our finances out of all proportion to practical considerations. But while we may follow fashion we are not necessarily slaves to it.

Between 1989 and 1999 the amount we spent on clothes, footwear and accessories grew by 38 per cent to just under £36 billion. Over the same period, the proportion of money spent on essential items fell. But the high street has undergone a revolution which makes dressing up with the Joneses more affordable. Outlets such as TK Maxx, part of the world's largest 'off-price' clothing retailer, the TJX Companies, and UK operation Matalan have boomed on the back of offering affordable chic. 'The chain stores copy the catwalk al-most instantly these days,' said the V&A's Bolton. 'People are getting much smart-er about mixing these items with one or two designer labels to achieve the right look.'

Even celebrities such as Zoë Ball and Posh Spice can be found flicking through the rails on the high street looking for fashions that can be worn today and then thrown away tomorrow. But this brings with it another set of problems. If fashionable clothes can be purchased for less money, there's nothing to stop us revamping our wardrobes more frequently. The benefits of lower prices are wiped out by more capricious spending.

And real financial problems can arise if we work, or spend our leisure time, in an environment where the dress code exceeds our purchasing power. 'The women in the office are all single and wear Prada,' said Sue (not her real name), who works as an office administrator in an advertising agency. 'I'm a single mother and just can't afford to keep up.' And while the high street is becoming more adept at imitating couture style, we are all becoming more brand aware.

'Peer group identity is being eroded by brands,' said Bolton. This shift is being recognised by the high street, and retailers such as Debenhams are bringing in high-profile designers to produce special ranges aimed at aspirational Middle England. We don't mend clothes because we get rid of them before we wear them out.

Neither is this a purely female thing. Men, particularly younger men, are just as fashion conscious. (Expenditure on male toiletries has risen 79 per cent in the past 10 years.)

Brands are also a way of establishing status. In a society where the outward trappings of class are being eroded, brands are one way of identifying with, and being identified by, a social or economic peer group. If Mrs Jones wears Prada, then so do I.

fields.headline: As posh as the Beckhams
fields.standfirst: All you have to do is spend - and that's the problem, reports  Anne Caborn
fields.trailText: All you have to do is spend - and that's the problem, reports Anne Caborn.
fields.body:
We live in a material world where affluence is demonstrated by conspicuous consumption. If you've got it - the saying goes - flaunt it. But while a spending spree, a high fashion wardrobe, or even the latest must-have in garden design can be fun, the downside is the disconcerting feeling that we are all on some form of money merry-go-round.

This spending spree is influenced by economic ups and downs at a personal, national and even global level, but the consumer society itself is here to stay. The more we earn, the more we spend and the more we aspire to spend as we flick through glossy magazines and view the lives of the rich and ostentatious through the television screen. There has always been a human desire to keep up with the Joneses, but now we know about and want to keep up with the Beckhams, the Tarrants and the Blairs.

Our ancient ancestors may have painted a particular pattern in woad on their faces to reinforce tribal links. We still want to belong but we do it with cars, kitchens and credit cards. And keeping up with the Joneses has never been so much fun. According to economic psychologist Professor Paul Webley of Exeter University we shop for pleasure - as opposed to need - because we can afford to do so. Although the divide between rich and poor is growing, middle-income families are increasingly well off. According to the British Lifestyles 2000 survey from Mintel, in the past 10 years gross income has increased by 22 per cent in real terms. And while most of us are not addicted consumers, as such, research indicates that there is a work-spend cycle in operation.

'People work more, because their employers demand that they do, and so they earn more, spend more, and luxuries become necessities. People work more to earn more and so on,' said Webley. According to Peter Ayton, chief statistician at Mintel, an example of a luxury that has become a necessity for many people is the dishwasher. And as the prices of such domestic appliances have not risen in real terms, they have become more affordable.

But this affordability also carries a sting in the tail. The appliance may be more affordable, but service costs have continued to rise, largely due to the fact that labour costs, which are a big part of service pricing, have increased. Once we buy something like a dishwasher we have to look after it; we may have to insure it (as part of our house contents, or with a product warranty), further driving up our spending. Failing that, the cost of major repairs, when they come, may seem relatively high compared with simply dumping the old dishwasher and buying a new one.

At the same time we are being subjected to increasingly sophisticated marketing techniques as manufacturers and retailers compete for our custom. Not only do we choose a dishwasher on the basis of cost and efficiency, but also upon whether it will match our new kitchen decor. And if we change the decor, which we do with increasing frequency, the dishwasher may have to go, along with the fridge, the freezer and washing machine. Our home and garden have become colour co-ordinated accessories for our lifestyles.

'It's almost as if we need the appropriate interior backdrop to go with the clothes we are wearing,' observed Andrew Bolton, a V&A and London College of Fashion research fellow. This need to spend money on our homes, as well as ourselves, is further reinforced by garden and home makeover programmes on television and a plethora of books and magazine titles. They not only give us fashion trends and decors to aspire to but, in theory, empower us to achieve them.

DIY has become the ultimate instant fix; a new look for the front room in the space of a weekend. All it takes is some money and a trip to B&Q. When Mintel questioned 1,958 adults about their spending plans, 38 per cent said decorating and making minor home improvements were a priority. Some 37 per cent listed buying something for the home.

So what we are being presented with is not only an increasing desire to spend, but also an ever-greater array of items to spend our money on. It seems that everything in our lives is being influenced by fashion, or the pace of technological change. It would never be possible to have everything we want because what we want changes as fashions change. The key to it all is a sense of proportion.

I want it, I want it, I want it. Fiftysomethings are among the biggest spenders

It's hardly surprising that after the rigours of war and rationing, people decided to have fun. The 1950s and 1960s saw an increasing emphasis on home decoration and fashion, as well as the birth of the teenager. They had the financial trappings of an adult but few of the responsibilities. Instead, their money went on looking good, entertainment and music.

When this generation finally settled down they did so without relinquishing everything that went with being young, free and single. Interestingly, today's 50-year-olds, who were in their late teens as the 1960s drew to a close, are among the biggest spenders.

'They are at the peak of their earning power and have grown up since the war in the consumer society,' explains Peter Ayton of Mintel.

But they also shop for bargains, look for discounts and stand up for their rights. 'If you look at the consumer programmes on the television they are delivering to this audience,' he added. 'They may be older, but they are also wiser.'

So the good news is that we have learnt valuable lessons about saving and spending on the back of property crashes and recessions. But when the good times roll we are bedazzled by an increasing range of things to purchase, housed in ever more attractive shopping environments (where we can eat and relax, as well as buy).

One way of getting off the spend-spend-spend merry-go-round is to visit the shops less often. But the latest weapon in the consumer revolution is the internet, bringing an array of potential purchases into our home or on to our television screens, and now we can even buy thousands of things via our mobile phones.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Fidelity Sector Funds
fields.trailText: Fidelity Sector Funds.
fields.body:
Contact 0800 414171 or www.fidelity.co.uk

Aim: To enable investors to spread their portfolios by targeting sectors they think have strong investment prospects.

Bells & whistles: Four new sector funds - healthcare, industrial, financial services and consumer industries - add to two existing Fidelity sector funds in technology and telecommunications. Fidelity is the biggest sector fund manager in the US, running sector funds for over 15 years, with 48 sector funds and more than $49 billion under management.

How it works: All four funds are global. The healthcare fund will concentrate on companies involved in the design, manufacture or sales of products and services connected with healthcare, medicine and biotechnology, while the industrials fund will concentrate on companies related to cyclical and natural-resource industries. The funds will be biased towards large and medium-sized companies - and some of the largest holdings will be the blue chips within their sector.

Minimum: £1000 lump sum or £50 monthly.

Charges: 3 per cent initial until October 31, when it rises to 3.25 per cent within an Isa, and 5.25 per cent outside. Annual charges 1.5 per cent.

Tax: Available tax-free through Fidelity's Isa.

Risk: Medium/high.

Should you invest? Patrick Connolly of Bath firm Chartwell is not impressed: 'Fidelity is one of the best investment houses, and in terms of resources it is second to none. But it's gone a bit over the top with the number of funds that it's launching. It has 38 funds at the moment, and the choice is likely to confuse investors who could end up overexposed to some very specialist and volatile areas.'

Michael Usher, of London firm Brooks Macdonald Gayer, agrees: 'Timing is everything when it comes to investing in funds like these and many investors will end up wondering - when they should be investing in industries or healthcare.'

Points out of 10: Connolly - 3, Usher - 4.

Charges: 3 per cent initial until October 31, when it rises to 3.25 per cent within an Isa, and 5.25 per cent outside. Annual charges 1.5 per cent. Tax: Available tax-free through Fidelity's Isa. Risk: Medium/high. Should you invest? Patrick Connolly of Bath firm Chartwell is not impressed: 'Fidelity is one of the best investment houses, and in terms of resources it is second to none. But it's gone a bit over the top with the number of funds that it's launching. It has 38 funds at the moment, and the choice is likely to confuse investors who could end up overexposed to some very specialist and volatile areas.' Michael Usher, of London firm Brooks Macdonald Gayer, agrees: 'Timing is everything when it comes to investing in funds like these and many investors will end up wondering - when they should be investing in industries or healthcare.' Points out of 10: Connolly - 3, Usher - 4.

fields.headline: Feeling groovy - and green
fields.standfirst: As the car industry has shown, good things can come in smaller, and more fashion-conscious, packages
fields.trailText: As the car industry has shown, good things can come in smaller, and more fashion-conscious, packages.
fields.body:
Conspicuous consumption has a conspicuous impact on the environment. The more we buy, the more we throw away and the UK has a long way to go when it comes to recycling. In Switzerland, national household waste recycling runs at about 52 per cent, and in the US it's 31 per cent. Compare that with 9 per cent in England and Wales and less than 6 per cent in Scotland. Packaging is typically 25-30 per cent by weight of dustbin waste.

Packaging plays an intrinsic role in the marketing and branding of the things we buy. Sarah Oppenheimer, waste campaigner with Friends of the Earth, said consumers are keen to avoid packaging, but this is often difficult. 'We would like to see more of the material used standardised and made recyclable,' she said.

However, Incpen, the Industry Council for Packaging and the Environment, states that making all packaging recyclable would be environmentally unsound. Factory refillable bottles would have to be thicker and heavier, thus taking more fuel to transport.

The council admits that some goods, such as luxury chocolates and perfume, are overpackaged, but says that packaging is an 'integral part of the treat'. The perception that goods are overpackaged also reflects a 'lack of understanding of the role of the pack'.

Another item that has a profound effect on the environment is the car. According to Tony Bosworth, transport campaigner with Friends of the Earth, air pollution contributes to 24,000 premature deaths in the UK each year.

Cars have an impact on climate and the countryside, but while there is a growing awareness of this, cars are still perceived as both a necessity and a status symbol. The good news is that car manufacturers, spurred on by European demands for greater fuel economy and cleaner emissions, have designed smaller models to fulfil status as well as practical requirements. 'Sales of cars in the mini and super mini category increased by 21 per cent and 17 per cent respectively in the first six months of this year,' said Bosworth. 'The sales of luxury saloons were down 9 per cent in the same period.' It isn't all good news. Sales of fuel-heavy multipurpose vehicles and four-wheel drives were up 23 per cent.

But Bosworth is optimistic that, as manufacturers continue to put more effort into producing stylish smaller cars, the consumer will increasingly buy a vehicle that is better for the planet, even if their decision is still being influenced by design and luxury interiors. 'I'm happy if they're doing the right thing, even if it is for the wrong reason.'

Hijacked by hi-tech

Technology left the lab long ago and found its way into the shops. The microprocessor has made hi-tech items smaller, cheaper and more accessible.

Companies have increasingly looked for consumer spinoffs from these advances. So technology-enhanced products have become more stylish as the consumer market has become more important. Just as catwalk fashions make it into the high street ever more quickly, so do technological advances, effectively shortening the shelf life of hi-tech products.

It is not so much that obsolescence is built in but that obsolescence is a by-product of technological advance. In less than a decade word processors have been overtaken by personal computers, videos by DVDs, cassette tapes by CDs.

Telephone answering machines seemed like a luxury in the mid-1980s but now it comes as a shock to telephone a home where your call goes unanswered. It is not uncommon for each member of a family to have a mobile phone and perhaps a pager as well.

webTitle: Property: The 'treatment' gives tower blocks new lease of life

fields.headline: The 'treatment' gives tower blocks new lease of life
fields.standfirst: Once notoriously unpopular, high-rise buildings are now desirable residences, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Once notoriously unpopular, high-rise buildings are now desirable residences, writes Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Tall is beautiful again. Just as London is welcoming a rash of new commercial skyscrapers, so the residential property market is beginning to transform an old enemy - the tower block.

In the Sixties, high-rise flats were described as futuristic streets in the sky, boasting communal areas and in-creased security. By the late Seventies they had become cells for council tenants isolated by broken lifts and housing-estate violence. When, in the Eighties, Thatcherite market forces tried to end council housing by giving tenants the right to buy, the undesirability of many tower blocks left them as mainly council-owned sink estates with a few home-owners who had no possibility of reselling. But now private developers, who have turned warehouses, barns, churches and schools into up-market contemporary housing, are giving the treatment to towers.

Take Sudbury House, a 19-floor block in Clapton, previously owned by Hackney Council. Two others nearby were demolished in the Nineties when the area was known for poverty and high crime, and run by an 'old Labour' local authority. Sudbury tenants paid from £40 to £80 a week in rent, although many were on housing benefit.

Sudbury House is now called Landmark Heights, London E5, with 114 one- and two-bedroom flats selling for £95,000 to £165,000. There is now a concierge at reception, floodlit secure car parking, landscaped gardens, plus conference room, laundry and gym facilities, and entryphones for each flat. Buyers can take an optional £15,000 upgrade to have wooden floors, trendier lighting and better kitchen and bathroom fittings.

Like many privatisations, this one benefited from a de facto public subsidy. 'The block was in good condition when we bought it because it had been refurbished for housing association use,' says Steve Eagles, a chartered surveyor at developer Aitch Group. 'We obviously made sure it didn't have structural problems of the kind associated with some blocks, and we were very happy with its location - it's right for the market we want to target,' he says.

The block now claims to be the height of contemporary urban chic. Large windows offer owners from the fifth floor and above striking views of Hackney Marshes on one side, and landmarks like the London Eye and Millennium Dome on the other.

'This block really signifies how Clapton is improving,' says Fizle Sagar, who lives nearby and works at Islington estate agency Currells, which is selling the apartments. 'The people who are buying are locals who want to start on the property ladder, singles who are attracted to this kind of accommodation, and people from outside of London who want a low-cost property,' she says.

It was the same story with Keeling House in Bethnal Green, east London, a 15-storey block designed in 1956 by Sir Denys Lasdun, who went on to create the National Theatre on London's South Bank. His theory was to make all the Keeling House living-rooms point outwards to gain maximum exposure to the sun as it moved around the towers. Thirty years later it was declared unsafe, with masonry cracks and nets erected to catch falling stonework. It was saved from demolition only because it was listed on the recommendation of English Heritage. It was derelict for some years and Tower Hamlets made various attempts to get a social landlord, like a housing association, to take it over. But last year developer Lincoln Holdings bought it for a reported £1.3 million and turned it, like Landmark Heights, into a des-res.

It has 50 maisonettes, eight flats and eight penthouses. There is now a glass foyer with a waterfall, and the flats' interiors have become more open plan. The penthouses, selling for a cool £375,000, have larger glass frontages to maximise their spectacular views. Warren Black, from agent Felicity J Lord, says this sort of property is a good investment in one of London's undervaluedareas, Bethnal Green.

'The canny purchaser will always keep his eye on centrally located, up-and-coming areas. Keeling House is on the fringe of the City.'

Nearby Solkin and Trevelyan Houses, also listed tower blocks, may be next on the agenda for other interested developers. But the drive continues to keep at least some blocks in the social housing sector. Voluntary groups have set up the National Sustainable Tower Blocks Initiative to try to breathe new life into council and housing association ownership. The group says there are still 4,000 publicly owned tower blocks housing up to 800,000 people, and wants a government and council campaign to repair the buildings and extend their life-expectancy. But it may be a battle. The initiative says most blocks would take £5m to make safe - but only £500,000 to demolish. Little wonder private development appears attractive to cash-strapped councils.

Buying in a privately refurbished block is also likely to be easier than, say, buying your own council flat in a tower still run by the local authority. Some right-to-buy applicants complain about some lend-ers' reluctance to offer mortgages for high-level flats. And the new fashion of tower living is not restricted to refurbished ex-council buildings. New towers are to be built, aimed at luxury buyers and renters,as part of the London regeneration schemes outlined for Elephant and Castle, Paddington Basin and parts of the City. Ironically, the upper storeys of the old blocks were deeply unpopular with council tenants, who feared the combination of lift failures and isolation. Now private renters and buyers pay a penthouse premium the higher they go.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Apple cheek
fields.body:
Apple cheek

Apple has always been renowned for extreme coyness about its new products. Any inquiries about its plans tend to be met with a terse 'Apple does not comment on future product announcements'. In fact, it was so important to keep secret the blue and green laptops released at the recent Apple Expo Paris that they were granted an armed escort.

But what's this? As soon as Apple stumbles financially - its share price is a third what it was a month ago - founder and CEO Steve Jobs starts tempting the markets with promises of bountiful innovations.

Name game

Red lorry, Yellow Lorry, Dotcom, Flipflop, Flapjack, Cake, Slice, and Bite are all names of PR agencies. Well, all but one. In its inaugural competition, @large invites readers to guess which is not a daft moniker.
business@observer.co.uk

RU12?

Whoever said that the art of conversation was dead clearly did not reckon on the sort of useful communication possibilities afforded by the mobile-phone text message. Luckily, the Little Book of Text Messages has codified this new lexicon.

%-) means I am drunk but happy. :-D* means I am laughing so hard that I did not notice a spider is hanging from my lip. And IU2LUVUBIAON is new-economy shorthand for: 'I used to love you but it's all over now.'

Look of love

And talking of innovative uses of new mobile phones, @large was horrified to learn of the existence of 'Wap porn'. The next time you see someone on the train staring at their expensive mobile with a strange smile in their face, beware. They may claim to be keeping an eye on their share portfolio but in fact be engaged in SMS sex. You have been warned.
