webTitle: Repair of Navy subs likely to cost £30m

fields.headline: Repair of Navy subs likely to cost £30m
fields.trailText: The Royal Navy faced fresh embarrassment last night when it emerged that the total cost of repairing all of the 12 hunter-killer submarines recalled to dock following reports of defects may exceed £30m.
fields.body:
The Royal Navy faced fresh embarrassment last night when it emerged that the total cost of repairing all of the 12 hunter-killer submarines recalled to dock following reports of defects may exceed £30m.

The submarines - equipped with the PWR1 reactor system first brought into service almost 30 years ago - were recalled indefinitely to the Royal Navy Dockyards in Faslane and Devonport after engineers found cracks in the cooling system on one of the subs' reactors. It is now feared that the fault may be part of the submarine's original design will affect all 12 vessels.

John Large, an independent nuclear expert, said that each submarine could require 'three to four months work'. Although the cost of the materials would be small, he said: 'You are going to need to pay for berthing space for each submarine, absorb the cost of each vessel being disarmed, and you will have to accommodate the mariners somehow.

'There is also a lot of specialised equipment to be used. You could be talking about £3m for each submarine.'

The Ministry of Defence said of the claims: 'It is far too early to comment.'

The defect involves small cracks in welds on the cooling system of the submarine's nuclear reactor; some experts believe these fissures are a sign of deeper problems. The Navy tightened monitoring procedures after similar generic cracks in cooling pipes were discovered in Polaris subs almost a decade ago.

The indefinite suspension of the 12 subs will leave a gaping hole in Britain's nuclear arsenal. Hunter-killers are often used to protect the larger Trident subs and form an essential part of Nato's defence programme.

webTitle: Now women make all the running at top football clubs

fields.headline: Now women make all the running at top football clubs
fields.standfirst:
All change in the offices and boardrooms as yet another male bastion crumbles

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Its enough to make football club chairmen everywhere spill the post-match brandy on to their camel-hair coats in disgust. Not content with playing, watching and even refereeing the ultimate man's game, women are now running it too. Soccer's traditional all-male hierarchy is being swept away by a new generation of female administrators who love the sport, understand the offside rule and don't just fancy David Beckham.
fields.body:
Its enough to make football club chairmen everywhere spill the post-match brandy on to their camel-hair coats in disgust. Not content with playing, watching and even refereeing the ultimate man's game, women are now running it too. Soccer's traditional all-male hierarchy is being swept away by a new generation of female administrators who love the sport, understand the offside rule and don't just fancy David Beckham.

An unprecedented number of women now occupy key positions in football. At almost half England's 92 professional clubs, the chairman, managing director or club secretary is a woman.

Lorraine Rogers is typical of the new breed. The 37-year-old ex-director of Hambros bank is chairman, chief executive and club secretary at Tranmere Rovers of the First Division. Last week she became the most powerful woman in football when she joined the board of the Football League, the governing body of the 72 clubs outside the Premiership. As one of the league's six-strong leadership, Rogers will help negotiate lucrative television, internet and sponsorship deals.

Like all the female decision-makers in football, Rogers dismisses any notion that women need special treatment to get on in such a male-dominated world. This is a natural progression of the changes in the Nineties when football became "sexy" and significant numbers of women became interested. Most of the female decision-makers are club secretaries. They include Bury's Jill Neville, the mother of Manchester United and England players Gary and Phil Neville; Julie Etherington at Peterborough United, whose son Matthew plays for Spurs; and Watford's Catherine Alexander, whose husband John is her counterpart at Spurs. But Queens Park Rangers club secretary Sheila Marson, who has been a soccer administrator since 1971, is their doyenne.

'Some people think being the secretary at a football club is just a typist's role, but it's actually very important,' she remarks. They handle players' contracts, organise the team's transport and ensure everyone gets paid. 'When I started as a club secretary in 1979, there were only a few women doing the job. Now there are many and the number is growing all the time. I suspect it's because women are renowned for their organisational skills, and as football has become more complicated and more of a business - with bigger crowds, foreign players and big television deals - those skills are very useful.'

Kirstine Nicholson has been club secretary at Third Division side Leyton Orient for four months. In that time she has had to field media in-quiries about one of the club's players being arrested during a gangland murder inquiry, helped the club mount a High Court challenge to an attempt by West Ham, its Premiership neighbour, to take over its training-ground, and hurriedly sign several players before the new season kicked off to ensure Orient had en-ough personnel to field a full-team on the opening day.

The media studies graduate's ambition was always to help run a football club. 'To be involved at the heart of a club, rather than have only a peripheral role as a fan, is fantastic. Women now feel they can be involved like this and be taken seriously.'

It is not, however, a glamorous existence. The absence of Orient's ticket-office manager through illness meant that when they played New-castle recently in the Worthington Cup, she had to stay until midnight printing tickets on the club's one old ticket machine and selling them to eager fans queuing outside.

A lot of men wondered how I got this job, because club secretaries had always been men. But once they realised I'd worked my way up through the ranks, I was respected.'

Helen Giles, secretary at Southend United, says: 'It's still a male-dominated business, so you're always going to get comments. What would really change things would be a female manager, but I can't see that happening.'

fields.headline: Knight errant at the opera
fields.standfirst: His methods are populist. His results win success. So what chance does this maverick have of rescuing the Royal Opera House?
fields.trailText: His methods are populist. His results win success. So what chance does this maverick have of rescuing the Royal Opera House? Euan Ferguson meets Raymond Gubbay.
fields.body:
This is the entrance we've been waiting for. If we were, in fact, watching an actual opera, rather than simply being high-paying spectators to the prolonged thrashings of bloodied elitist melodramatic footshootery that make up the real-life tale of the Royal Opera House, then this is the point where we'd happily put down the boiled sweets, ignore the doubtless incomprehensible programme notes [Augsburg, 1756. Three years in it is to the famous War of the Helvetian Pantaloon and so Franz, a shepherd ...] and listen, thankfully, to the closing caterwaul from the irrelevant third milkmaid. The real action is, at last, about to begin.

Raymond Gubbay starts sotto voce, emerging surprisingly tremulous from the wings. The self-appointed scourge of Covent Garden, an absurdly successful populist impresario of operas in his own right, who has now taken his long-standing critique of the ROH shambles to its logical end by applying, formally, for the vacant post of executive director there, does not come in with a crash of cymbals; he is hesitant, soft-voiced, thoughtful in his manner and, in the end, his criticisms are all the more coruscating for it.

So when he speaks, for instance, of the way in which Peter Gummer and Mary Allen, after handing out £78.5 million to the House from their positions on the Arts Council, then simply 'walked round the table to collect it', becoming chairman and chief executive of the House within a year, his voice grows quieter, not louder. It was, he almost whispers, 'a truly appalling piece of history. There they were with their snouts in the trough, in receipt of the same money they'd just allocated... if that had happened in a Third World country we'd all be sneering. But it happens over here and we just say: "Oh, jolly good luck to them."' By the end, I am straining to hear his measured words. And ROH chairman Sir Colin Southgate - the man who said he didn't want to go to the opera 'to sit next to somebody in a singlet, a pair of shorts and a smelly pair of trainers' - and the rest of his board should strain still further, for this application, and the points raised therein, are made in deadly seriousness, and are bound to shake much welcome air into the Covent Garden debate.

They won't like Gubbay there. Thirty-three years at the sharp end of promoting, and most of it highly successful, despite critical sneers at his 'tacky' mid-Nineties stagings of La Bohème and Carmen. They won't like him, but they should listen, because they have something of a history of gross malmanagement. It was the hilariously observed BBC documentary The House which first alerted us a few years ago to the arrogance, the elitism, the Gothic stupidity - but it didn't seem to alert them. Since then we've had the Gummer shambles, the Allen shambles, their enforced shambolic resignations, the two-year closure shambles, the touring shambles and the constant losing-of-vast-amounts-of-public-money shambles. The eventual reopening was hailed in some quarters as a success, but six months later the apparent saviour, Michael Kaiser, resigned, and ticket prices are still seen as ludicrously high - for those who can get the ones not already taken by the House's well-off 'Friends'. A third of the seats have a poor view of the stage, and the word 'shambles' still hovers nearby, waiting to alight at any time.

Why, I asked Gubbay, did no one seem to learn? He sighed. 'Partly because there is no political will to do anything about it. And partly because the board, by and large, with I suppose some honourable exceptions, appear to leave their brains behind when they step through the stage door: they are in awe of the setting, the ambience, the fact that it's great art, and sensible business practices are thrown away. The House is a gem, a priceless gem. But you have to remember that it began in another time, another century, when people went to the opera simply to be seen. And I wonder whether that's changed at all. They hold so many seats for the Friends, supporters who pay for the privilege, that they've disenfranchised a lot of people, and after all this is funded at the rate of £20m a year for the benefit of everyone.

'An audience can always be had for popular opera, well done, at a decent price. There are huge audiences out there. But the House's problem isn't just that it hasn't penetrated that audience; it doesn't want to penetrate that audience. Its coterie of supporters like to keep it exclusive, for Friends and corporate sponsors. I want an audience to come because it's there to see the show, not to be seen itself. And I don't think anyone's going to come in gardening gear, or smelly trainers, or whatever.

'There are all kinds of ways to get the place more efficient. The number of outside consultants is scandalous, for instance. And if La Bohème is popular why can't you run it for two weeks? Let's triple cast, have 16 shows in two weeks, your smaller parts will be paid by the week... I mean, it would upset people terribly but they'd do it, wouldn't they, if they were being paid properly for it? Why are opera singers treated with this great deference? Artists at the top get more than enough. You see, I'm not against public subsidy for the arts per se, far from it. But I think it can breed terrible bureaucracy, and I think the way the House has been run has actually damaged other subsidised arts. I'd like to see a lean and hungry Covent Garden.'

For all the tough-money talk, he's still a kindly and happy conversationalist. He talks passionately and widely about, for instance, his grandchildren (he has two daughters; he himself is divorced), and why it's such a worry that no children receive musical education at school any more; and his flat on Paris's Left Bank; and why Puccini is better for an orchestra than Verdi; and how he failed his own Grade 1 piano, which causes me to interrupt, rudely, to wonder quite how. 'God. Don't ask. I think my mother was very disappointed. And it's one of those things I'm sure that will allow people to say, "Oh, he knows nothing about music, he's just an entrepreneur who got lucky." But I'm quite, quite happy to let my record speak for itself. I've been knocked so many times by the establishment that I can't be bruised any more.'

Given the House's propensity for wrong-headedness, one suspects his chances of winning the appointment are doomed, no matter how right he may be for the job. Southgate and co. will probably pick another contender; the fact that Jennie Page's name is in the running tells you all you need to know about their foresight. The forthcoming appointment has all the hallmarks of an accident waiting to happen, and not even a very interesting one at that; a collision between two milk-floats, say, where all you're left with is some broken glass and the smell of spilt cream.

But Raymond Gubbay will have had his solo, and will have deserved it.

webTitle: How phantom German fighter tricked Britain

fields.headline: How phantom German fighter tricked Britain
fields.standfirst: It existed only in Goebbels' s propaganda. Neal Ascherson hunts the He.113
fields.trailText: It existed only in Goebbels' s propaganda. Neal Ascherson hunts the He.113.
fields.body:
Six miles above the French coast, three German fighters plunged down at the American bomber beneath them. Lieutenant Peck, the pilot of the B-17 'Flying Fortress', recognised them instantly. These were rare birds, the fabulous but seldom-seen Heinkel 113.

Peck had come across the Heinkel fighter before, as a pilot with the RAF in the Battle of Britain. Now, as the fighters opened fire and swept overhead, he got a close look: big nose-spinner, one cannon in each wing, summer camouflage which was baby-blue underneath and green topside. In his report afterwards, Peck wrote: 'Very pretty plane!'

But the Heinkel 113 never existed. It was a fiction. And the secret of this ghost-fighter lies buried in an old Air Ministry intelligence file, only recently declassified.

Peck was not the only pilot to meet the He.113. A Hurricane of 213 Squadron had claimed one shot down over Dunkirk as early as May 1940. Pilot Officer Boot had a dogfight with one in September 1940. A few days later, Pilot Officer Stavert got on to the tail of a He. 113 near Dover and left it diving in flames. That summer, every small boy in Britain carried a silhouette of the He.113 about with him in his Aircraft Recognition booklet. But it was a Nazi propaganda invention, fed into the food-chain of British intelligence where it thrived. Even Air-Marshal Hugh Dowding, head of Fighter Command, wrote in his famous Battle of Britain dispatch that the He.113 'made its appearance in limited numbers... its main attributes were high performance and ceiling...'

The story began in the 1930s, in the Heinkel works. Marshal Goering had ordered a few prototype Heinkel 112 fighters for the Luftwaffe, but in 1938 his advisers persuaded him that the main order for single-seat fighters should go to the Messerschmidt 109. Heinkel, cutting losses, sold the rejects to Franco's Spain and Japan, where they performed poorly. Then they produced a souped-up new He.112 version and - pretending it was a new design - named it the He.100. About a dozen were built. When war came, they flew guard duty over the Heinkel works near Rostock, but never saw action.

But in late 1939, Nazi intelligence stepped in. The 12 He.100s at Rostock were reinvented as the 'new Heinkel 113'. Painted with a variety of imaginary squadron markings, and photographed with Heinkel workers posing as pilots, they featured in press releases in the German papers which were eagerly reproduced abroad. In early 1940, pictures of them on 'Danish airfields' and reports of their prowess in the Norwegian campaign were fed down the same channels.

The British fell for it. In May 1940, the authoritative journal The Aeroplane carried a picture of the He.113 and an account of its dimensions. The Air Ministry entered the He.113 in its official recognition handbook for pilots. A secret Ministry document stated that at least one squadron was already in service.

Only one doubt was raised. The future Air Marshal Robert Saundby minuted that there was something odd about the photographs. There seemed to be no wing space for guns or ammunition. But now the Battle of Britain was starting. Soon pilots were seeing He.113s all over the place.

More stories and pictures appeared in Nazi-controlled Europe. A captured German pilot even confessed that the He.113 was 'not very satisfactory'.

And yet the truth lay under the noses of Air Intelligence. By the end of 1940, not one single He.113 could be proven to have been shot down. And in January 1941, just before the Nazi invasion of Yugoslavia, the British air attaché in Belgrade sent a coded despatch: 'According to certain confidential information, this aircraft presumably does not exist; i.e. the Germans have advertised it in order to give the enemy the impression that they possess such a powerful fighter ...'

Incredibly, almost the whole story had already been spelled out by an informer. In an interrogation report paper in the Air Intelligence files, a nameless 'source' who had apparently worked in the Rostock factory insisted that pictures of the He.113 in fact showed the He.100.

The document is dated 17 June 1940. But nobody wanted to know. Too many people, pilots or Ministry analysts, now had a stake in the He.113.

The files do not make clear when the Allies realised that this fighter had never existed. Possibly it was not until after the war. Modern histories of the air war and the Battle of Britain mention the He.113 only briefly, if at all. The reported kills were probably Messerschmidt 109s. Just possibly some of them were Spitfires, which had a passing resemblance to the phantom fighter.

Did this successful Nazi deception make any difference? Richard Overy, author of The Battle (a study of the Battle of Britain), doubts it: 'What skewed Air Ministry intelligence was an over-estimate of German aircraft numbers. The idea that many He.113 squadrons existed must have confirmed that. But in fact the myth only reinforced Dowding's strategy of holding back a large part of Fighter Command in reserve. And for the Battle of Britain, that strategy was successful.'

fields.headline: Divorce: he's richer, she's poorer
fields.standfirst: Impact of marriage break-up does not hit both partners equally, research shows
fields.trailText: Divorce makes men richer and women poorer. The finding has astonished researchers involved in a major study of the effects over time on the partners of a failed marriage, and confounds the common belief that both partners suffer financially.
fields.body:
Divorce makes men richer and women poorer. The finding has astonished researchers involved in a major study of the effects over time on the partners of a failed marriage, and confounds the common belief that both partners suffer financially.

The research tracked 10,000 people over a decade and found that men's disposable income increases by an average of 15 per cent after divorce, while women see theirs fall by around 28 per cent, mirroring the average gain they experience on marrying.

'Men bring more, economically speaking, to relationships and walk away with more, too,' said Dr Jonathan Scales, a research fellow at the Institute of Social and Economic Research, which carries out the British Household Panel Survey with the University of Essex.

'This is the first time the effect of divorce on the same group of people has ever been tracked over a long period of time, and we were amazed by the results,' said Scales.

The survey, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council with the support of the Future Foundation, returned each year from 1991 to question the same group of people about the effect on their lives of issues from the state of the labour market to workplace stress.

The sharp difference in earnings between the sexes partly explains why women see their incomes fall so dramatically after divorce. Unmarried women earn, on average, around 14 per cent less than male colleagues.

'There are also certainly divorced men who are getting their children brought up on the cheap,' said Scales, citing the Child Support Agency's report that only 48 per cent of absent fathers regularly pay full child support, while 29 per cent pay nothing at all.

But divorce experts believe there are other more complex reasons why men's incomes increase so sharply in the wake of a divorce.

'Divorce is a complete mess for women,' said Maryly La Follette, a partner at Charles Russell, divorce solicitors to Countess Spencer and Camilla Parker Bowles. 'I always tell husbands that they will have completely recovered from a divorce after five years and will probably be doing even better than before.

'It's completely inevitable and has nothing to do with men hiding their assets or refusing to pay for children,' she added.

'The odds of getting a fair divorce settlement are quite simply stacked against women.'

To get what she is really owed, said La Follette, a woman must return to court every two or three years to fight out a new settlement to take account of increasing childcare and general costs. 'Very few women can afford or bother to return to court to achieve this. And while she loses out, he profits.'

Gay Cox, a divorce expert at Family Mediation Scotland, said she had seen many cases where men's incomes have increased after their divorce. 'The earning capacity of divorced men increases for many reasons. There is such a fear of ending up poorer that newly divorced men frequently work their backs off to increase their earning capacity, taking advantage of the fact that there is now nothing to stop them working 18-hour days.'

This work binge is often spurred by a fear that, if they lapse in their financial commitments, the men's former spouses may resort to using children as emotional blackmail, she maintains.

About 141,000 divorces are granted in England and Wales each year, with around 12,000 in Scotland. On both sides of the border, courts compel the man to support his children until they have finished full-time education.

Scottish courts calculate a 50-50 split between the couple's assets and compel men to support their ex-wives for three years after the settlement has been established, a recent change in the law which has made divorce cheaper for Scottish men, according to Cameron Fyfe, a senior partner in Glasgow's Ross Harper Solicitors who specialises in divorce and compensation cases.

'This survey flies in the face of assumptions but adheres absolutely to my anecdotal experience,' he said. 'Women have a far higher earning capacity nowadays, which means that settlements are less draining for men than they once were.

'And although both members of the failed marriage will be worse off immediately after the divorce, this new three-year limit means the strain on men's pockets is relatively short-lived.'

webTitle: Darwin's theory was inspired by a hillock

fields.headline: Darwin's theory was inspired by a hillock
fields.trailText: For Isaac Newton, it was an apple tree; for Archimedes, a bath of water; and for Charles Darwin, scientific inspiration struck while staring at a 'tangled bank' of undergrowth, earthworms and weeds.
fields.body:
For Isaac Newton, it was an apple tree; for Archimedes, a bath of water; and for Charles Darwin, scientific inspiration struck while staring at a 'tangled bank' of undergrowth, earthworms and weeds.

Or at least, that's what he wrote of so eloquently in The Origin of Species. Scholars and biographers have speculated for years about this famous visual prompt. Was it a metaphor, or did it exist?

Now a new study of Darwin claims that the oft-quoted description of a 'tangled bank' at the end of The Origin of Species was based on a ridge in Bromley, Kent. Now the obscure site is a candidate for World Heritage Status as a cultural shrine equal to the Taj Mahal and Stonehenge.

The great, great grandson of Charles Darwin, Randal Keynes, is preparing a book of fresh evidence uncovered in the family's former home. Documents found by Keynes directed him towards Down Bank, in Kent, and a hillock called the Orchis Bank.

'This was well within Darwin's daily range and he walked around it for the 40 years he lived and worked in the area,' Keynes told The Observer.

'There is strong evidence to suggest that the wonderful passage at the end of The Origin of Species refers to this bank of foliage. It is a description that is easily remembered because it encapsulates everything Darwin was trying to say about his theories of natural selection and the struggle for life.'

In his great work of 1859 he proposed the idea that all species gradually evolved by diversifying. The vulnerable in any species do not survive, while helpful traits are repeatedly selected. It is known that Darwin formulated his revolutionary view - his 'one long argument' - as he walked in the grounds of his home, Down House, in Kent in the mid 1800s. He spent his early life in South America and the Galapagos Islands, but when he came to write, he saw in the English countryside examples of natural selection and animal behaviour.

The 'bank' passage begins: 'It is interesting to contemplate a tangled bank, clothed with many plants of many kinds, with birds singing on the bushes, with various insects flitting about, and with worms crawling through the damp earth, and to reflect that these elaborately constructed forms, so different from each other, and dependent on each other in so complex a manner, have all been produced by laws acting around us.'

Sir David Attenborough, the natural history expert, believes the lines embody all that Darwin was saying.

'Anybody who has heard about Darwin must be interested to know that this bank might really have existed,' he said. 'He used the "tangled bank" image for what we now call something like the "integrity of eco-systems".'

Keynes' book, Darwin and Annie's Box, will be published in the New Year. Central to its thesis is the nature of the fatal illness which killed Annie, Darwin's beloved daughter. Her death at the age of 10 is known to have deeply upset the scientist, who spent most of his days looking after his 10 children.

'Annie was regarded as a particularly lively girl,' said Keynes. 'She was obviously well-loved and regarded as a special child.'

Keynes' grandmother kept a small wooden writing box that had belonged to Annie, which Keynes inherited. Darwin and his wife, Emma, had stored a lock of Annie's hair and personal documents, together with her writing equipment, inside the box.

Keynes believes that the strength of Darwin's sympathy for his little girl - he suffered the same heart palpitations, stomach cramps and sweats - were a crucial in shaping his ideas about evolutionary distinction between animals and human beings. Keynes believes Annie's death pushed Darwin away from faith in God as a creator.

Down House is being restored by English Heritage. In addition to the World Heritage bid, there is a plan to link it with the Darwin Research Centre in the Galapagos Islands.

fields.headline: Brain drug reverses chronic Alzheimer's
fields.trailText: The brain of a 70-year-old woman suffering from severe Alzheimer's disease has been brought back to life by a new drug, leading scientists to believe that the illness could be reversible.
fields.body:
The brain of a 70-year-old woman suffering from severe Alzheimer's disease has been brought back to life by a new drug, leading scientists to believe that the illness could be reversible.

The researchers in Southampton showed that the drug Aricept revived whole regions of the woman's brain, leading to such a dramatic improvement in behaviour that her daughter declared: 'My mother is back!'

New scanning techniques showed that the woman's brain had apparently irreparable damage to the cells controlling short-term memory and other thinking functions. Dr Paul Kemp of the University of Southampton said they gave the woman the drug for four months and scanned her again: 'It showed clearly that the cells we thought were dead were in fact lying dormant and could be switched back on.'

The woman regained her memory, her ability to speak, and could again find her way around. Kemp said: 'It was a dramatic improvement - the Lazarus effect. She went from a severe form of dementia to a mild one.'

Aricept has been used in the US for a few years, but is largely unavailable in the UK because health authorities claim it does not work. The respected Drug and Therapeutics Bulletin has said it had virtually no effect. In patients where the progress of the disease slowed, other factors were often held responsible.

The new research, involving 25 patients, shows for the first time that Aricept can lead to a real physical improvement in the working of the brain. 'It's very scientifically objective, not a subjective clinical assessment,' said Kemp. 'It's a big step finding a drug that modifies the progression of the disease.'

Alzheimer's so severely damages the areas of the brain that control memory, talking, thinking, and navigation that they are effectively 'turned off', and blood no longer flows to them. After a sustained course of Aricept the blood started flowing again.

'It's like turning the tap back on. The damage was not permanent,' said Kemp. Previous research has suggested the drug can halt the progression of the disease only for around a year, and only in around a third of patients.

But Kemp says the dramatic findings show how the drug works, so they can learn to target it better and even develop a cure for the disease, which afflicts 500,000 people in the UK. Ronald Reagan and Dame Iris Murdoch are well-known victims.

The researchers hope treatment will follow a similar pattern to that of the previously untreatable Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's patients now are given dopamine, which arrests the development of the disease for decades.

'Eventually sufferers will die with the disease, rather than of the disease. They will live so long they die of something else,' said Kemp.

fields.headline: Bitter battle over hut holidaymakers
fields.standfirst: Lochside retreat is paradise for some, a potential goldmine for others
fields.trailText: Bill McQueen sits in his armchair tussling with the  Daily Record  crossword while his wife, Margaret, practises her cross-stitch at the kitchen table, occasionally casting a wary eye at the pot bubbling on the stove.
fields.body:
Bill McQueen sits in his armchair tussling with the Daily Record crossword while his wife, Margaret, practises her cross-stitch at the kitchen table, occasionally casting a wary eye at the pot bubbling on the stove.

On the other side of their patio doors, the tall trees leading down to the water are starting to show off their autumn colour, glinting gold in the wet October sunlight.

This weekend, as with every weekend for 17 years, the McQueens will be enjoying this cosy rural domestic bliss in a small wooden hut they built and cared for themselves at Carbeth, north of Glasgow. There, dotted around the undergrowth and invisible from the main road, is a tiny community of 150 green and brown huts which for 80 years have offered working-class Glaswegians a chance to escape city life and immerse themselves in some spectacular scenery.

But all is not as tranquil as it seems. The McQueens and dozens of their fellow residents are embroiled in a bitter legal battle with the owner of the estate their huts stand on. A low-key local disagreement over increases in ground rent has escalated into one of the most vicious land disputes in modern Scotland.

The hutters claim Allan Barns-Graham is trying to sweep them off the land in the name of profit; the landlord insists he is merely trying to make the estate pay its way. At stake are not just a few huts but a thread running right through the rich fabric of Glasgow working-class history.

The first Carbeth huts were built in the 1920s when the current landlord's grandfather, Allan Snr, allowed ex-servicemen to use his land to leave behind - for weekends at least - the crushing poverty of urban life. In the 1930s they were used as a training camp by socialists preparing to join the International Brigade fighting Franco's fascists in Spain. In the 1940s, they became home to hundreds of families forced to flee the Clydebank blitz.

Now the campers think there is a glimmer of hope. Next month, Stirlingshire council will be asked to make the Carbeth estate a conservation area. The hutters believe planning restrictions would then destroy any development plans by Barns-Graham who, they believe, wants to replace the huts with luxury tourist chalets.

Barns-Graham said: 'That is just pure misinformation put out through sheer badness. If I wanted to get rid of the huts, I would have let the area continue into decline, when in fact I have done the opposite, spending a lot of money on improving the infrastructure.'

But more than 80 of the hutters have received eviction notices from him after refusing to pay rent increases in some cases of up to 40 per cent.

There have been 17 court cases, all of which have gone in the landlord's favour. The hutters have learned that even though they own the buildings, the landlord can take possession of them because he owns the land they stand on.

By law, the McQueens should no longer be able to enjoy their long weekends at all; last year they lost their court battle against eviction after refusing to pay the increases which took their ground rent to £750 plus a £200 premium because their hut had a view of the loch.

And when Barns-Graham refused the McQueens' request to be allowed to pay the bill for his legal costs in instalments, the retired joiner was made bankrupt at the age of 70. There was worse to come.

Last summer, their hut and three others were burnt down. Fire brigade investigators found that petrol or some other accelerant had been used but no arrests have been made. With materials donated by their neighbours, they have managed to rebuild their hut. They know, however, that they are there on borrowed time. 'We are pensioners,' Mr McQueen said. 'I don't keep too well and neither does my wife. We've been coming here for 17 years, and we built that hut with our own hands. Yet he could send in the sheriff's officers and throw us out. It's a disgrace.'

Barns-Graham has a very different version of events. 'This rent strike is being organised by a small minority who do not have the interests of the huts at heart. They are pursuing their own agenda, and that has been very damaging for Carbeth.' He has said that they were refusing to pay the rents simply because they wanted their holidays for free.

fields.headline: The perfect cigar
fields.standfirst: Terence Conran
fields.trailText: Terence Conran
fields.body:
The perfect cigar is about ritual as well as smoking. The business of getting the cigar out of the box, cutting the end off, lighting it and having the first puff of the day with a cup of coffee is integral. I think you enjoy a cigar much more if you're on your own. I do smoke when I'm having a meeting with people, but it's not the best time. Smoking in the greenhouse with a glass of Armagnac is one of my greatest pleasures.

The perfect taste is a matter of opinion. My favourite cigar, Hoya de Monterrey, has a very robust flavour. It's rather like smelling a wonderful autumn bonfire. Everyone knows how thrilling that aroma is, and when you smoke a cigar there's that little bonfire burning just outside your mouth and the flavour of burning leaves in your mouth. It's incomparable.

Just like the rest of life, it is often the packaging that is a very important part of your enjoyment of the cigar. If you buy a shirt in a very nice box, beautifully folded in tissue paper, it adds to the appreciation of that particular bit of clothing. The cigar boxes and the graphics associated with them are wonderful. The little band around a Cohiba, the national cigar of Cuba, is particularly attractive. It's said that Castro designed it himself, but that's probably just clever spin.

Cigars must be kept slightly damp - they taste better like that. If they're dry, the outer skin that holds the smoke in becomes brittle and comes off in shards. I keep mine in the cellar, which is just damp enough, but, of course, people should use a humidor.

The perfect cigar is a total luxury. If I ever really thought about how much it cost, I'd probably never smoke another one.
